PROCTEXT.PARA: FIRST SESSION OF THE THIRTY-FIFTH PARLIAMENT
The Senate, on 21 December 1988, adjourned to 28 February 1989 unless the President fixed an earlier day of meeting.
Pursuant to the Resolution of the Senate passed on 21 December 1988, the Senate met on Tuesday, 28 February 1989, at 2 p.m.
The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: VACANCY IN REPRESENTATION OF NEW SOUTH WALES

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that yesterday Senator Gietzelt resigned from the Senate. Senator Gietzelt was a long-serving senator, having come to the Senate in 1971. He has had a long, distinguished career, including service as a Minister. On behalf of all honourable senators I pay tribute to his distinguished service and extend to him every good wish for his retirement.

INTERJECT.PARA: I present to the Senate Senator Gietzelt's letter of resignation and a copy of the letter by which, in accordance with section 21 of the Constitution, I have notified the Governor of New South Wales of the vacancy in the representation of that State consequent on Senator Gietzelt's resignation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Senator Gietzelt's letter has been common knowledge for about 24 hours and in the circumstances of his retirement I just wish to say a few brief words. Before entering parliament, Senator Gietzelt was very active in local government-as a shire councillor in Sutherland and as a member of the Executive of the Local Government Association of New South Wales. He was a senator for New South Wales from 1971 and until yesterday remained co-father of the Senate with Senator Durack, who is not here at the moment. He served on many committees of the Senate, including Finance and Government Operations, of which he was Chairman; Trade and Commerce; Foreign Affairs and Defence; and Science and the Environment. He was a delegate to constitutional conventions and also served on other committees.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Gietzelt was Minister for Veterans' Affairs from 1983 to 1987. As an ex-serviceman and a former member of the Executive of the New South Wales Branch of the Returned Services League, he maintained a strong commitment to the ex-service community. While Minister, he was responsible for implementing the recommendations of the Brand Review of the Repatriation Hospital System, which led to a significant upgrading of facilities in repatriation hospitals. Perhaps most important, however, he was the Minister responsible for the introduction of the Veterans' Entitlements Act in 1986. This Act, which was a landmark in repatriation legislation, consolidated and streamlined what had become a vast, unwieldy and almost impossible to comprehend set of repatriation Acts. It is a great credit to the Senate that it passed that legislation. He also had a great interest in Vietnam veterans and was responsible for setting up the first crisis accommodation centre for those veterans.

More importantly, from the point of view of this side of the chamber, Senator Gietzelt was a very long-serving member of the Australian Labor Party (ALP). He was a senior vice-president for a number of years and a convener of some national policy committees of the ALP, including the urban affairs committee and the legal and constitutional committee.

I conclude by saying that on a personal level I found, on occasions, Senator Gietzelt a man of some passion. In the course of our respective careers we had a number of disagreements but those disagreements were always very frank. On a number of occasions I recall that he expressed his disagreement in my office in a tone of voice which might, even in this building, have been heard on the House of Representatives side. I think those disagreements were always characterised by a degree of mutual respect and trust and we argued--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mutual respect and trust!

—I said `I think'. The honourable senator, in his eagerness, always interrupts. I was going to say that, for my part, that was certainly the case and I hope it was for Senator Gietzelt too. Certainly, on behalf of all Government senators I wish him well in his retirement. I am sure it will be a very active one in terms of community service, and we all wish him well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I keep reminding myself that we do not have a condolence motion before us; it is a much happier occasion than that, Senator Gietzelt having opted for voluntary retirement. We would all hope for a very happy and fulfilling retirement period. Indeed, on a day when my father is in the Parliament, I wish for Senator Gietzelt what my father has enjoyed since he left involuntarily nearly 20 years ago, namely, a very fulfilling and cheerful life outside this place. I say that to both Senator Gietzelt and Mrs Gietzelt.

SPEECH.PARA: I was very interested to read in the Sunday Telegraph the account by Kerry-Ann Walsh as to why the senator came back and why he has chosen to leave. We are told:
. . . quite unabashed about the timing of his departure from the federal Parliamentary scene after 18 years.

He wanted to make sure his Senate spot would be taken by Mr John Faulkner, one of the few left-wingers operating out of the heavily right-wing dominated New South Wales Labor headquarters. If Gietzelt had retired at the last Federal election, Faulkner would not have secured the seat because of his placement on the ticket. Only a casual vacancy would secure Faulkner's future.

Given the performance of the New South Wales right wing, and particularly its management of the economy over recent times, I can only say that it is time the left wing had a go in here. We look forward to Mr John Faulkner's contribution in this place to see whether he can improve on the right wing of New South Wales and its abominable performance in this place up to this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to add to the comments that have been made about our former Senate colleague Arthur Gietzelt, particularly from my position as a vice-chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. Although our politics were widely different I always found Arthur to be a man of honour and total integrity. I was especially pleased when he joined the Joint Committee of Public Accounts after the 1987 election, when he left the Ministry. Often senior parliamentarians, after leaving ministerial office, decide to coast along until their retirement, but that was not Arthur's way. He became a member of the Public Accounts Committee and involved himself energetically with several major inquiries, including one into veterans' issues. Arthur's recent experience in government proved very valuable. He always gave wise counsel to the work of the Committee. He also served as Chairman of Estimates Committee C and as a member of a number of Senate standing committees on community affairs. I place on record my regard for the Hon. Arthur Gietzelt as a parliamentary committee member and offer my very best personal wishes to him in his retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I join with the comments made by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) and Senator Watson and associate my colleagues with those remarks. It is always nice to be able to comment on somebody leaving this place alive. I remember particularly working with Arthur Gietzelt on the legislation that Senator Button raised, that is, the Veterans' Entitlements Act, which was a massive piece of work that Senator Gietzelt managed to put through while he was Minister for Veterans' Affairs. It was something with which other Ministers and Senator Messner had been wrestling for a long period. Indeed, it was a herculean task and to have got the legislation through, despite the fact that it sat in the Senate for about nine months all told while the negotiations went on, shows that he had the capacity to stay in there, fight for the legislation and also work very hard when delicate negotiations were required on the finer points with the political parties in this place and in the face of divisions in the veterans community at that time over certain aspects of the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that Arthur Gietzelt will have a long retirement. However, knowing him, I am quite sure that it will not be a quiet one and I expect that we will hear from him from time to time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Arthur Gietzelt has been my closest political associate over a period of 35 years. He is one of the most hardworking people I have ever met. In local government in the Sutherland Shire many of the initiatives with which he was associated have continued to this day. As a member of executive local government he has been an inspiration to many hundreds of people on the Labor side of politics in terms of the local government initiatives with which he was associated. He is currently Senior Vice-President of the Australian Labor Party and has been a longstanding member of the National Executive of the Party, once again concentrating on the national needs of the Party through its executive. From the very first time I met him he has always found time to be involved in the peace and nuclear disarmament movement. He has been very active in that sphere regardless of other responsibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: He surprised other people, but not me, when he became Minister for Veterans' Affairs. The veterans community is traditionally regarded as a conservative constituency. He won the respect of people in the veterans' community for his work, to which Senator Button has referred. He has a characteristic of always looking for the best in people. He has always sought to build bridges with people who do not agree with him. That quality, which he has enjoyed over the years, commends itself to us all. I know that he has always encouraged young people to be active. Furthermore, he has always had a wide number of interests, but he also applies himself to detail. I know of nobody who has been as keen as Arthur to pay attention to detail, and many political opponents have regretted that they have not given such attention to detail. I know that in retirement he will be able to spend more time with his wife, Dawn, and can indulge his only vice, which has been fairly secretive until now: the occasional punt on Saturday afternoon.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I have had a very limited acquaintance with Senator Gietzelt, and perhaps on those grounds would not normally seek to speak. However, I would not wish any failure of a National Party speaker to rise to lead to any possible misconstruction. I simply wish to say that on such infrequent occasions as I did have discussions with Senator Gietzelt I always found him a most pleasant, relaxed personality and not in the least the kind of tense, shouting individual in some moods whom Senator Button perhaps portrayed. On the contrary, I always found him a most pleasant person. I wish Senator Gietzelt and his wife a very happy retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to add briefly to the comments made by my colleagues, and particularly to those made by Senator Childs, whose remarks I endorse. I served with Arthur Gietzelt on the National Executive of the Australian Labor Party for 14 years and it is to that aspect of his activities that I wish to refer. Until my retirement as National Secretary he, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and I were the three longest serving members of the executive, having served together continuously for those 14 years. In common with everybody else who has spoken, I have at times strongly disagreed with Arthur about issues on which we have worked together. What was consistent was his commitment to the Labor Party as a national organisation and his preparedness to fight very hard within the Party for those things in which he believed. If he were successful he would go forward with the proposal, but if unsuccessful he would accept the outcome and go forward with the collective decision of the Party and implement it to the best of his ability. In that period he became Junior Vice-President and then Senior Vice-President of the Party. He chaired many important, historic meetings of the Executive. When the history of the Party is written, the role that he played will be recorded.

SPEECH.PARA: No new, young member of the National Executive, as I was in 1973, or new National Secretary, as I was in 1981, could have asked for more friendship or support than I received from Arthur Gietzelt. I noticed from time to time that, not unlike some boilermakers I used to know in the trade union movement, Arthur's deafness came on very suddenly when he did not want to hear what you were saying, although sometimes it did not fade when you wished that he could not hear what you were saying. Nevertheless, he persevered in the face of this affliction and was a very successful and effective contributor to the Executive. I enjoyed working with him. I wish him and Dawn a very long and happy retirement.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF FORMER SENATORALBERT GEORGE POKE

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on 4 January 1989 of former Senator Albert George Poke, senator for Tasmania from 1956 to 1974.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on 4 January 1989, of Albert George Poke, Senator for the State of Tasmania from 1956 to 1974, places on record its appreciation of his meritorious public service and tenders its sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

The late Senator Poke was born at Somerset, Tasmania, on 16 February 1906 and was an Australian Labor Party senator for the State of Tasmania from 1956 to 1974. As of yesterday only two senators, Senator Arthur Gietzelt and Senator Peter Durack, would have been senators over that period. During his time in the Senate he was a Temporary Chairman of Committees. He served on various parliamentary committees, including the Senate Select Committee on Foreign Ownership and Control. He was also a member of delegations both to Inter-Parliamentary Union and to Commonwealth Parliamentary Association conferences. He was Deputy Opposition Whip in the Senate from February 1962 to December 1972, which I suspect must be a record period in that office.

The late Senator Poke will be remembered with gratitude by the Labor Party for his tireless service. He was a lifetime member of the Party, and was Vice-President of the Tasmanian branch. He served as Treasurer of the State branch in 1974 and 1975. Prior to entering Parliament he was an engine driver and Secretary of the Timber Workers Union of Tasmania from 1946 to 1956. He was President of the Miscellaneous Workers Union of Tasmania from 1958 to 1972. He was a loyal and tireless worker for his Party, a respected member of the Senate and a diligent contributor to the committees of the Senate. On behalf of the Government I extend to his family our most sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I join with the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) in expressing support for this condolence motion. I express our sympathy for the family of the late Senator Poke. He was one of the very large number of earlier members of the parliamentary Labor Party who had a lengthy career in the trade union movement. He was an engine driver and, later, the secretary of his union for just under 10 years. He continued his close association with the union movement when he was in this place, combining, as Senator Button has pointed out, the presidency of the Miscellaneous Workers Union of Tasmania with his role as a senator. Some might regret that those traditions have not been kept alive as much as they might have been, but in any event Senator Poke made a good contribution to this place. We express our sorrow at his death.
—I would like to associate Australian Democrat senators with this motion of condolence and convey our sympathy to the family of the late ex-Senator Poke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to support the condolence motion. Bob Poke and I were State colleagues in this Parliament and in Caucus. I was in my first term, and he was in what turned out to be his last term. So I only knew him well during the latter part of his parliamentary service, as he retired after the 1974 double dissolution. Bob Poke as he was known-I do not think he was ever known as Albert George Poke-was one of those people who are very much the salt of the earth. He had firm views and those views were firmly expressed. I was able to attend his funeral in January. Many Australian Labor Party stalwarts, including the former Deputy Prime Minister, Lance Barnard, were there. The former leader in this place, Ken Wriedt, spoke at the funeral service. I would like to express my thanks for his service to the people of Tasmania and the labour movement as a union official and a senator. I express my condolences to his family, not only to those whom I had not met until the funeral but also to his widow, Alice.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

DEBATE.TITLE: GOVERNMENT TECHNOLOGY PRODUCTIVITY AWARDS: PARLIAMENTARY INFORMATION SYSTEMS OFFICE

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform honourable senators that the implementation of information systems facilities in this building by the Parliamentary Information Systems Office was awarded six gold awards for improved performance through technological innovation at the Government in Technology Awards dinner last night. This major implementation which all occupants of this building are benefiting from was achieved with considerable cost savings through integration across the five parliamentary departments. I am sure all senators will join with me in congratulating Mark Goodall and the whole team who work in the Parliamentary Information Systems Office.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
X-rated video material contravenes Christian moral beliefs in that,
1. the status of both women and men are degraded by the material,
2. children could gain access to the material, much to the detriment of their moral development,
3. the material often promotes and encourages criminal acts.

Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate to put pressure on the Government immediately to implement the recommendation of the majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material by introducing substantive legislation to ensure that X-rated video material (and its R rated equivalent) is refused classification for the purpose of Commonwealth laws.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BISHOP; BUTTON; CHANEY; GILES; MCKIERNAN; PUPLICK
PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programs for children and particularly those programs promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray: that you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programs for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by WA Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. This Act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programs that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bishop (from 48 citizens), Button (from 13 citizens), Chaney (from 13 citizens), Giles (from 12 citizens), McKiernan (from 13 citizens), and Puplick (from 13 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated and Violent Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Parliamentary Joint Select Committee on Video Material has concluded that `Adverse effects upon people, and especially upon children, of exposure to material containing various degrees of violence, pornography or obscenity have been demonstrated'.
The majority of the Select Committee strongly opposed the proposition for a new NVE (non-violent erotica) category, which would have entrenched X-rated video pornography.
All six State Governments have, through their Attorneys-General, expressed unanimous opposition to the circulation of X-rated videos.
We consider the continuing distribution of X-rated videos from the Australian Capital Territory to be reprehensible and to be contrary to the wellbeing of the Australian community in general.
We strongly request urgent Government action to prohibit the distribution of X-rated and excessively violent video material.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Borroloola Township Telephone Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: We, the undersigned:
(i) request that Telecom Aust. repair, and maintain in a fully operational order, the telephone service into the Borroloola township.
(ii) request that Telecom Aust. fully refund the rental and call charge fees for the past month as the service has been totally unacceptable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) condemns the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) for his intemperate and unjustified attack on the Senate Committee system and, in particular, the work of the Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs;

(b) rejects Mr Hand's assertion that civil liberties are threatened by the operation of Senate committees, that individuals have no right of reply and that the recently concluded inquiry into Aboriginal affairs policy is a `political stunt';
(c) reminds the Minister that the Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs has a majority of Government members;

(d) calls on the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), to dissociate the Government from Mr Hand's comments and from similar attacks by the Premiers of Western Australia and Victoria; and
(e) reaffirms its confidence in the integrity of the Committee system which has enjoyed all-Party support for a period of almost 20 years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) congratulates the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Ray) for his honest, perceptive and informed comments made in Hong Kong to the effect that there has been no evidence of a drop in business migration from Asia as a result of any informed debate about immigration policies within Australia; and

(b) further congratulates Senator Ray, the Minister best placed to make informed comments on this matter, for his complete exposure of the misinformation and clearly untrue statements made on this question by his colleagues, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans), and suggests that Senator Ray make them aware of the truth in the hope that it might, for once, influence them.

DEBATE.TITLE: TENURE OF OFFICE OF APPOINTEES TO COMMONWEALTH TRIBUNALS: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a joint select committee be appointed to inquire into and report on the principles that should govern the tenure of office of quasi-judicial and other appointees to Commonwealth tribunals and in particular whether the provisions of sections 24 and 28 of the Industrial Relations Act provides proper and adequate provision for the tenure of office of Presidential members and Commissioners of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

(2) That the committee consist of 9 members, 3 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Government Whip or Whips, 2 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Opposition Whip or Whips, 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and 1 Senator to be nominated by any minority group or groups or independent Senator or independent Senators.
(3) That every nomination of a member of the committee be forthwith notified in writing to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives.
(4) That the committee elect a government member as its chairman.

(5) That the committee elect a deputy chairman who shall act as chairman of the committee at any time when the chairman is not present at a meeting of the committee and at any time when the chairman and deputy chairman are not present at a meeting of the committee the members present shall elect another person to act as chairman at that meeting.
(6) That 4 members of the committee constitute a quorum of the committee.
(7) That the committee have power to send for persons, papers and records.
(8) That the committee have power to move from place to place.
(9) That the committee report by 30 June 1989.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matters be referred to the Standing Committee of Legal and Constitutional Affairs for inquiry and report on or before the last sitting day of the penultimate week of the 1989 autumn sittings of the Senate:
(a) the adequacy and appropriateness of section 72 (ii) of the Constitution as the only basis on which judges can be removed from office;

(b) the adequacy and appropriateness of the matching provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 for the removal from office of presidential members of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission;

(c) the need for, the type of, alternative mechanisms for the removal of judges from office with paramount regard being paid to the need to protect the independence of the judiciary, the rule of law and the role of Parliament in the process;

(d) the workability and effectiveness of courts and the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission (or the new Industrial Relations Commission) being responsible for the arrangement of their business, with particular regard to the utilisation of all judges on those courts and the role of Parliament, if any, in that arrangement;

(e) whether any charge of misbehaviour or incapacity within the meaning of the Act has been made against Mr Justice Staples, a deputy president of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and if such a charge could be made out to the satisfaction of the Committee;

(f) the compatibility of the Government's method of removing Mr Justice Staples from office with the existing mechanisms for removing judges from office and with any alternative mechanisms which the Committee might propose; and
(g) whether any action should be taken to appoint Mr Justice Staples to a position on the Industrial Relations Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) condemns the remarks of Senator Hill in Tasmania on 2 February 1989, stating that domestic violence is a `soft issue' for women;
(b) condemns the Opposition for not correcting Senator Hill for this appalling attitude;

(c) condemns Senator Hill for suggesting that domestic violence is not an `economic issue', and in particular for failing to understand the considerable cost, not only in human misery and suffering, but, in hard dollars, of broken homes, services to assist victims of violence and perpetrators of violence and of legal and law enforcement costs; and
(d) condemns Senator Hill and the Opposition for failing to appreciate the steps this Government has taken and is taking to address this terrible problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice on behalf of myself and a number of other coalition senators that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) condemns the threats made against the British author, Mr Salman Rushdie;
(b) emphasises the need for a united front by the democracies in the face of this act of international terrorism and state-sponsored terrorism at that;
(c) calls on the Australian Government to fully support the actions of the United Kingdom and other European Governments by withdrawing our Ambassador from Tehran;
(d) declares its total support for the right of freedom of expression by all people in any country; and
(e) indicates to the Australian Government that it regards Australia's response so far as quite inadequate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes the latest attempt by the Hawke Labor Government to hoodwink the Australian people with an image-polishing exercise directed at women;
(b) further notes that, after 6 years of the Hawke Labor Government, the women of Australia feel cheated and deprived of their entitlement to decent living standards; and
(c) condemns the Hawke Labor Government for failing to provide Australian women and their families with:
(i) financial security,
(ii) affordable housing and health care,
(iii) freedom from the fear of violence at home and in the streets,
(iv) a drug free culture,
(v) access to superannuation benefits,
(vi) job opportunities for their children, and
(vii) a reduction in the heavy burden of taxation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) deplores the action of the Ayatollah Komeini of Iran in having commissioned the killing of British author Mr Salman Rushdie in retribution for controversial passages in the book The Satanic Verses;

(b) upholds the democratic right of any citizen to profess or practise any faith, doctrine or way of life which does not inflict nor intend harm against the interests and equivalent rights of other citizens;
(c) reaffirms the rights of Australians to sell, buy and read any book when such actions do not infringe lawful standards of procurement, publication style or content;

(d) appreciates the dilemma of booksellers who may deem it necessary to interrupt the free sale of literature in the face of threatened and demonstrated violence against their property, employees and customers;

(e) deplores the abuse of Australian residency and liberty exhibited by unknown persons who have threatened or committed violence against persons or property in contravention of the laws of the States and the Commonwealth of Australia;
(f) requests that the Government act decisively to restore order and the enjoyment of traditional liberties;
(g) seeks clarification of reported complaints that the Australian Federal Police have advised booksellers against storing and displaying copies of The Satanic Verses;
(h) strongly supports Australian booksellers and other citizens in totally rejecting and opposing any unlawful action to censor or suppress the distribution of the book;
(i) nevertheless recommends that booksellers have regard for the sensitivities of Australian Muslims and avoid undue provocation in their display and promotion of The Satanic Verses; and
(j) commends the moderate and responsible stance which has been adopted in this issue by Islamic leaders and their communities in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes the visit to Libya by Senator Dunn, 3 Victorian Labor members of Parliament, Joan Coxsedge, Jean McLean and George Crawford, and a representative of the Australian Democrats;
(b) notes that the visit was arranged by Mr Robert Pash of the Libyan funded Libyan Cultural Centre in Melbourne, and Colonel Gaddafi's representative in Australia;

(c) expresses its concern that these persons allowed themselves to be used as pawns by the Libyan Government despite the fact that the Federal Government ceased diplomatic relations with Libya in 1987 because of Libya's terrorist activities and destablising international policies with particular regard to the Pacific region;

(d) notes that, at their meeting with the Secretary of the General People's Congress, Mr Abdelhamid, he stated that the Libyan Government took their presence `as a sign of solidarity with the country' following the shooting down in self defence by United States fighter planes of 2 Libyan MIG jets;
(e) notes that Colonel Gaddafi told the delegation that its visit `would have a positive effect on public opinion'; and
(f) expresses its concern that because of the farcical nature of the trip to Libya, Australia has been brought into disrepute in the world arena, laying it open to ridicule and scorn.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT (SAVINGS ACCOUNTS INTEREST) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following Bill be introduced:
A Bill for an Act to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to grant exemption from income tax of certain income from savings accounts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes the trial of 10 dissidents in Czechoslovakia in February 1989, charged in connection with a demonstration on the 20th anniversary of the death of Jan Palach, when they laid flowers at the site of his suicide in Wenceslas Square in 1968;

(b) notes, too, the sentence of 9 months passed on Vaclav Havel as a result of the trial, the sentence of 12 months and 9 months passed on independent peace activists Otakar Veverka and Jana Petrova, and the fines and suspended sentences allocated to the 7 others tried with them; and

(c) commends Charter 77 for its continued witness for human rights in Czechoslovakia and the Independent Peace Association for its continuing critique of bloc alignment between East and West, despite ongoing harassment from the current conservative hardline regime in Prague.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON CORPORATIONS LEGISLATION

PROCTEXT.PARA: (1) That the time for presentation of the report of the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation be extended to 13 April 1989.
(2) That a message be sent to the House of Representatives requesting its concurrence in the foregoing resolution.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. I refer the Minister to his comments on the Face to Face television program last October when, after the then very bad balance of payments figures for July and August, he referred to the need to wait for at least one more month's figures but said that if the trend continued the Government would need to review the economic strategy announced in the August Budget Papers, and that under those circumstances the Government `might have to do something on the expenditure side'. Now that September, October, November, December and, of course, worst of all, January have produced further massive balance of payments deficits producing a cumulative current account deficit for the first seven months of this financial year which is already in excess of the Budget estimate for the year as a whole, does the Minister now believe that the conditions for a review of the Government's economic strategy as announced by the Treasurer last August have been satisfied? In particular, does he now agree that there is a need for an early statement on cuts in this Government's own spending or, to use a more colloquial term, a mini-Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it was in October that I said what I had been quoted as having said. I think it was quoted correctly. That is now four months ago. In that intervening four months there has been, as I am sure Senator Stone well knows, a very significant tightening of monetary policy. It may be less effective in curbing excessive demand than monetary policy was in a regulated financial system-either less effective absolutely, or it has taken, it would appear, a somewhat longer time to bite. That of course is not fully apparent, or the expectation that the tight monetary policy has substantially curbed demand is barely apparent in the published statistics because of the normal time lags, although in the house building industry there are some indications that that has already had an effect on demand.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer was making those points 10 or 11 days ago. The Treasurer's view was strongly reinforced by an article written by Don Stammer of Bain and Co. for the Business Review Weekly and published last week, a study of which I commend to members of the Senate. Notwithstanding somewhat slack newspaper comment to the contrary, it was also substantially reinforced by the report prepared by Barry Hughes, or Professor Hughes as he is these days, of Newcastle University, a copy of which I have in front of me. I acknowledge that there are many qualifications in this table. But based on an assumption that the response, demand-wise, to the monetary policy tightening that has happened this year would be similar to that which happened in 1986, Dr Hughes calculated that, on a calendar year basis, the current account deficit for 1989 could come in at less than $10 billion. I stress that there were many qualifications but that is what the table shows. As for expenditure cuts, it is always arguable whether the existing level of expenditure is the appropriate level. I suggest that what is not arguable at this stage is that the country cannot afford the vast array of increased expenditures that the Opposition has been proposing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his response and in particular for his reference to the fact that the Government's only response to the increasingly serious position on the balance of payments to date has been-and I think I quote him correctly-a significant tightening of monetary policy. Of course the Minister also said that that significant tightening had not yet had time, however, to be effective, or at any rate that such effectiveness as it had was only barely apparent. In view of the Minister's reference also to the interesting and fascinating report by Professor Hughes, which I have also read, would the Minister agree that that report, while admittedly qualified as he quite rightly described it as being, drew as the alternative to the response of the economy to that monetary tightening, to which the Minister referred-namely, a response rather like the downturn in the economy in 1986-the downturn that occurred in 1982. In any case, will the Minister confirm that the Hughes document indicated that, if we got a response like that in 1986-which I gather was the Minister's preferred interpretation-the bottom of the cyclical response would occur in the September quarter of this year. Is the Minister telling us that we have another seven months to wait before we see the full response to what the Government is alleged to have done to the economy so far?

—I said just a couple of minutes ago that the effects of the tightening of monetary policy were barely apparent in the published statistics. In all the published statistics there is a significant time lag, and in some there is a time lag of several months. By definition, nobody can be certain of just what the statistics for the period we are going through right now will show when they are ultimately published. In reference to the Hughes article, in which Hughes described 1982 as a crash landing, or something like that, I think I can give one guarantee. Indeed, I will give a personal guarantee of this or I will not be Finance Minister any more. This Government will not produce under any circumstances a Budget as irresponsible as the one John Howard produced in 1982 and which was rightly condemned by Senator Stone.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. While Australia imposes very high safety standards on its domestic civil aircraft, what checks for safety and airworthiness do Australian civil aviation authorities make on overseas registered aircraft which visit Australia? Is the Minister aware that a United Airlines B747 aircraft landed at Tokyo in May last year with three out of its four engines not working and that the particular aircraft involved is a frequent visitor to Australia? Was the aircraft involved in the Honolulu accident last weekend a sister Boeing aircraft to the one involved in the Tokyo incident? Is he aware that, with the apparent exception of one aircraft, this particular type of B747 is not the type operated by Qantas Airways Ltd?

—International airlines which enter Australia, all come from countries which are contracting states of the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) and the aviation regulatory authorities in these countries, rather than Australia, are responsible for ensuring that their international carriers do meet the ICAO agreed safety standards. As to the latter questions, I am unable to comment on whether and how often the United Airlines Boeing 747 involved in the Tokyo incident flies to Australia, but I can confirm that the aircraft involved is of the B747-100 series and that Qantas has only one of this series in its fleet.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. I refer him to the promise made by the Prime Minister on 23 June 1987 that `by 1990 no child will be living in poverty'. Is this promise still operative and, in the light of the very disturbing report on homeless children last week, can the Minister advise the Senate of children who are living in poverty now, just 10 months away from 1990?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is probably nothing more disappointing in this Parliament than the degree of hypocrisy that has been shown--

—Either Opposition senators want an answer to this question or they do not. If they do I suggest that they keep quite. Nothing is more disappointing than the degree of hypocrisy that has been shown by the Opposition, both in terms of its track record and of its promise, especially when one compares those with this Government's track record, promise and commitment. This question has been asked this afternoon by Senator Chaney who was a member of the previous Fraser-Howard Government-a regime which, during its term of office, managed to put at least 400,000 children into the poverty bracket. For the first six years of the seven years of conservative rule we had 50,000 children per year added to that bracket. In the last year of conservative rule a massive 150,000 children were added to that bracket. Not only did the previous Government do that, but also at the same time it managed to slash the level of income support for children, especially those of low income earners. That is not the end of the Opposition's performance in this area--

—I raise a point of order. The Minister started his answer with a reference to hypocrisy. He was asked a perfectly simple question about a clear and apparently unequivocal undertaking by the Prime Minister in 1987 that by 1990 no child would be living in poverty. The answer that has been given so far is entirely irrelevant to the Government's intentions in respect of this promise and whether it is still operative. My point of order is that the answer so far is totally irrelevant to the question which has been asked. I ask you, Mr President, to ask the Minister to direct himself to the question which was asked and not simply to go off on a general frolic in order to try to avoid answering.
—There is no point of order. The Minister has made a long preamble but I think he is about to answer the question.

—I think it should also be stated that, as the Prime Minister said in the other place just a few minutes ago, the Government is still committed to that promise and believes that it is still very much on track in achieving it. The Prime Minister also made the point-and I wish to make it again in answer to Senator Chaney's question-that when we look at this Government's performance in this area which is precisely what Senator Chaney asked about we should look at the Burdekin report and compare this Government's policies in achieving some redress in these areas mentioned by Mr Brian Burdekin with those of the Opposition. The Burdekin report raises a number of highly complex and sensitive issues involved with child homelessness and child poverty. The basic one is that of, on the one hand, needing to help young people remain with their families and, on the other, ensuring that those people who cannot or should not remain with their families have avenues for leaving. The report also highlights the central role of community organisations and State governments in redressing the problem.

ANSWER.PARA: This Government has already commenced consideration of the report. However, it should be noted that, on an analysis of the report, our policies stand up very well when compared with those of the Opposition. The report emphasises the role of family poverty. There can be no doubt at all about the approach that the Opposition will be taking in this area. Let us look at the Opposition's comment in Future Directions:

Labor policies have attempted to shield certain groups in the community from the effects of reduced national income. Unless these policies are reversed the current account deficit will continue to grow.

It is obvious that the Opposition is unambiguous there. The mechanisms which this Government has been concerned to put in place, whether they be family packages, child care places or whatever, are the sorts of mechanisms that find no place at all in the general economic direction that Mr Howard and Dr Hewson put.

The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission points to exploitation of young people by employers as a major problem of youth homelessness and child poverty. It is the centrepiece of Opposition policy to deregulate the youth labour market in an area which Mr Burdekin highlights as being extremely important. Mr Burdekin also talks at some length about difficulties of access to health services, particularly if young people have to pay up front for those services. It is precisely this sort of policy put by the Opposition, through its spokesperson, Mr Shack, that will aggravate the situation of young people. The Commission points to the devastating effect of youth unemployment. We need look only at the Opposition's history in that respect.

This Government has been committed, is committed and will be committed to meeting the particular promise made by the Prime Minister in 1987. We are the Government that has put in place mechanisms such as the job search allowance and schemes to assist sole parents, to ensure that people have access to employment in the market-place. It is also this Government that has assisted in terms of providing school places and encouraging the development of appropriate curricula to enable young people to stay at school. Let us remember that over the period of this Government the Year 12 retention rate has increased from 36 per cent under the Government of which the Leader of the Opposition was a member to 65 per cent. That in itself is a major achievement.

We inherited a situation in 1983 where 266,000 children at least were dependent on the unemployment benefit. We have reduced that number; by 1988 there were only 204,000. Every year since 1983 we have made significant improvements in the level of payments for children-from 11 per cent of married rate pension when we took over to 14 per cent for children up to the age of 13 in 1987 and 17.2 per cent for children over the age of 13. Our commitment is to achieve the benchmarks of 15 per cent of the married rate pension for the under 13s and 20 per cent for older children. In our policy speech the Prime Minister has committed the Government to achieving these benchmarks and we are very much on track in doing that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—There might be guffaws on the other side, but when we talk about child poverty we must consider the whole range of measures that this Government has introduced. The family allowance supplement is one extremely important measure and the rent assistance increase is another that will affect and assist 103,000 families. We have also streamlined the operation of the family allowance system. The indictment of the hypocritical criticism from the other side comes from Commissioner Burdekin himself, who pointed out that this Government's reforms alone have lifted 400,000 children out of poverty. I have mentioned only some of the schemes. I have referred to the child support scheme, geared very much to assisting hundreds of thousands of children in sole parent families following marriage separation, stage one of which is in operation, and of which stage 2 will come into operation in the middle of this year. As I have already mentioned, New Start and Jet are two other programs.

ANSWER.PARA: In summing up, it should be noted that the Hawke Labor Government has allocated $1.5 billion by way of family allowance supplements to assist the particular people about whom Senator Chaney is concerned. In terms of our promise, as the Prime Minister said, we will deliver on target to make sure child payments are adequate and we will develop and deliver child support schemes to protect those custodians. I believe that the Government's record in this area is on track. We recognise that the complexity of the problem is not easy to grapple with.

TALK.START.PARA: —Go round the shelters.

—And we recognise, Senator Walters, that there needs to be a response from all tiers of government and from the community to defeat this problem. The debate is not helped by the apparent division in the Opposition, when Mr Howard says that this problem should be treated in a bipartisan way and at the same time his spokesperson, Mr Connolly, parades on every radio and television station trying to exploit the issue.

—I ask a supplementary question. I welcome the fact that the Minister has said that it remains Government policy that by 1990 no child will be living in poverty. I note that he totally ignored the second part of the question, in which I asked him to give the Government's estimate of the number of children now, 10 months from 1990, living in poverty. I refer him to the Burdekin report, which in paragraph 9.22 says that after the Government's family assistance package, an estimated 440,000 children would continue to live in poverty. What is the Government's estimate?

—There are two parts to the answer. It should be noted, as I said in my first answer, that Commissioner Burdekin noted that the reforms this Government introduced have in themselves lifted 400,000 children out of poverty. It should also be recognised in this context that Helen Brownlee of the Institute of Family Studies has recognised our programs here as achieving great inroads into child poverty. I shall take the second part of the question on notice and obtain the information for Senator Chaney. It cannot be denied by the Opposition that this Government has taken initiatives, and that those initiatives have been recognised not only by independent spokespeople but also by Commissioner Burdekin.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. What is the Government's timetable for the integration of repatriation hospitals with the State hospital systems? When the repatriation hospitals are transferred to State control, will veterans be guaranteed priority of access and quality of health care as they are under the present system? Will ex-service groups be involved in consultations regarding the way in which the integration proceeds? Could there by any circumstances under which the integration will not proceed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has announced that the repatriation hospitals will be transferred to State hospital systems by 1 July 1995.
—Just table the answer and save us the time.

—Some people are interested in this subject, Senator Stone. Some hospitals may be transferred before that date if satisfactory arrangements can be achieved earlier. Unambiguous guarantees have been given by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and by the Prime Minister that integration would not proceed until such time as veterans and war widows can be guaranteed priority of access to hospital facilities and the same quality of care as that which is presently available. Ex-service organisations are involved in consultation on integration at the national level and in each State and the national committee will be the major negotiating forum. It will make recommendations to Government on all matters of concern to ex-service organisations and all proposed arrangements for the transfer. The State committees will provide a forum for discussion with State representatives of the ex-service organisations concerning progress with local, Commonwealth and State organisations.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to Senator Colston's last question, the Government believes that integration is the best means of ensuring that the long term interests of the veterans community are maintained and that integration will result in a clear role within the State system and provide an ageing treatment population with care closer to home, families and friends. However, if satisfactory arrangements cannot be reached with State governments, particularly on the critical issues of priority of access and quality of care, integration will not proceed in that State.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to statements made by him last year in which he claimed that the proposed Wesley Vale pulp mill would mean a net addition of up to $300m to the balance of payments. I ask the Minister: What is the source of this figure? Has it been checked by any independent economic analysis? If so, by whom, and if not, why not? Does it take into account such factors as economic loss caused by damage to the Tasmanian fishing industry through the chemical pollution of waterways? Has any assessment been made of the damage to Tasmania's export potential in other areas of primary industry if that State's reputation for producing unpolluted foodstuffs is tarnished by the presence of chemical waste from pulp mills? Does the $300m figure take into account the repatriation of Noranda's share of profits received and the writing off against tax of interest payments? Finally, what proportion of the profits derived from the proposed Wesley Vale mill will remain in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Haines has always taken a general interest in the matter raised in the last part of her question, repatriation of profits and so on, but the burden of her question, of course, relates to the effects on Australia's trade position. The joint venture partners, North Broken Hill Holdings Ltd and Noranda, have claimed that the Wesley Vale mill will have a beneficial effect on Australia's trade position of $300m a year, as reported in the newspapers, or $280m a year, which was the figure given in relation to the environmental impact statement. That claim, as I understand it, was based on the calculation of projected exports times the price of pulp minus woodchip exports forgone and was made before the Canadian joint venture partner, Noranda, became involved.

ANSWER.PARA: I was asked whether there has been any independent assessment of this. I am aware of a paper entitled `Economic Implications of an Export Pulp Mill in Northern Tasmania-A Critical Review and Extension' written by Dr Neville Norman of the Department of Economics at the University of Melbourne. He estimated that the effect on the current account would range from a negative impact of up to $165m a year during the construction phase-accounting for imports of plant and equipment, a $1 billion investment in total-to a positive impact on the current account rising from $70m in 1992 to $260m in the late 1990s as the mill becomes operational and improves its efficiency over time. Dr Norman's analysis did account for the fact that Noranda will not be paying for its 50 per cent of the pulp produced, but neither will its borrowings have current account implications because those borrowings will be overseas.

Other important assumptions were made by Dr Norman in relation to borrowing levels, overseas exposure, interest holidays, currency depreciation, productivity increases and added imports arising from higher Tasmanian gross domestic product. So a range of factors was taken into account in his assessment of the current account implications. In his view these assumptions were on the conservative side. But Dr Norman's analysis did not take into account factors raised in parts two and three of Senator Haines's question. It appears from Dr Norman's analysis that the mill will have a positive effect on trade throughout the 1990s. With regard to what proportion of profits will remain in Australia, that is certainly not something on which the Government could comment as we have no idea as to how and to whom profits will be distributed in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I asked specifically in the second part of my question whether there had been an independent economic analysis done. Is the Minister aware of who, if anybody, commissioned Dr Norman's analysis?
—No, I am not. I will get that answer for Senator Haines very quickly.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Minister aware of failures by some of the States to address issues which are posing significant impediments to the process of micro-economic reform? Could the Minister identify these issues and the causes of inaction by the States concerned?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have here a copy of an information paper put out by the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) on Government non-tax charges. Several pages of the report are devoted to the charging policies of the Governments of New South Wales and, much more particularly, of Queensland for the transport of coal to ports. It points out among other things that the excess freight charged on coal imposed in those two States is variable but for some companies in Queensland it is as high as 11 per cent of the f.o.b. price. This industry, of course, is critical to the nation's export performance. It has been fighting over many years to maintain its competitiveness. It is axiomatic, of course, that if some companies are being overcharged in freight to the extent of 11 per cent of the f.o.b. price in a tight and competitive international market they are finding it extremely hard to cope. I must say that I put on the record my amazement that a free market economist like Senator Stone is implicitly defending the rip-off that the Queensland Government has been practising for many years. The dead hands of the New South Wales and, much more particularly of course, the Queensland Governments on these industries has been exposed by the IAC.

ANSWER.PARA: MIM Holdings Ltd, which operates the Collinsville and Newland mines in Queensland, is one of the companies specifically reported upon. That company has shown that the real freight rate and export prices have been moving in opposite directions for the last 10 years. Caltex, which operates the Bayswater colliery in New South Wales, expressed concern about rail freights and also about regulations which restrict road haulage and thereby allow the rail authority to charge more than it would be able to do if it were subject to competition. Most spectacularly of all, probably, CRA, which transports coal from Blair Athol in Queensland to Dalrymple Bay, estimated that its excess freight bill was a massive $40m in 1985. For Queensland generally the IAC estimated that the excess freight rate for new mines was of the order of $7 a tonne. Those sorts of rorts have been going on for a long time. I would hope that Senator Stone, far from supporting them, which he appears to have been doing in the Senate, would use his influence with his National Party colleagues in Queensland-because the Queensland Government has been the main offender in this area-and get them to do something about it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice, both in his own capacity and as Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I remind the Minister of newspaper reports of threats and coercion being used against Aboriginal groups or persons opposing the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) proposal. I ask the Minister: Can he give the Senate an assurance that such action will not be tolerated by the Government? What action would the Government take if such behaviour were identified?

—I do not know the reports to which Senator Chaney is referring but in principle, of course, I can say quite categorically that this Government and, I believe, every member of the Senate would be dismayed to hear of threats of violence made against any person in relation to any matter of controversy within this community. After all, we are a pluralist democracy and one hopes that in the conduct of our affairs dealing with matters of great moment and of controversy we can do so in a non-violent manner.
—What about other than violence? One can threaten and intimidate without violence. What about monetary intimidation?

—I understand the distinction, but nevertheless I am pointing to a general cultural phenomenon. In our society we want these sorts of discussions and the resolution of major conflicts as to the course of this nation and the policies that might be pursued to be conducted in a way which does not unduly overwhelm those whom might oppose a particular point of view. If these unfortunate practices have in any way been put into effect by persons within our community, the Government condemns that to the extent that it lays within its power to do so.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I refer the Minister to a statutory declaration by Mr Merv Gibson, Chairman of Queensland's Aboriginal Co-ordinating Council (ACC), which alleges that on the same day Mr Gibson issued a press release opposing ATSIC and sent a facsimile message asking to meet Mr Hawke, he received a phone call from Mr John Gayler, the honourable for Leichhardt. The declaration states that Mr Gayler asked Mr Gibson what was happening because of his press release and said he would tell the Prime Minister not to meet him. According to the statutory declaration, Mr Gayler said, `We would have to reconsider our position on the funding of the Hopevale infrastructure project'. Mr Gibson also stated that Mr Gayler had left him in no doubt that his actions as ACC Chairman in not supporting ATSIC would see his community penalised by the cancellation of funds for infrastructure. I ask the Minister for Justice to examine the declaration and investigate the matters which are raised in it. Will the Minister take appropriate action on the matters raised, including ensuring that the Aboriginal residents of Hopevale are not penalised for their stand against ATSIC. I seek leave to table the statutory declaration.

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no knowledge of the truth or otherwise of the matters contained in the statutory declaration. I will refer the matter to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, as might be appropriate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to press reports on the submission of the Australian Conservation Foundation (ACF) and the National Farmers Federation (NFF) to his ministerial task force? What is the Government's response to those submissions? What is the Minister's reaction to the uniting of the ACF and the NFF in the commitment by this Government to soil conservation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the press reports. Phillip Toyne of the Australian Conservation Foundation and Rick Farley of the National Farmers Federation presented me with a copy of their submission prior to its public release at a press conference held yesterday afternoon at the headquarters of the National Farmers Federation. The ACF and the NFF were able to agree on the submission. My colleague the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, agrees with me that soil conservation is the foremost conservation issue in Australia at the moment. We congratulate the NFF and the ACF for collaborating on such a comprehensive proposal as the one on soil conservation which they have put forward. Many of the points contained in their submission are points to which I have referred on many occasions. Senator Richardson has also referred to them on many occasions in public speeches and comments on the problem. This Government, in particular, has placed a great deal of emphasis on encouraging community groups of landholders to join together and on a voluntary basis apply particular land care strategies to the area or catchment in which they live so that as landholders they are entrusted with maintaining their land in a proper condition, having regard to ecological or environmental concerns at the same time as keeping it productive. Thus, we welcome the submission that has been put forward. The NFF and the ACF costed their proposal and their submission contains a request for funding. That matter will be considered in the proper process of Budget deliberations in the Cabinet.

ANSWER.PARA: Might I say, in conclusion, that the issue of soil conservation is now achieving a great deal more coverage in the press. Today the Sydney Morning Herald had a very good article about the issue by Peter Fray and Bob Beale on page 1 and a feature spread on pages 8 and 9. They drew attention to the New South Wales Soil Conservation Service survey, which illustrated the extent and detail of the problem in New South Wales.

The West Australian yesterday carried a report headed `The seeds of revolution', referring to a green and brown revolution taking place in Western Australia and to the fact that trees in that State are being planted faster than they are being cut down in order to combat and reverse the problem of salinity in our soil.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are the relative sizes of the ones that are being planted and the ones that are being cut down?

—One does not actually plant them the same size as one cuts them down. The proposal in Western Australia is for 100 million trees to be planted by farmers between now and the end of the century, with the aim of covering areas of high salinity to reduce the salinity content and to make saline land come back into production. That 100 million tree planting is not to be confused with the Western Australian Government's tree trust proposal, which is to plant another 100 million trees in association with the timber industry for the purposes of plantation forestry on timber resources in Western Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The point I make is that this Government is sensitive to and recognises, applauds and encourages the efforts being made by volunteer organisations such as the ACF and the NFF to join together on this massive national problem. We are committed to working with them and with the States in resolving the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice, both in his own capacity and as Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Can the Minister confirm that the acting commissioners of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC), specially appointed by Mr Hand in 1988, sent a letter to the Auditor-General's Office accusing that office of racism, incompetence and unprofessional conduct? Has a meeting of the Board of Commissioners been held at which it was resolved to send such a letter to the Auditor-General? If so, will the Minister table a copy of the letter and indicate whether all commissioners and acting commissioners approved the dispatch of such a letter? Will the Minister ask his colleague the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to explain to the Parliament why those persons associated with the dispatch of such a letter remain in office as commissioners or acting commissioners? Finally, can the Minister for Justice inform the Senate under what Commonwealth Government guidelines or authority the ADC has retained a Queen's Counsel to act for it in relation to the Auditor-General's investigation and whether that person has associated himself with the ADC commissioners' attack on the Auditor-General's Office, implying racism, incompetence and unprofessional conduct?
—Mr President, I will take that question on notice.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Justice. Has the National Crime Authority (NCA) commenced operations in South Australia? What cooperation, if any, is the NCA receiving from the South Australian police?

—I am sure the Senate will be interested in the answer to this question because this chamber was very supportive of the change to legislation late last year to enable the particular appointment, as it turned out, of Mr Le Grande, as an additional member of the National Crime Authority to deal with the investigations pursuant to allegations that had been made about corruption and criminal activity in South Australia. In particular, the operations have commenced. In fact, I visited the Authority during January and spoke with Mr Le Grande, who took up his position on 1 January for an initial period of 12 months. I think senators in general would be pleased to know that the Authority has felt confident in obtaining the cooperation and the assistance of South Australian police in its investigations, which cover allegations of corruption within the force, and, of course, such a decision to involve South Australian police was taken after long and very careful consideration. There is no evidence that the vast majority of South Australian police are not honest and, indeed, if there is a corruption problem within the South Australian police, the Authority will need to rely on South Australian police of integrity, amongst others--
—Barry Moyse?

—It was the National Crime Authority which exposed Barry Moyse, as the honourable senator should know. I do not know what the honourable senator was trying to prove by that interjection. The fact is that on a practical level the support of the South Australian police is important, and indeed, the South Australian Police Commissioner, Mr David Hunt, and his deputy, Mr Pat Hurley, have had many discussions with Mr Le Grande, and he reports to me that the South Australian Police Force has indicated its full cooperation. That enthusiastic support from the South Australian Police Commissioner in particular will underpin much of the work to be undertaken by the Authority and I believe that it will be extremely successful.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Justice. I refer to evidence given by the Chairman of the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC), Mr Henry Bosch, to the Joint Select Committee on Securities Legislation. Is the Minister aware that when asked about the deal done by the NCSC in which it was agreed not to make public the fact that it had been investigating Rothwells Ltd prior to the 1987 rescue attempt of that organisation and to drop its inquiries--
—Is the Western Australian election over yet?
—Yes, the Western Australian election is over, so perhaps we can now get some truth about all this. Mr Bosch said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . We were at a late stage in an investigation of a market manipulation antic. The Western Australian Government drew our attention to the fact that it was carrying out a rescue which might run onto the rocks if our investigation went public at that time. So what we said was, `We are prepared to settle in the normal way. You give us what we want and we will not say anything publicly about it'. What we wanted was that Mr Connell step down as Chairman; Mr Lucas, who was then Managing Director would be dismissed; several other executives of the company would be dismissed; they would hand in their dealer's licence, which removed the need for us to withdraw it; they would put forward a new business plan and submit it to us for agreement; and a special audit of the accounts would be carried out.
I ask the Minister further whether he is aware that later in his evidence Mr Bosch said:

In this instance, you have got representations made to you by the Premier of a State government. It would be capricious of you to disregard those and I think, quite properly, you have got to take it into account and make a balancing judgment.

While noting that Mr Bosch denies the NCSC succumbed to political pressure on this case, I ask the Minister whether he considers it proper for the Western Australia Government to have made the approach it did. If that was not political pressure, what would constitute political pressure? Further, does the Minister agree that it was improper and grossly unfair to the investing public for the NCSC to agree to suspend inquiries into Rothwells and in not letting on that it had that company under investigation when the same body, the NCSC, now reveals that its renewed inquiries into Rothwells have produced what it calls `serious findings'?

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a very long preamble to that particular question, but the essence of it was that I am asked to agree that in fact political pressure was placed on the NCSC in relation to its Rothwells investigation. I repudiate that. Indeed, I believe that the NCSC has not been subjected to the sorts of political pressures which are conjured up in Senator Lewis's question. I believe that the report prepared by the NCSC is to be considered by the Ministerial Council at its meeting on 2 March, which is only a few days away. Apparently it raises serious issues, as the honourable senator has said, and I believe that that report ought to be fully considered by the Ministerial Council. Of course it is worth noting that the Ministerial Council is composed of Attorneys-General from all jurisdictions in Australia. I believe that they will be able to comprehend fully and deal with any untoward activity that occurred in the course of that investigation, if that proves to be the case, and is the subject of report by the NCSC. Until that Ministerial Council has fully considered the report I do not believe that I should pre-judge what might come out of the NCSC report to the Council.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am not asking the Minister to prejudge the decisions of the Ministerial Council. I asked the Minister whether he considered it was improper or perhaps even grossly unfair-I think those were the words I used-to the investing public for the NCSC not to let on that it had this company under investigation at that time.

—I believe that all the various inquiries and court actions that have taken place in relation to Rothwells have been complex; some of them overlapping and some of them interrelated. I believe that, at the end of the day, only in the light of the final report that is made available by the NCSC will we be able to judge whether those inquiries were conducted in the most proper manner.
—You just hope that it will all go away.

—Not at all. I believe that the Ministerial Council will come to some conclusions on 2 March in relation to this report which will satisfy much of the concern that has emanated, including concern from Opposition spokesmen, over the last few months.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Following representations from the honourable member for the Northern Territory and me, can the Minister advise the Senate as to what decision he has taken in respect of the levying of entry fees into Kakadu National Park? In particular, what decision has he taken in respect of the imposition of those fees on the residents of Jabiru?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Given that some $25m has been spent in Kakadu in the last decade and given that the number of visitors to Kakadu is increasing at an extraordinary rate, for some time the Government has been looking at the question of how funds for Kakadu might best be provided and the user pays principle was an obvious one for consideration. We cannot impose fees in parks such as Kakadu and Uluru without consultation, obviously, with the traditional owners, the Aboriginal people, and with the tourist industry. We have been talking about doing this since as long ago as April 1987.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. What are the Standing Orders governing the fact that the honourable senator who has asked the Minister a question has now left the chamber? He has not even bothered to wait for the Minister to give the answer to the question he has asked. Mr President, there must be some rule. Either he is sufficiently interested in the question actually to stay and listen to the answer, or the answer has been cooked up and he is now making sure that the press release goes out announcing the answer that he has already been given.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—Where is he? Is he so thin that we cannot see him?

—If he were in the chamber I think we would notice him; he is big enough. Those consultations to which I was referring took place over quite some time. It is true that both Senator Collins and the honourable member for the Northern Territory, Mr Snowdon, made a number of representations to me on this question. Since 1 August charges have been in place for permits issued for commercial filming and still photography at both Kakadu and Uluru.
