An adult entry fee of $3 for admission to the new audiovisual display at Kakadu headquarters was introduced on that date as well. An adult park use fee of $5 was introduced on 1 January this year. That entitles visitors to use the park facilities, remote area camping, ranger guided tours and so on. That is the first entry or park use fee ever at Kakadu. At Uluru it was a bit different because there has been a fee of $1.50 in place there for years and that was increased to $5 last October.

ANSWER.PARA: There were a few complaints from some of the operators. The commercial operators of buses are being charged an annual rate of $50 to conduct their tours. The only other difficulty that came about was for residents of Jabiru, the town in the middle of Kakadu. There was a period of a couple of weeks when residents of Jabiru were being charged each time they entered the park. This was creating some difficulties and I am pleased to announce that, as a result of representations I have received from both Senator Collins and Mr Snowdon, the residents of Jabiru have been exempted from those charges and are now charged only when they use park facilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade or his Department authorise, and if so on what basis, the Australian Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See to attend but not participate in the ultimate junket-a recent Western Australian Development Corporation-sponsored Pacrim conference in Hong Kong? Is it a fact that, despite only having taken up his `job for the boys' a mere six months ago, His Excellency has currently found it necessary to make a detour to his old stamping ground for the purpose of canvassing his Federal preselection prospects with a few cronies? Can the Minister inform the Senate on what official pretext Mr Burke managed to get back to the State of Excitement and at whose expense? While Mr Burke is in Australia, will the Government take the opportunity to invite him to give evidence before the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) inquiry into the Rothwells Ltd rescue debacle, which he masterminded? Alternatively, will the Government ensure that Mr Burke is available to assist the NCSC in its inquiries, should his testimony be considered to be of sufficient reliability?

—I am of course aware of Mr Burke's attendance at the Pacrim 88 conference which was held in Hong Kong from 19 to 22 February. Mr Burke, who was very closely involved with the successful Pacrim 86 conference in Perth, was invited by the organisers of Pacrim 88 to chair a session of the conference. It was agreed that he could attend provided he took recreation leave for the entire period of his absence from his post in Dublin. No cost whatever associated with Mr Burke's travel and accommodation has been met by the Commonwealth Government. As to the latter part of Senator Alston's question, relating to--
—What about his accommodation back in Western Australia?

—No part of any of that has been met by us either, as I understand it. That seems to me to be subsumed within the answer. I will check it and make absolutely sure, but it is entirely consistent with what I have said-that this was recreation leave which involved no travel costs for the Commonwealth. As to the rest of the question relating to Rothwells Ltd and WA Inc. and so on, I simply suggest that Senator Alston, in the aftermath of the Western Australian election, has a strong but understandable case of sour grapes.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister suggesting by that answer that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade-or indeed, the Minister himself-takes the view that when a serving diplomat wishes to attend a conference that has absolutely no relation to his current responsibility, he is entitled as a matter of course to take recreation leave?
—What a stupid question!

—It is a stupid question and I will explain why. Mr Burke was invited to attend in his personal capacity, because of the outstanding contribution he had made to Pacrim 86 and because of the obvious continuity of issues involved-trade and investment issues are of world-wide consequence for the Australian Government. There was absolutely no reason why he should not have participated in that conference, particularly on the basis I have indicated, where it was entirely within the scope of his recreation leave.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training to the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Education of Gifted and Talented Children which was published some 12 months ago. Does the Government agree with the Committee's nine recommendations? If not why not? Can the Minister indicate how many of the Committee's nine recommendations have been implemented to date? Specifically, has any action been taken on recommendation 6 of this report which states that a national centre for research into the education of gifted children be established in an Australian tertiary institution and that this centre be financially supported during its establishment phase by the Commonwealth Government? Will the Government make a final decision on implementation of any recommendations upon which decisions have not already been taken?

—I have been asked whether I am familiar with the recommendations of the report of a Senate select committee on education and the action taken pursuant to those recommendations. I did not even know about the report because, in my job, I believe that I have more important things to do than read Senate reports. I will get an answer to Senator Macklin's question from Mr Dawkins.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to the recent comments by a former President of the New South Wales Labor Council and former Australian Labor Party member of the New South Wales Parliament, Mr Joe Thompson, when he said, `We are now on the verge of a major national wage blow-out, the effects of which will ultimately be felt by the whole community and cause further damage to our fragile economy'. Does the Minister endorse these comments by a former leading trade union official? Given that the major wages blow-out is a very real prospect, does the Minister agree with the recent comments made by the Treasurer that if there is an unacceptable wage-tax proposal on the part of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) the Government would go to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and argue `that any wage rise must be on a company by company basis'? Further, does the Minister think that a 20 per cent wage rise and a 30 per cent tax cut would be economically responsible in the current circumstances or, indeed, in circumstances where Australia suffered further disastrous balance of payments and inflation results such as those that we have had over the last couple of months?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of parts to that question. Ever since I have been here I have had the now retired leading trade union official of New South Wales quoted in various questions in this chamber and I have developed a sort of familiarity with him at Question Time. He used to be an expert on the motor vehicle industry.
—Do you agree with him or not?
—I am coming to that, if the honourable senator can wait with bated breath. First of all, I do not agree with Mr Thompson in saying that we are on the verge of a national wage blow-out.
—Not on the verge. It is in place already.

—If a Liberal government were in power, like the Government that was here when Senator Stone was Secretary to the Treasury, we would have a wage blow-out like those of 14 per cent and 16 per cent which occurred in 1981 and 1982 respectively, as I recall it. Mr Thompson's experience very much related to that period. I can understand his saying that because that is the sort of thing that happened under Liberal governments. In terms of the present Government, the Budget predictions in respect of wages and the predictions which have been made by the Treasurer and others in respect of wages since, have been between a 6.5 per cent and a 6.75 per cent increase in average weekly earnings over the year. If we compare that with the sort of performance in Senator Stone's day when Mr Howard was presiding over the Treasury, it is a pretty satisfactory increase. Senator Messner quoted from the alleged comments of the Treasurer about the level of success in negotiations with the ACTU which are still to take place and I accept what he has said. I also accept the Treasurer's view. If an agreed negotiated position cannot be arrived at that produces a result that is a reasonable expectation in the light of past wage restraint, the Treasurer is undoubtedly stating a course which he assumes it would be appropriate to take at that time.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Messner asked me in the last part of his question whether a 20 per cent wage rise and a 30 per cent tax cut were sustainable. I do not think a 20 per cent wage rise or a 30 per cent tax cut would be sustainable. I think the honourable senator got his question mixed up and, as a matter of fact, misread it. I think he probably means a $20 wage rise and a $30 tax cut.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have just got it mixed up too.
—No, I have not; I am quite clear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented. In the House of Representatives on 21 December 1988, which was the last day of sitting of both chambers, in a debate on the suspension of Standing Orders the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) made a speech in which he made a number of references to me and, indeed, made a personal attack on me that was inaccurate in a number of particulars, two of which I would like to deal with today. Firstly, Mr Hand said:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney comes to my office and sits there for nearly 2 1/2 hours, congratulates me on certain things that I have carried out that day, and the very next day goes into the Parliament and buckets people that he has told me are doing a great job in their particular functions . . .

That followed a suggestion that I am a Jekyll and Hyde on Aboriginal affairs and was a rather amusing misstatement, given that I have now had three meetings with Mr Hand at which I have made abundantly clear to him the extent of my concern about his administration of Aboriginal affairs. The meeting to which he referred was one of those three meetings and occurred on the day of his appointment of Mr Bill Gray as Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. That was an appointment which I welcomed. I tried to telephone Mr Gray to congratulate him at 11 p.m. but he was not at home. I divined, correctly, that he would be in his Minister's office. I rang the Minister's office and asked whether I could go and see them. I went to the office and congratulated Mr Hand on one thing and one thing only, namely, his appointment of Mr Bill Gray. I did that in Mr Gray's presence and I congratulated Mr Gray.

The Minister said that we then sat there for nearly 2 1/2 hours, which is longer than I recall, but it was certainly a lengthy discussion. I went through in great detail my concerns about his administration of the portfolio. There is absolutely no truth in the suggestion that I congratulated him on anything other than that single item. I did not proceed, on the next day or at any other time, to drop a bucket or do anything else about Mr Gray, whom I regard as an outstanding public servant and a very good appointment. I say simply that the Minister's statement was incorrect.

I should also add that the Minister was, I think, somewhat taken aback, or certainly affected, by one of my conversations with him which occurred outside the Senate committee rooms when again I detailed my depth of concern about his portfolio. He then arranged for Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) commissioners to call on me to brief me and offered me a briefing from the Secretary to the Department. In light of his suggestion that I have behaved inconsistently, I should say that on the morning Mr Gray came to my office at 8.30 to give me a briefing which had been arranged by the Minister, I had the night before determined to raise a matter of privilege in the Parliament which affected an official of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. Therefore, I asked Mr Gray not to carry on with the briefing, to return to his Minister's office and advise him of the reason for the cancellation of the briefing. I mention that because, again, it simply underlines that I have attempted to behave in an entirely proper way with respect to my dealings with officials in that Department.

Secondly, in the same speech Mr Hand said that I had walked into the Adelaide Airport and had `publicly abused' an Aboriginal woman because she was on the Aboriginal Development Commission. I spoke with a female commissioner of the ADC at Adelaide Airport. I deny that I abused her. The commissioner concerned has been known to me since 1979, when I first became Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, and there is no person for whom I have higher regard. I regard her as a friend. When I met her in the lounge at Adelaide Airport I spoke with her about what had happened in the ADC with the sacking and replacement of commissioners. I spoke to her, as I have spoken to some others, including members of this chamber, forcefully and with some passion because of my deep concern for what I think is the mess this Government is making in this area. I have spoken with the commissioner since. She told me that I did not abuse her and that she has not said that I abused her. She said to me that she was surprised by the vehemence on the subject. She recalled, and asked me to mention, her contribution to the conversation as being her concerns about the position of Charles Perkins and his being treated fairly.

After a time that particular conversation with the commissioner was broken off by me. I then introduced her to another transit passenger from Perth. The three of us sat and talked until my plane was called. I have spoken with the third person in that conversation, who recalls it as a friendly conversation which concluded with the commissioner sending her love to my wife. I make no apology for the strength of view I have expressed in this chamber and elsewhere about Labor's administration of Aboriginal affairs. I must say that it is no stronger than the expressions of concern I have heard from both Labor members of this Parliament and Labor supporters elsewhere, many of whom have expressed equally deep concerns about maladministration of Aboriginal affairs under the Hawke Labor Government.

Finally, I should say that reports I have had of increasingly personal attacks by this Minister on me and other critics of his policies and administration-and I stress `critics of his policies and administration'-attacks made, among others, on public servants who have served with me and, indeed, with other people who have been criticised in similar terms by the Minister, suggest an increasingly desperate Minister with whom sensible communication would appear impossible without serious risk of misrepresentation and, to use the Minister's term, `personal abuse'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented. Today Senator Crowley gave notice of a motion in which she said that I had made remarks in Tasmania on 2 February--

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. This matter is now on the Notice Paper. When it comes on Senator Hill will have an opportunity to speak. It is not a matter for personal explanation, surely. We will get dozens of them if we accept this proposition.
—It is not on the Notice Paper. Senator Button should learn the Standing Orders.
—If Opposition members enshrine that as a principle here, they had better look out.
—Order! Senator Hill was given leave to make a personal explanation.

—Today Senator Crowley gave notice of a motion in which she said that I had remarked in Tasmania that domestic violence was a `soft issue' for women. I did not make any such remark in Tasmania. No doubt Senator Crowley was referring to an article which appeared in the Tasmanian Mercury, presumably supplied to her by the National Media Liaison Service. Therefore, I also presume that Senator Crowley would have been supplied with a subsequent letter I wrote to that newspaper referring to the article it had written and some correspondence that had appeared in its letter columns. In that letter I said to the newspaper:

SPEECH.PARA: I want to settle a misunderstanding which is being perpetuated through your letter column.

I do not regard domestic violence as a soft issue and have never said that I do. I regard domestic violence as an appalling indictment on society and support efforts to isolate and remedy the causes and to support those abused.
What I have said is that the Federal Government has determined its key priorities in the area of Status of Women to be the role of women in advertising and domestic violence.

I said that the highest priority of most women's organizations speaking to the Opposition has been economic security and the related challenges of affordable housing, child care, education and re-education and worthwhile employment opportunities. Additionally women have called for a reversal of the trend under Labor of less support for families.
It might be that in at least some cases, declining family support and economic stress is related to domestic violence.

I thank the Senate for the opportunity of clarifying that matter. I regret that Senator Crowley did not even do me the courtesy of saying that it was reported that I had made such a statement but simply made the assertion, which is untrue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a brief statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
I ask Hansard to note that in the final part of the question I asked Senator Button earlier, when I referred to 20 per cent and 30 per cent, I meant in each case dollars.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate will recall that on 1 November 1988 I made a statement and presented to the Senate certain documents relating to the meetings of the Public Accounts Committee during sittings of the Senate. I now present to the Senate further opinions which have been received from the Attorney-General's Department in relation to that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Is it not the usual practice as a matter of courtesy to advise the Chairman or Deputy Chairman representing the Committee in this place as to the tabling of opinions before they are tabled in the Parliament?
—I believe that the documents I have just tabled were sent to the Chairman and the Secretary of the Committee before they were tabled here today.

—At the request of the President of the House of Representatives of the Republic of Cyprus, I present to the Senate a copy of a resolution of that House of 10 December 1988 relating to the implementation of United Nations resolutions relating to Cyprus.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the publication Business of the Senate for the period 1 January to 31 December 1988.

INTERJECT.PARA: Ordered that the paper be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate will recall that on 15, 16 and 20 December 1988 I presented to the Senate documents relating to the validity of a resolution of disallowance passed by the Senate on 1 May 1986 in respect of certain export control orders. I now present to the Senate the reasons for judgment of Mr Justice Woodward of the Federal Court of Australia in Thomas Borthwick & Sons (Pacific) Ltd v. John Charles Kerin and others, given on 23 December 1988 which relate to that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish to say briefly that I very much welcome the document that you have tabled, Mr President, and the judgment which was given by Mr Justice Woodward. Honourable senators will recall that some doubts were cast in an opinion, an opinion which many of us found extremely unconvincing, as to the capacity of the Senate to disallow certain parts of an order. The judgment of Mr Justice Woodward vindicates our doubts and concerns.

It is important to remember that the extraordinary and quite improper conduct of the Minister at the time, Senator Cook, was not in a sense dependent on that legal opinion of the Attorney-General's Department. That opinion permitted Senator Cook, or appeared to permit him, to do what he did, but no sensible Minister, concerned for the national interest, would have done what Senator Cook did. This is not the time for full debate on the implication of the judgment, but I believe that we should have a debate, perhaps early next week. Therefore, I give the Government notice that if it does not list the matter for hearing, I shall seek the cooperation of the Australian Democrats to have the matter brought on for debate. I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I do not take Senator Chaney to task on this matter but, as I understand it, the judgment on 23 December 1988 was very much an interlocutory proceeding and the final judgment has not yet been given. It seems to me that this chamber should wait until His Honour brings down the final judgment. I understand, subject to correction, that the application to have that matter put over from December to February was an application made by Thomas Borthwick and Sons (Pacific) Ltd and an order was made to put the matter over to that time. That occurred despite objections by those who wanted the matter to proceed then. The matter is still in a state of uncertainty, and it seems to be premature now to criticise the Minister, particularly as the matter is likely to be debated later. It seems to me that in any event the Minister has acted properly in the light of the advice he had received. I want to correct any impression that Senator Chaney may have given-unintentional, I would have thought-that a final decision had been reached on this matter and that the decision of the court had gone against what the Minister decided on that occasion.

—The Senate will recall that on 1 November 1988 I presented to the Senate correspondence with Mr Justice Staples, the Deputy President of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I now present a copy of a letter from him dated 6 February 1989 and my response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

Although this is a matter of increased public interest, the Opposition does not intend to debate the issue now, but at a later time this day, after we have dealt with Senate Committee reports, we shall seek to bring on for consideration motions of which notice was given this morning by the Opposition, through Senator Hill, and by the Australian Democrats, through Senator Haines. I am not sure whether the Whips have had a chance to discuss the matter, but before seeking leave to move this motion I checked with the Australian Democrats and understand from Senator Macklin that they were content, as are we, not to debate this issue at this point in the Senate's proceedings. On that basis I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the fourteenth report of the Committee of Privileges entitled Possible False or Misleading Evidence and Manipulation of Evidence before Senate Committees.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
On 8 November 1988 the Senate referred the following matters to the Committee:

(a) whether false or misleading evidence was given to Estimates Committee E in relation to the attendance in Canberra on 1 and 2 September 1988 of Mr R. Robinson, Mr D. McCarthy and Mr N. Johnson; and

(b) whether, in relation to the appearance of those persons before the Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, there was an attempt to manipulate the evidence laid before the Select Committee,
and whether a contempt of the Senate was committed in respect of those matters.

The Committee, having received and considered submissions from Messrs Robinson, Johnson, McCarthy and Perkins, and having received information from Senator Coulter and the Secretary of the Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, has found no evidence that Messrs Robinson, Johnson and McCarthy came to Canberra for purposes other than those stated in evidence given before Estimates Committee E. The Committee has therefore concluded that, on the evidence available to it, no contempt of the Senate has been committed. Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON AGRICULTURAL AND VETERINARY CHEMICALS IN AUSTRALIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to order, I present a progress report of the Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to make a statement in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will recall that on 1 November last year the Senate established a Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals to inquire into and report upon the following matters:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) the adequacy of arrangements under the legislation relating to agricultural and veterinary chemicals for administration and co-ordination systems for agricultural and veterinary chemicals;
(b) the efficacy of chemical, non-chemical and integrated management systems; and
(c) the economic, social and environmental impact on Australia of agricultural and veterinary chemicals and their alternatives.

The Committee also may consider and recommend amendments to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act 1988. The Committee's terms of reference require it to present a progress report on the first sitting day in 1989 and a final report on the last sitting day in 1989. The progress report that I have just tabled on behalf of the Select Committee addresses the conduct of the inquiry, committee activities in relation to the reference and the Committee's program of public hearings and inspections. The report also notes some of the issues raised in the submissions already received.

I will not take up the time of the Senate by reviewing all these topics. There are, however, three matters contained in the report on which I wish to elaborate. Firstly, the Committee decided that submissions to the inquiry should be lodged as soon as possible but by 31 March 1989. Given the broad and complex issues contained in the terms of reference, this period for the preparation of submissions has been welcomed by several organisations and individuals. Even with this closing date for submissions, the Committee has adopted a program that should enable it to present its final report by the end of this year. Secondly, when the establishment of the Select Committee was debated in this chamber late last year, several organisations registered their opposition to such an inquiry. The Committee is pleased to record that it has been assured of the full cooperation of major interested parties. Thirdly, the Committee recognises that the important issues raised in the terms of reference have been the subject of considerable debate in the community and that it is important for an inquiry of this kind to receive as many points of view as possible. The Committee encourages all those wishing to express a view on the reference to lodge a submission with the Committee by 31 March 1989.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON THE ADMINISTRATION OF ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

In speaking to the motion I would like to address the essential principles which underlined our task and, in so doing, to restate the terms of reference in a way which I think outlines the essential questions we had to address and our response to them. Firstly, we had before us the question, `Was or is the concept of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) one that should be supported?'. I refer in particular to three aspects of that concept: firstly, the administrative consolidation envisaged within it; secondly, the establishment of a representative national structure; and, thirdly, a representative regional structure-those structures being designed to advise and recommend priorities to the Minister. The majority report's answer to that important question is yes.

Secondly, we were asked to consider whether there were clauses in the proposed Bill seeking to implement this concept which should be amended. The answer to that question is also yes. Thirdly, we were asked to consider whether the amendments as proposed were such as to require the Bill to be scrapped. The majority report's answer to that question is clearly no. If the Government's response to the report were to be a proposal for further consultations based upon the amendments proposed by the Committee, I certainly would not have any difficulty with it. It is in no way inconsistent with the thrust of the Committee's report.

Fourthly, we were asked to consider whether the proposed alternative strategy of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) was preferable to the Government's proposal. The majority report, which I support, concluded that it was not. There were two subsidiary and less important questions. I do not regard them as unimportant, but they are less important. We were asked to consider whether the consultation leading up to the Bill was sufficient, and our conclusion can be summarised as follows: it was the best ever, it could have been better, but nothing in the consultation process to date necessitates further delay in dealing with the Bill.

Finally, we were asked to consider the Government's treatment of the ADC and, in particular, of the dismissed ADC commissioners. I think I can best summarise the majority report's conclusions by saying that the Minister had to act as he did but that nothing in that action or in the Committee's considerations and conclusions should derogate from the good faith in which the dismissed commissioners acted.

The relative priority given to each of the questions is determined by whether one prefers to look forwards or backwards, whether one is seeking, in presenting and discussing this report, to make a constructive contribution or to conduct some sort of retrospective witch-hunt. I note that there are minority dissenting reports. That is not surprising in such a controversial and complex area. I will refer briefly to them subsequently.

However, having put those broad principles on the table, and notwithstanding the minority and dissenting reports, I take this opportunity to thank my colleagues for their cooperation and courtesy and the diligence with which they undertook this onerous task which the Senate imposed upon us. In particular, I thank them for their cooperation with me in my first experience of chairing such a select committee; I appreciated their cooperation. There were some very contentious matters before us. In fact an issue of some controversy was involved. From time to time, some honourable senators might be surprised to know, even a little publicity was generated. The way in which the inquiry was handled by my colleagues did credit to the Senate. I take this opportunity, rather than at the conclusion of the report, to thank the Committee staff, Hansard officers and others for facilitating that smooth handling of the matter. I thank them and I thank my colleagues.

I now turn to detailed consideration of the recommendations. There are too many recommendations for me to give detailed consideration and response to all of them at this stage. I will try to highlight those that are the central ones, that is, those that go to the principal matters before us. For the consideration of other minor but, in some instances, still important recommendations, I recommend to senators and members of the interested public that they examine the report at their leisure.

The first matter is the general question of the case for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. It is very difficult in a few moments to summarise the evidence presented in a large number of public hearings, through a large amount of reading and in the many written submissions. But I thought in a sense this aspect was well set out in a document presented to the Committee which was incorporated in the report at page 17. It says:

This scheme presents a challenge to the leadership of the Aboriginal community-to the extent they provide governments with professional, objective advice, they will (i) obtain access to information not otherwise available (and certainly not available to lobby groups) and (ii) obtain the opportunity to influence from inside the public sector the development of Government policy as it affects Aboriginal people.

That is a very important statement. It is essentially a statement of the philosophical underpinning which supports the Commission. I shall refer to it later because I believe it is a challenge which I am confident the Aboriginal people, if given the opportunity, will meet.

There is also an important factor in the support for the concept of ATSIC which goes beyond that national aspect outlined and summarised in that challenge in the role of the proposed regional councils. This area is significantly misunderstood but is a very important aspect of ATSIC. If I had to determine one part of the proposal which I thought was most important, I would refer to the regional council. In the report, we concluded:
These councils will have responsibility for the development of a regional plan and-
I am quoting from the Bill-
for improving the economic, social and cultural status of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander residents of the region.

The regional councils will also make the proposals to the Commission for expenditure under certain restrictions in each region. In addition, the councils have a general representative and advisory function. Those two elements together are the philosophical underpinnings of ATSIC. They are the reason why the proposal should proceed, provided-I will come to this subsequently-there is a Bill which adequately reflects those principles.

The third aspect of ATSIC which I referred to in my opening remarks related to the consolidation. Although not every aspect of the proposed consolidation as stated in the Bill at the moment is supported in the majority report, the concept is certainly supported and is worthy of support for reasons of administrative efficiency. More importantly, it is consistent with the challenge outlined in the quotation which I earlier referred to concerning the broad role of the Commission at the national level. For those reasons, the majority of the Committee has supported the ATSIC concept and is continuing to do so.

I would like to go on now to consider some of the recommendations for modification of the Bill which is designed to implement the ATSIC principle. I will firstly refer-I will do it as closely as possible to the sequence in the report to assist those who might be trying to read the report-to the recommendation in clause 2.22 at page 17 of the report which recommends that a separate office of Aboriginal Affairs be retained within the Department of Employment, Education and Training. It states:

The precise structure of the office is a matter to be determined by the Government of the day. The office would be responsible for advising the Minister on all matters relevant to the portfolio, including the administration of legislation and the exercise of delegations for which he or she was responsible.

The significance of this is that there have been assertions and allegations that somehow there is inherent in ATSIC an irredeemable flaw in that the same people have both a responsibility to a constituency which elects them and administrative accountability to the Government and the Minister as well as a role to advise on legislation. The argument is that these functions are incompatible. It is made clear elsewhere in the report, and it is obvious as a fundamental question of Westminster accountability, that there is nothing which prevents a Minister doing what is proposed in this recommendation at the moment. The legislation certainly, although it is silent on it, in no way prevents the Minister from establishing some separate advisory structure within the Department to which he or she is responsible. Nevertheless, the Committee thought that, to allay those fears and to make the situation clearer, we should make an explicit recommendation that such an office should be established so that no such conflict either exists or can be seen to exist.

At page 20, the Committee recommends that a greater proportion of the current activities of the ADC should be the responsibility of the proposed Aboriginal Economic Development Corporation (AEDC) as set out in the Bill, that is, a greater proportion than is envisaged in the Bill. This is important in two ways, but principally because we think it gets the balance of responsibilities right. The more appropriate division which we recommend would involve the abolition of the ADC as proposed in the Bill, the transfer of all its housing functions to ATSIC. But the responsibility for enterprise development, enterprise support, land acquisition and investment functions currently proposed for ATSIC in the Bill should be transferred to the AEDC.

That is an important reorientation. It does not change the fundamental supporting structures of the Commission because the interrelationship between ATSIC and the AEDC would continue. It does separate the economic development functions in a way that, I think, is appropriate. It is more appropriate than what was proposed. On consideration, the Government should, looking at that report, make such an amendment. I also believe that making such a change will make the role of the Commissioners more workable because, although some of them will be on the Board of the AEDC, they will have the capacity there to get extra economic advice from other Commissioners of the AEDC and not all of the ATSIC commissioners will be involved in all the economic decisions.

With regard to the Institute of Aboriginal Studies, which is also proposed to be part of the consolidation, the Committee in fact recommends that the Institute retain its own legislation and continue to deal with other Aboriginal Affairs portfolio agencies as it has in the past. In effect, we are accepting the submission from the Institute. Importantly, and consistent with the submission from the Institute, the proposed reforms in the Bill which would have changed the relationship between what is now to be proposed to be ATSIC and the Institute should be implemented by amendment of the Institute for Aboriginal Studies Act. The restructuring of the Council of the Institute to include three commissioners of ATSIC should also be supported. The links that are proposed between ATSIC and the proposed Institute should be retained but we do think that the separateness that is involved in a separate piece of legislation should be retained and sustained.

The other recommendations that we have made to which I wish to refer go to other but important matters. With regard to questions of accountability there are a number of faces. At the moment, I am talking about the question of the proper dealing with public finances and proper accountability. There have been accusations that the ADC and other Aboriginal bodies responsible for dispersing public funds-not just recently but over a series of years-may have approved substantial expenditures, whether grants, loans or guarantees, without the necessary documentation and without the sort of rigorous analysis that would normally be supplied. Without commenting on past decisions because, to some extent, they are outside our brief, the Committee recommends that boards such as those of ATSIC and AEDC should not be able to approve substantial expenditures without a written assessment of proposals, including reports on viability, costings and alternatives. That would require a couple of minor amendments to the Bill, but I think they are important. They are important in substance; they are important in principle.

I turn now to the proposals for the implementation of ATSIC in terms of how it would be elected, how the people, particularly and initially at the national level, would be selected. First, we are not talking about an Aboriginal parliament or a black parliament. The attempts to use those sorts of phrases, those colourful, rhetorical flourishes, do proper consideration of this matter no good. They mislead; they are intended to mislead; and they are grossly mistaken. As the majority report says, the Commission is not a parliament. It is very important that that be said from the start. It must be reiterated, because mischievous people could--

TALK.START.PARA: —What does the minority report say?

—To the extent that it says that it is a parliament, it is mischievous and misleading also, because none of the trappings of a parliament are there. We have yet to deal with questions of electoral systems, but we have electoral systems for trade unions; that does not make them parliaments. We have electoral systems specified in--
—They are not given access to $800m of public money either.

—Neither is this body given access to that money. Somebody is accountable to the Parliament for that money and that is as it should be. It is taxpayers' money; the expenditure of it should be approved by the Parliament and accountability should be to the Parliament through the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. The Committee quite properly recommends that that should continue to be the case, so people who do not understand the Bill should not try to put about such furphies. The report states quite clearly the principle that the Commission is not to be considered a parliament. Neither do we want those who might be elected to it or those who might be dealing with it to be under any misapprehension. At the national level, Aboriginal and Islander people are, like all other Australian citizens, represented in this Parliament, to which democratic requirements apply and to which ATSIC is properly accountable; this is the parliamentary accountability that ATSIC has. The Commissioners are elected as representatives of the Aboriginal people to make a very important input into that decision making process, but they are not the final decision makers nor, for so long as the funds are taxpayers' funds, can they be, and that principle is stated.

SPEECH.PARA: However, it raises the important question of the electoral system. In the time I have, I can refer to only one of the many aspects of the system. I refer to the variation in voting populations within zones. There are a number of subsidiary questions to do with that concerning the establishment of electoral rolls which I hope to have time to deal with. First, although it is not a parliament in the strict one vote one value principle that I know everybody in the Opposition is so--

TALK.START.PARA: —You just said it was not a parliament; and now you are saying it is a parliament.

—No, I am not. I said `although it is not a parliament'. I am sorry that I cannot speak any more slowly for Senator Boswell. The fact is that it is not a parliament. Although it is not a parliament, we should seek to represent the fairest democratic structures we can, consistent with the underlying principles of the Bill. Therefore, we make a series of recommendations suggesting the ways in which zone boundaries and representation might be changed to reduce the significant disparities that are in the Bill as proposed. They do not go as far as one vote one value. I know that will offend all members of the Opposition who are so sorely committed to that principle! But they do go substantially in that direction.
—What do you think of that?

—I know that Senator Stone at his leisure will read this report to see exactly what I think. My view is stated clearly in the report. The recommendations strike the appropriate balance and I happily support them, as I did in the Committee. There will never by any circumstance in which any parliament in Australia will have my support for unrepresentative structures. I hope that that will continue to be the case on this side. I would be delighted on the day on which it becomes so on the other side.
—As in Western Australia.

—I support absolutely one vote one value. If the silly Party of the honourable senator had done so, we would be much better off at the moment, as would his Party. A regular review of boundaries is proposed. A panel, including representatives of the Electoral Commission and ATSIC, would undertake that review so that the Aboriginality questions would be dealt with by the elected representatives and the fair electoral boundary aspects would be dealt with by the people recognised by all Australians as the arbiters of such matters-members of the Australian Electoral Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: More complex questions are involved with respect to the setting of the boundaries of the regions. They include historical, cultural, linguistic and other important factors that were raised in discussions with the Minister and with us in the course of our consultations. It is important that an immediate review be undertaken before the first election and that some changes be made, but those changes do not need to be very major. A number of people have made written or oral submissions to us or to the task force. Their views ought to be taken into account and appropriate modifications made. It is important that subsequent regular reviews be undertaken both by the panel and, where appropriate, ATSIC, and recommendations to that effect are made in the report.

There is a disparity in populations within the regions. That does not matter with regard to most of the functions of the regional councils. It does not matter that there are different populations in each zone for the purpose of their drawing up regional plans, but it matters for their function as the electoral college for the electoral zone commissioners. Therefore, at page 40 we recommend certain modifications to the representative scale to accommodate those variations and make the electoral colleges more equally representative.

Another key aspect of the electoral process to which I make brief reference is that of compulsory voting. It is a very finely balanced argument as to whether in this matter of elections to ATSIC we should have the standard Australian principle of compulsory voting. In the end, the majority in that debate came down in favour of the introduction of compulsory voting for elections for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, essentially because of the fairly complex argument with respect to a series of points. I refer honourable senators to the report for the detail, but essentially Australians are accustomed to that manner of conducting elections. The argument was so finely balanced that it was felt that the normal electoral process ought to be continued and sustained. I support that.

We also recommend that there ought to be options for local communities at the regional level to determine alternative methods of selecting their representatives. It was clear from evidence given to us and from the report previously given by Lois O'Donoghue on the possible national structure that there is a strong view among Aboriginal people that electing representatives in accordance with Western parliamentary traditions is not always the most appropriate way of choosing Aboriginal representatives and that they ought to be given the opportunity locally to determine processes and procedures. My colleague Senator Collins has a strong view about that, as do others, but it was neither possible nor appropriate for the Committee to start recommending what that process ought to be. That would contradict the principle that underpins it. We recommend that regions should be able to recommend a preferred method of selecting councillors, subject to final approval by the Minister so that there is some benchmark to check that they are fair and reasonable proposals and that they ought to be able, therefore, to vary their representatives through that process. I reiterate that nothing in the recommendation would permit a regional council to change the system so that they get more representatives voting for a zone commissioner, but they can choose in their own way if that is possible. However, the first election should be conducted under the electoral system currently proposed in the ATSIC Bill.

I want to refer to some other amendments. I have to skip over many of them because of the time constraints. I refer first to the very important question of the preamble. More mischief has been spoken about the preamble than about anything else. The Committee concluded-my assessment of the discussion and my recollection of it is confirmed by a brief reading of the minority report-that it was the unanimous view of its members that the legal position, as set out in this preamble, is quite clear. The Acts Interpretation Act, combined with the Minister's statement in his second reading speech, ensures the legal neutrality of the preamble to the ATSIC Bill. It does not have any of the potential legal consequences that some people wish it had and that many other people try to whip up a frenzy of concern that it might have.

Nevertheless, to ensure that as little mischief as possible is engaged in by those who sometimes seek to whip up concern in these matters, the Committee has recommended not that the preamble be changed with regard to one word but that the preamble, as it is currently proposed, should be put to the Parliament as a separate and simultaneous resolution of the Parliament. That is, at the same time that the ATSIC Bill is being considered, we should have a resolution of the Parliament expressed in the clear terms of the currently proposed preamble. I think that is important. It does not change the legal effect of the preamble one bit, but if it makes people happier and achieves the same purpose then I have no difficulty with that.

One other matter I wish to deal with, before I come to some of the questions of implementation and the supplementary issues before us in the time available, relates to the taxation of the Aboriginal Economic Development Corporation (AEDC). It is proposed in the current legislation that the capital fund of the AEDC and income derived from it should become subject to taxation and the payment of dividends. That is not the case for that money now within the AEDC and I think it is the unanimous view, but certainly the majority view, of the Committee that it should not be the case under the AEDC. The principle should be that there is no detriment to the interests of Aboriginal people arising from any aspect of the ATSIC Bill and that they therefore should not lose that which they currently have. It is therefore proposed that the status quo be retained.

The concept of the Bill is one that is capable of phased implementation. If the Government were of the view to do that, the three aspects to which I referred initially would be quite severable: we could have a regional council without establishing the national body; we could have a national body without electing, continuing and operating regional councils; and the administrative consolidation could proceed irrespective of the election of commissioners. That is a matter which we commend for the consideration of the Parliament and of the Government, but it is not something which we recommend. The Committee is recommending that the Bill should proceed.

I wish to refer very briefly to the consultative process. Put in perspective, it is quite clearly the best ever consultative process in Aboriginal affairs and far better than has ever been conducted with affected groups on any other matter, such as industrial relations. I reiterate that there is nothing in the consultative process to date which necessitates further delay. There are some allegations in the minority report concerning the consultative process which, to put them at their best, are merely salacious. Those who signed the minority report list all the most outrageous allegations that came before us-most of them in camera, I might say, with nothing to back them up. They say, `Here they all are. They are very important. Let us drag them through the mud. Maybe we will get a headline. We do not actually have anything to support them but they are very serious indeed'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you suggesting that people who gave evidence in camera are liars? Are you suggesting that? What a shocking statements.

—It is a great pity that Senator Boswell can neither hear nor read. The report says that we think they believe them to be true, but none of them came forward with first-hand evidence. They came forward with allegations that what they had heard had happened to other people. Senator Boswell knows that is true. He is deliberately misleading. He had that information while the Committee was meeting and chose not to bring it forward. Do not blame us. The honourable senator hid it, not me. The fact is that there is nothing to reflect upon the integrity of that process in anything that came before us. I deeply regret that, quite contrary to the spirit of the whole conduct of the Committee, these conclusions have been reached. I read the minority report and was stunned. I thought the two people concerned had been in a different committee from the rest of us, because nothing in the material we received or in the conduct of the discussions we had, whether in public or in private, supported those salacious and outrageous conclusions.
—Did you say `salacious'?
—Yes, that is right. They are drooling over them.
—I would not have thought that was an appropriate description.
—Enjoy it. I actually said it twice. Senator Stone missed it the first time.
—I thought you said `phalanxious'.

—It is that as well. The conclusions the Committee came to, as best I can summarise them in the time available, are that no such consultation can be completely successful. However, it did gain the endorsement in principle of the Aboriginal people with whom the consultation was conducted. Given the subsequent activities of the Committee, there is no reason arising from the consultative process why the Bill should not proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: I have not had time to deal with the very important question of the dismissal of the commissioners. I recommend the report on that matter to the Senate and to the public who wish to discuss it. I hope my colleagues will give to that the substantial consideration it warrants. In conclusion, I hope that the report receives the serious and responsible treatment it deserves, rather than some of the sensationalism and humbug that recently has surrounded the general question of Aboriginal affairs in this place and elsewhere. If it does, I believe the recommendations will lead to an improvement in the administration of Aboriginal affairs. On that basis, I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to notify my dissent to the majority report and to support both Senator Baume's and my own dissenting report. Both coalition parties disagree violently with the majority report. I recommend that the Bill now before the Parliament, and the whole concept it represents, be withdrawn.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many reasons for this, but the main one is that the indigenous people of Australia either do not want the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC), do not understand the legislation, or want more consultation. We, as part of the Senate Select Committee on Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, took evidence in Queensland, the Northern Territory, Torres Strait, South Australia-all over Australia generally. With very few exceptions-and they were few; I could count them on the fingers of one hand-Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders wanted more time for consultation or did not want ATSIC at any price. Yet this Government is determined to force ATSIC onto the Australian Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander population. This is despite the promise made in Parliament by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) to them and the Australian people when he said:
The effective implementation of these proposals ultimately rests on receiving a positive endorsement from the Aboriginal and Island Community.

Let me say conclusively that that endorsement has never been forthcoming. People out there in the Aboriginal communities do not want it. Earlier, the Minister made this statement in the House when he presented Foundations for the Future:
Aboriginal people need to decide for themselves what should be done-not just take whatever governments . . . say is best for them.

I concur wholeheartedly, 100 per cent. Why will the Government not honour its own promises? Why will it not listen to its own rhetoric? Why does this Government want to foist ATSIC on an unwilling Aboriginal community that has very little understanding of the Bill and an even lesser desire to see its passage through this Parliament?

The Aboriginals and Islanders want more time and this Government will not give it to them. The Government's intended action to force this Bill through Parliament without consent to, or even an understanding of, the legislation by the Aboriginal people is a betrayal of every black person in Australia. It is patronising, it is degrading, it is demeaning to our black brothers and sisters. It shows that this Government has not learned anything about Aboriginals. This Government's determination to go ahead with the legislation, as indicated in the majority report, will not give self-determination. It is white man's legislation, setting up a white man's bureaucracy and thrusting it on the black communities of Australia. That is not self-determination. That is not the Aboriginal way and Senator Collins knows it. This is the same attitude white people had when they took children away from Aboriginals and put them into orphanages because it was good for them, or rounded up blacks and put them on reserves because it was good for them.

This Government is saying, `This ATSIC legislation will give you self-determination and it is good for you. You are going to cop it, whether you like it or not, because Gerry Hand, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the leader of the Socialist Left faction in this Parliament believes it is good for you. It is good Socialist Left doctrine'. I wish there was an honest man or woman in the Australian Labor Party who was prepared to stand up for our 300,000 indigenous people and go to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and say `Look, Bob, let's give Aboriginals more time. Let them make the decisions that are going to affect their lives. Let them understand and let them have more consultation'. Has the Labor Party degenerated to such a low that, because of the cross-factional deals and the need to keep the Socialist Left faction quiet, there is no-one who will speak up for the Aboriginals they represent?

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Senator Zakharov can laugh. Look at the Aboriginals up in the gallery. They are not laughing. Let us look at the consultation process undertaken by the Minister. The Minister travelled extensively through Aboriginal communities for about six weeks between late January and early March. He did not have the legislation to discuss in detail. His visits were whistle stop, rushed and inconclusive. He spoke about a concept only, with no detail. There were no maps available to show the Aboriginal people how the boundaries would operate and how regional councils would work. He offered inducements to communities to get their support for the ATSIC concept and he promised more consultation when the Bill was drafted. I have heard from one large community that he came in and did not even talk about ATSIC; he did not even attempt to explain the legislation. He asked them what they wanted. The Chairman told me that Gerry Hand came into the community and said, `What do you want?'. So he hit the Minister for some houses, roads and water. They never discussed ATSIC at all. That is not consultation; there is another name for it. The fact that Gerry Hand flew into communities and spoke to them for two or three hours in large groups is not explaining to the people what ATSIC is all about. During the Committee's travels it became quite clear that there were many people who had not the slightest idea how the legislation would work. Many had never seen the Bill. Those who had, found it extremely difficult to understand. The Minister promised that when the Bill was printed they would have meetings and more discussions. That never happened. Some communities travelled miles to see the Minister, but he was in and out like a fiddler's elbow. I want to read into my contribution a plea from the Anmatjara tribe of Central Australia. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Hand,

We have heard about this new proposal for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. We went to see Mr Hand at Yuendumu but he was gone. He only stay a short time. That no good. He should stay longer and listen to each group and not just visit big communities.

There was a meeting at Three Bore near Utopia. We heard Alan Randall talk about ATSIC. We heard about those new zones, voting for the Commission and all those things. We had a big talk about it between ourselves when we came home. We are not happy with ATSIC.
Other mobs we talk to are not happy with ATSIC either. All over Napperby, Alyawarra, Utopia outstations, we don't like to mix everyone up in one big council.
We got map today from D.A.A. The map shows all those ATSIC regions in different colours.

Well now we got to tell you, we are not happy about ATSIC and we are not happy about that map. That map is wrong. You can't split our country up. You can't put us with all those other people from different country. That mob from south haven't got skin groups like us. You can't put us with them.
We are not happy with ATSIC and we don't want it.
We are going to talk more about this with our own people.

This is a plea from Aboriginal communities that should make every member of this Senate and this Parliament stop and think before they vote for this legislation. The Anmatjara tribe are not the only ones who could not support the Bill. The Aboriginal Development Commission's (ADC) former acting commissioners advised the Minister that ATSIC was not in the best interests of the Aboriginal people. They genuinely believe that they had the duty to offer the Minister advice on what was in the best interests of the Aboriginal community. Section 8f of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act provides that it is a function of the Commission to further the social and economic development of Aboriginals, to give advice and make recommendations to the Minister with respect to the furtherance of the economic and social development of Aboriginals. These eight ADC commissioners were sacked for having the audacity to tell the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs what they thought was good for their people. Despite the fact that they were required to do so by the Act, they got the chop. The eight acting commissioners were sent back to their communities in disgrace for standing up for their people.

In evidence we were told by Mrs Helen Williams that when she went back to her community she felt ashamed and disgraced. That is the way she described how she felt when she was sent back. She believed that the people in her community would think that she had committed some offence. We were also told that one of the women commissioners was on the verge of a nervous breakdown because her good name and reputation had been denigrated. One of the commissioners said that he felt like he had been kicked in the guts when he got his marching orders. There is no doubt that all the commissioners felt disgraced and denigrated when the Minister sacked the entire board of acting commissioners because they would not be bullied, threatened or intimidated into accepting ATSIC. They knew that their people did not understand and they knew that they did not even have time for consultation.

The commissioners were not the only ones who felt this way. At a meeting in Rockhampton, the former secretary of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, Charles Perkins, moved that the meeting request the Minister to immediately set about holding further meetings and further consultation on ATSIC. We know what happened to Mr Perkins-he got thrown off the troika, off the sleigh, and was fed to the wolves. Similarly, the West Australian Labor Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Ernie Bridge, expressed worry and fear about ATSIC. In October 1988 he said that he was worried about the way ATSIC's regional structure would relate to the State's administration of Aboriginal affairs.

Let me put it on record that every one of the acting commissioners who Mr Hand sacked-I will name them individually: Mr Ossie Cruse, MBE, Mr John Atkinson, AM, Mr Ben Ward, Mr Phillip Yanner, Mrs Helen Williams, Mrs Lena Anaai Passi, Mr Andrew Thomas, and Ms Maria Thompson, as well as the ADC Chairman, Mrs Shirley McPherson, and Commissioner Mrs Zona Martin-acted with integrity, honour, devotion and honesty to the Aboriginal and Islander cause. They refused to betray the Aboriginal people and sell their people out. I wish there were a few honest people on that side of the Parliament who could take a leaf out of their book. On the contrary, the acting commissioners can hold their heads up as people who would not bow to a Minister who wanted to tell Aboriginals and Islanders what was good for them. If this legislation goes through Parliament with the help of the Australian Democrats and causes havoc, disunity and chaos and sets the Aboriginal cause back 40 years, the former commissioners will be held up as role models-as the black heroes who tried to stop the insidious ATSIC Bill.

I now want to put on record the most disgraceful event of the whole sorry saga of ATSIC. This concerns the leaking of a completely fictitious story in the Sydney Morning Herald with the express purpose of denigrating all the dismissed ADC Commissioners. That story ran on 25 May 1988 with the headline `Black group missing $670,000'. The Committee heard evidence that this newspaper report was faxed out to Aboriginals by way of explanation for the dismissal and that some former commissioners had suffered emotional and physical distress because of the leaked story. There is no proof that the Minister's office was aware of who leaked the story, but the story emanated from either his own office or the office of one of the agencies he controls. Either way, he must write a letter of apology acknowledging to each of the dismissed commissioners that the leaked story about financial misrepresentations and misappropriations was untrue and damaging. That is the recommendation of both Senator Peter Baume and myself. It is the least the Minister can do to reinstate the reputations of the dismissed commissioners.

The Senate Committee under its terms of reference was asked to investigate the alternative proposals put forward by the ADC commissioners. Both Senator Peter Baume and I believe that that was not performed adequately. The fact that the Minister took absolutely no notice of the alternative strategy proposed by the ADC is further evidence that he was not interested in any point of view other than his own. He was not interested in discussions or consultation with Aboriginal people. During the Minister's consultative visits to Queensland he completely ignored the largest Aboriginal organisation in Queensland, the Aboriginal Co-ordinating Council (ACC). This organisation represents between 15,000 and 20,000 Aboriginals-arguably more than any other Aboriginal organisation in Australia. It has its own office in Cairns and its own executive, and it is authorised to speak for all Aboriginals living on deed of grant in trust-DOGIT-communities. The Minister did not see fit to consult these people. He did not ring them; he did not even make a courtesy call. It is just another instance of the ineffectiveness of the consultation process undertaken by the Minister. To claim, as he has, that the Aboriginal communities want this legislation is misleading to the Parliament and to all Australians.

Members of the ACC management committee have come to Canberra-I see them sitting in the gallery and I welcome them here; they are courageous men-to make a last ditch appeal to the Prime Minister, who has fobbed them off and sent them over to Gerry Hand. They did not want to see Mr Hand but they are kind, courteous people so they went to see him yesterday. I believe that, belatedly, the Minister has decided that he will visit them, more out of shame than anything else. The reason the ACC is totally opposed to ATSIC is that it will deprive its 15 communities of self-determination. These communities set their own priorities on how to run things. They decide whether they want to allocate money for roads, housing, seweage or whatever. Now these communities will not have that option. They will have to go to the regional council to argue for the funding.

Many of the smaller shire councils and communities may not get any representation on the regional councils. Some Aboriginal councils, such as Utopia and Umagico, have populations as low as 149. These people in smaller communities will not get representation on regional councils. Who will look after their interests? Members of some of the smaller councils have little understanding of English. How will they be able to put their case to a regional council even if they do get on? They are terrified that they will be swamped by more articulate Aboriginal members. Let us take the Cairns regional council. There is a total of 9,000 black people in the Cairns regional council area. There are 1,800 at Yarrabah, 150 at Mosman Gorge and 300 at Kuranda-Mona Mona. That means there are 6,750 urban Aboriginals left, out of the total of 9,000 Aboriginals who live in the Cairns region. There is no doubt that the Cairns people will control the Cairns regional council. This is not a single case; that will happen all over Australia. The smaller communities will not get a look in; they will not have any representation. These are the problems that the Minister has never considered; they are problems that this Parliament has to consider.

The DOGIT communities are financed directly by the Department of Community Services-the Queensland Government department responsible for Aboriginals-and the Federal Department of Aboriginal Affairs. With ATSIC, all funding under DAA will cease and be transferred to ATSIC. The smaller councils will not be represented at regional level and it will be extremely difficult, if not impossible, to have a commissioner elected from Aboriginal communities in Queensland. This will have the effect of establishing two Aboriginal communities in Australia-the articulate haves who can get in and argue their case, the urban Aboriginals who make up the numbers in the big centres, and the smaller communities who will not get a look in. But let there be no misconception and no misunderstanding. Just as many urban Aboriginals are opposed to ATSIC as are community dwellers.

Not only did the Minister not consult Aboriginals but also he did not consult the States, despite the fact that many joint programs are funded through the State and Commonwealth governments. As I understand it, the majority report recommends that a roll be established and only those on the roll will be allowed to vote. I challenge the Minister to have a referendum to determine whether Aboriginals want ATSIC. I believe that the result would be an overall no. Last week on television the Minister said that Aboriginal people must agree with what he is proposing and that it must be introduced with them, not over them. Again I agree with the Minister, but it is rhetoric because very few Aboriginal people want ATSIC. If he has to establish an electoral roll, if the recommendations in the majority report are carried out, the Aboriginals should decide whether they want ATSIC. Let us put it to a referendum and see what the Aboriginals say. I believe that this is the only chance that this Minister has to extricate himself and his Government from this mess.

If the Government really wants to give Aboriginals self-management let it have a referendum on ATSIC. The Minister has relied on the carrot and stick theory with Aboriginals to get their support for ATSIC. He tracked around the communities like Santa Clause with a grab bag of money-$807,999 worth of inducements-and, when that failed, he used the stick. There has been the sacking of eight commissioners, votes of no confidence in the Chairman of the ADC, and the humiliation of the Manager, Mick O'Brien, by transferring him to a non-job. There is a complete loss of morale amongst the management structure of the ADC and the DAA, and one-third of the upper echelon has resigned. These people know the damage that ATSIC will cause. They cannot stand by and see their life's work go down the drain. They are demoralised and they are getting out.

The concept of ATSIC is wrong. It is flawed. It will not work, because it will divide the Aboriginal communities. They will have to fight to get representation at elections for Aboriginal councils and commissioners. There will be deals, counter deals and double deals and it will drive a wedge right through the middle of the Aboriginal communities. Culturally, it is not right for Aboriginals to cross community boundaries. They are devoted to their own communities and they are comfortable working in them. Senator Collins knows that everything I say is right. It is wrong for both white and black Australians to set up what is virtually a black extension of this Parliament with 1,200 elected regional councillors and 15 commissioners. We do not want apartheid in Australia, and that is what this Government is offering us. We want both blacks and whites to enjoy the benefits that this country has to offer. This ATSIC proposal will not achieve that.

Once again this Government has raised the expectations of the Aboriginal people. It has promised them many things which have never been delivered, unlike the Queensland Government and its Minister, Bob Katter, who have given them ownership title to seven million acres of land. That has encouraged Aboriginals to go into their own businesses and develop their own farms and grazing properties. That is self-determination-allowing Aboriginals to run their own enterprises, their own establishments. The ADC that Senator Chaney set up genuinely let Aboriginals develop their own commercial enterprises with no ministerial control-Aboriginals making decisions for Aboriginals. ATSIC will take that all away.

It has been argued that under ATSIC the Minister will have the final say; the commission may make recommendations but the Minister has the power. After 200 years of white settlement this ATSIC legislation will still provide for a white Minister telling black people what is good for them. I cannot, and I will not, sign the majority report. I ask the Australian Democrats and the Independents in this Senate to support the minority view.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the Party that dumped Senator Bonner off the ticket in Queensland.
—No, it was not. That is where you are dead wrong. Madam Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. Senator Bonner was never a member of the National Party of Australia.
—Order! I do not believe that that is a point of order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This whole matter is an extremely difficult one. We have heard a great deal of evidence on both sides of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) question and I do not think we will really serve Aboriginal interests-and that is what we should be on about-at all by name calling and attempting to score points off each other. I begin by dealing with the attack which the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) made on Senate committees in general and on the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs in particular because I believe that both the Minister's general attack and his specific attack were entirely uncalled for. His remarks were damaging because they came during the final days of the deliberations of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. They maligned the members of a Committee from both sides of the House who, as far as I can judge, were behaving in an absolutely impeccable manner and were discharging their duties to the best of their abilities.

SPEECH.PARA: I would draw the conclusion that this is a symptom of the way in which this Minister has dealt with the legislation from the very beginning. Unfortunately, this has brought the whole matter of restructuring Aboriginal Affairs into an area of debate which has been totally counterproductive to the best interests of Aboriginal people. The Minister has seemed to accept that any criticism of ATSIC, no matter how well-founded, is a personal criticism of him, has attacked those people who have dared even to offer constructive suggestions for modification of the ATSIC proposal and therefore has developed a confrontationist and a polarised view which I can only repeat has been totally counterproductive and very damaging to the whole process of the consideration of this legislation. One could extend that diagnosis of the Minister's handling by mentioning the way in which he dealt with the eight former Aboriginal Development Commission commissioners and, as Senator Boswell has pointed out, his attack on the Chairman of the ADC, Shirley McPherson. Personally I have found her to be a competent person of the highest integrity who is certainly not in any sense attempting to attack the Minister but simply to put up alternative proposals for the betterment of Aboriginal people of whom she is one.

I think the Minister was totally wrong in behaving that way.
