His actions were counterproductive and, indeed, politically stupid because, had he waited only a few short weeks, the terms of those acting commissioners would have expired anyway and he could quite easily have appointed other people. I have observed much of the hurt which the Minister generated in Aboriginal communities by that action because those people took that not only as a personal slight but also as a slight on their families and their communities. That whole action could have been avoided.

It is also worth while pointing out in relation to consultation that, I believe the Minister did consult quite widely and quite well on the general principle of ATSIC-the principle of self-determination and self-management. He went around with the document Foundations for the Future and I believe that he achieved an in-principle support for ATSIC. But I also believe many Aboriginal people formed the opinion that the Minister had given an undertaking that when the legislation became available he would go back and further consult with them so that they could make a judgment as to whether the specific clauses of a specific Bill met the outline to which they had assented in those early consultations. The majority report makes it quite clear that that later phase of the consultation did not occur. There was no consultation whatsoever once the legislation was introduced into the House of Representatives on 24 August 1988.

One can move on from that and draw attention to the fact that from that process the Opposition essentially has adopted several fall-back positions. The Opposition's first position is that the legislation should simply be thrown out. Failing that the next fall-back position is that the legislation should be delayed so that further consultation should occur. The next fall-back position is that if the legislation proceeds then the Opposition has very significantly contributed to those amendments which have been suggested in the report in which there are some 31 recommendations. I have contributed significantly to the recommendations for modi- fication of ATSIC and I would part company with the Opposition at the point where it is calling for the abolition of ATSIC and also at the point--

TALK.START.PARA: —It hasn't been abolished yet.

—I think I understand Senator Baume's position very well. I respect his position and I think he has come to it for good and valid reasons. I happen to disagree with that position and I wish to explain why. I also disagree with the call for further consultation. The reason I do that is that I believe that if the amendments which have been suggested in the report are adopted-and that is a very big if, considering the way in which the Minister has hitherto dealt with this matter-they will constitute an extension of the principle of self-determination and self-management, which is the principle to which those Aboriginal people assented in those early consultations. Moreover, in framing those suggested amendments, the Committee, which has existed for six months, moved around the country. It has considered a number of submissions and has taken on board a number of the suggestions for amendments which have been put before it. I stress again that, provided the Government is prepared to accept those amendments to the legislation which give back to Aboriginal people the ability to modify this legislation with respect to the regional council boundaries, the electorate processes and a number of other things which I will deal with in a moment, then the legislation will give effect to the in-principle support which Aboriginal people had originally assented to back in that period of January to March 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is worth making the point here, as Senator Boswell has stressed and some Aboriginal people as recently as yesterday and today have pointed out to me, that some groups who will be represented in regional councils will have either no voice or a very small voice. It was pointed out to me yesterday that in the case of the Aboriginal Co-ordinating Council (ACC) from Cairns some groups may have only 20 per cent of the representation in a regional council. They fear that it may follow that they will not continue to get the funding which they now get through a white administered system. My comment on that is that if ATSIC is about self-determination and self-management it seems to me to follow that under these regional councils Aboriginal people are the appropriate people to make those judgments. For Aboriginal people to say that they want to continue to have that dispensation of funds in white hands because white hands do it better simply flies in the face of everything that the Australian Democrats, certainly, have been on about in giving the control of these matters-the recognition of Aboriginal self-determination and self-management-back to Aboriginals.

I have just met with a number of Aboriginal people outside who pointed out to me, quite rightly, that this is a piece of white legislation and it imposes on Aboriginal people a white system of structuring regional councils and electing, through zones, a white structured organisation, even though it might represent Aboriginal interests. I accept that that is a valid criticism looked at from the Aboriginal point of view, but I am afraid that I do not see a way around that, given 200 years of white occupation. I believe that the best the white people can do is to give back, as far as possible within the existing structures, a mechanism wherein Aboriginal people can make their own decisions regarding welfare, housing, education and legal services. Because we work under a European legislative system, necessarily we must do that under our own law. I recognise that that is a compromise. However, given the history which has preceded the development of Aboriginal and white relationships and the development of the whole legislative process in this country, that is an inevitable mechanism.

I now turn to some of the recommendations in the report that I think are important to observe. First of all, the report recommends that the preamble be separated from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill. As Senator McMullan pointed out in his opening remarks, it is widely recognised that the preamble, even attached to the Bill, has no force whatsoever in law. Yet many Aboriginal people looking at that preamble believed that it may have had some force in law and they may have been misled into believing that it gave some legal recognition of prior Aboriginal occupation, dispossession and the legal consequences flowing from that. That would have been a completely dishonest impression to give to Aboriginal people. Therefore, it is appropriate that the preamble be separated and dealt with in the Senate as a separate motion of the Senate in a cognate debate. Hopefully, the preamble would be passed. It would be a motion of the Senate and would be seen as such. It would have the force of any other motion of the Senate, but it could never be confused as a document which had some legal force.

Recognising that the passage of the ATSIC legislation would lead to the abolition of the ADC and the Aboriginal Development Commission Act-at the moment the ADC Act is the only piece of legislation which recognises in law prior Aboriginal occupation of this country and the dispossession of the Aboriginal people-that report recommends that those sections of the ADC Act which would be revoked be carried over and written into the ATSIC legislation. It is important to recognise that, while the Committee recommends the separation of the preamble from the Bill, it actually seeks to strengthen the recognition of the position of Aboriginal people with respect to their prior occupation of this country and their dispossession.

It is important to recognise a number of other sections of the report. The passage of legislation of any sort inevitably imposes on Aboriginal people a white European system. Recognising that and recognising the need for a democratic process, the Committee has accepted the prior construction of rolls on which the election of the regional councils and through that the election of the zones to ATSIC can be carried out. The Bill as it stands does not provide for prior construction of rolls or compulsory voting. It is wide open to abuse. For instance, people could come in from outside an area and vote in an area in which they were not normally resident. Moreover, in the event of the recall provisions, one could have a different population of people responsible for recall from those who voted for the original regional council. I believe that such a situation is quite intolerable. Therefore, it is appropriate that rolls constructed before elections occur and that the placing of one's name on such a roll be voluntary. However, once one's name is on the roll, voting should be compulsory and those who could vote for the regional councils should be residents of that area, so that people outside the area cannot interfere with that electoral process.

Related to that is a recommendation in my minority report that was not accepted by other Committee members on either side of the House. That recommendation concerns the definition of an Aboriginal person. The Bill as it is at the moment defines an Aboriginal person as a person of the Aboriginal race. It is a tautology. It says absolutely nothing. It leaves the matter wide open for legal challenge. Under the existing Bill rolls would not be constructed prior to an election. People would simply turn up to vote, they would vote and, if their right to vote were challenged, they would have that challenge necessarily heard in a court and the vote would be kept separate until the court challenge had been heard. That would be an enormous impediment to the further progress of the implementation of ATSIC.

It seems to me that it is necessary to clarify who is eligible to vote so that challenges are likely to be less frequent. That links necessarily with the idea of prior construction of rolls and compulsory voting. That would tighten up the electoral process and make it properly democratic. The recommendation I have made for the redefinition of an Aboriginal person is exactly in line with the definition that has been used by the courts. It is a two-part definition and it says that an Aboriginal person is a person of Aboriginal descent and, if unable to prove Aboriginal descent, a person who identifies himself or herself as an Aboriginal and is identified as such by the community. That is the working definition which is used by the courts. It seems to me that it is an abdication of our responsibility to put into legislation a definition which requires interpretation by the courts when it is our proper function to write those definitions into law.

I should mention that the objection that has been made to clarifying the definition is that it may fall foul of the section of the Constitution which was amended in the 1967 referendum. The basis of that argument is that by further clarifying the definition it may be possible to show that an Aboriginal person was excluded from the provisions of this legislation and, therefore, fell foul of the provisions of the Constitution. I point out in defence of my proposal that if the courts have consistently used the working definition I have outlined, it would be necessary for a person challenging this legislation-supposing it included my redefinition-to establish a different definition of an Aboriginal person, to have that accepted by the courts, and then establish that under that new definition that person was excluded. That begs the question rather too far and, therefore, it is appropriate that the matter be clarified so there will be fewer challenges and people will be quite clear as to who is included or excluded from the provisions of the ATSIC legislation.

Another provision to which it is important to draw attention and which, if adopted, would significantly modify the ATSIC Bill relates to the structure and function of the Aboriginal Economic Development Commission (AEDC), the body which will take on the function of accepting capital grants from the Government. I would point out-and Senator Chaney will recognise the importance of this-that the capital fund was set up originally and specifically in recognition of prior Aboriginal occupation of this country and of dispossession. Money was paid into that capital fund by a then Liberal government, but no money has been paid into that fund by the Labor Government since 1983. The AEDC will take on that capital fund and will have the function of investing that in a range of activities-not necessarily even Aboriginal activities-under the existing Bill. If the Committee's recommendations are adopted, the AEDC will take on many of the functions of economic development which up to now have been carried on by the ADC. We believe as a Committee that it was appropriate that in accordance with the ADC's submission to us and to the Minister-but the Minister did not accept it-welfare and economic functions should be kept separate. Moreover-and I think that Senator McMullan has drawn attention to this-in view of the fact that that capital fund was a recognition of dispossession and therefore was a fund, as it were, in compensation for that dispossession, it was very appropriate that, contrary to the Bill as it stands at present, no dividend should be paid to the Government on any profits which flowed from that fund, nor should taxation be paid on the profits from that capital fund. Again, I hope that the Minister will accept that recommendation.

In line with the number of submissions which I have received personally and which the Committee received, running the full gamut from asking for ATSIC not to proceed at all to implementing ATSIC forthwith without amendment or further discussion, and recognising that what Aboriginal people assented to in those early consultations was in principle acceptance of the self-determination and self-management principle, I have sought-and I believe the Committee has agreed with this approach-to suggest amendments. When ATSIC is implemented those amendments will give to the Aboriginal people themselves the ability to control the further evolution of that structure so that it meets their real needs. With that in mind, the recommendations go to the matter of boundaries, and there is great concern over boundaries both in the Northern Territory and in Queensland. I cannot stress more strongly that if the Minister accepts the recommendations-and I hope that he does and no longer proceeds with the attitude he has adopted up to now on this legislation-one of the first tasks of these regional councils will be to review their own boundaries. There is also a requirement that before every second election there be a review of boundaries.

The Committee also heard evidence that some areas would prefer a different election process. What is envisaged in the Bill, rather interestingly in view of the imposition by the Government and Opposition of the d'Hondt system in the Australian Capital Territory, is a Senate type election process for regional councils-a very appropriate quota proportional representational system which could not be more democratic. We heard in some regions that people would prefer to have representation through their existing councils and elected and representative bodies in each region. I see nothing wrong with that at all, and even from a democratic point of view it could easily be accommodated. Again, the report recommends that the regional councils consider that matter and they will be able to make recommendations about change in the electoral process. It is also recommended that the Electoral Commission consider those matters and make a recommendation on any proposals which come forward. It is appropriate that there be an overview so that whatever electoral process is suggested that process will be properly representative and democratic and properly represent the interests of Aboriginal people within that region.

In regard to this report, provided that one goes past the first two fall-back positions of the Opposition, I would point out that Opposition members fully participated in the discussion of the recommendations which were included in the majority report. Therefore, if the legislation proceeds I believe that the Opposition will support those recommendations. I express the hope that the Minister will accept the fact that those six members of the Committee in good faith, and with the best interests of Aboriginal people at heart, carefully considered all the pros and cons and came down with the best recommendations that they possibly could. I hope that the Minister will take those recommendations very seriously. I hope he will either make it clear that if he proceeds with this legislation he will be prepared to allow those amendments to be included, or if he chooses to withdraw the legislation and resubmit it that again he will take those amendments into account. In that way we shall get before the Senate a much better Bill which will more comprehensively fulfil the considerations of self-management and self-determination to which I believe the Aboriginal people are committed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope not to detain the Senate for too long. Indeed, there is no need for me to do so, as the Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, Senator McMullan, has fairly comprehensively outlined the major aspects of the majority report. However, I must touch briefly on some of the comments made by the two previous speakers. One of the most bizarre aspects of this debate for me so far has been the spectacle of the far right wing of this Parliament, a Queensland National Party senator, purporting to act as a champion for blacks. As a person who has been actively involved in the political life of this country for some time, and having seen at first hand the way in which the conservatives have ground Australian Aboriginal people into the dirt for the last 20 years, I regard that as a fairly bizarre performance. The Queensland National Party was responsible directly for dumping the one and only Aboriginal Australian who has ever graced this Parliament, Senator Neville Bonner, in a disgraceful intervention in the preselection processes of the Queensland Liberal Party. It reached the point-a chapter I shall never forget-where a Liberal Party senator, then Senator Kathy Martin, in a gesture which does not happen often in politics, publicly offered to give up her position on the Senate ticket to Senator Bonner because of her outrage at the behaviour of the Queensland Nationals, and in particular the Queensland Premier who wanted to rid himself of that turbulent priest. The turbulent priest embarrassed the Queensland Nationals by his very moderate and conservative support of the position of his own people in Queensland. So it is a little bizarre to hear in this Parliament this afternoon a defence of Aboriginals by a representative of that same party that dumped the only Aboriginal ever to get into this place.

SPEECH.PARA: I must also comment on a couple of the more outrageous statements that Senator Boswell made in canvassing the question of the propriety and personal integrity of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Gerry Hand. Senator Boswell accused the Minister of buying support for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission by approving grants to communities that he visited during the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) consultations. He then quoted statements made by Aboriginal people from Queensland that the Minister did not talk to them about ATSIC when he got to their communities. There may be criticisms of and reservations about the consultation process that took place. Indeed, the majority report has expressed them. But, as someone who was part of those consultations, at least in the Northern Territory sector, I suggest it is beyond question that the round of consultations was the most extensive ever undertaken by any Minister for Aboriginal Affairs on anything. I say that in order to address the serious, false and malicious charge levelled against the Minister by Senator Boswell that the Minister bought support for ATSIC by the simple act of approving applications made to him for grants. What nonsense.

The Aboriginal affairs ministry is a difficult portfolio. In order even to attempt to cover the portfolio properly, the most extensive travel around this country is necessary because Aboriginal people in their thousands live in every State of this Commonwealth, many in isolated communities. As I know, at times one has to spend days and days of uncomfortable travel to visit literally a handful of people. Aboriginal people do not have constant access to Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs. It is not a common event-nor could it ever be-for a sole individual ever to visit frequently any Aboriginal communities in this country. Not surprisingly, on the rare opportunities communities have to gain direct personal access to the Minister they wish to canvass matters of concern to their communities. I would have thought that that message, at least, would have got through to Senator Boswell by now.

As someone who was personally present with the Minister at the meetings in the Northern Territory, where every single community raised these matters of concern, I can say that on each one of those occasions the Minister behaved with the utmost propriety and, I am pleased to say, showed sympathy and understanding. In many cases he made positive responses to the representations made to him at those times by Aboriginal people for toilets, houses, assistance with sporting venues and so on.

I am certainly not going to stand here and say what a dreadful thing it was for Gerry Hand to have approved a grant of thousands of dollars for the provision of public toilets at Yuendumu because he happened to be there when the ATSIC consultations were on. I say good on him for doing so. To attempt to portray that as misbehaviour on the part of a Minister is disgraceful, and Senator Boswell knows it.

I want to address the complaint that `the Minister was here but he did not talk to us about ATSIC'. I have worked in Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory for over 20 years. Over 10 years I represented two Aboriginal seats in the Northern Territory Parliament. It did not matter how many times one visited an Aboriginal community, it was never possible to see everyone. On every occasion that I went to an Aboriginal community-I may have visited it only two weeks before-more than one person would say, `Where have you been for the last 12 months?'. I would say to those persons, `Hang on, I was out here only two weeks ago'. They would say, `Well you did not talk to me'. Again, that kind of criticism is not valid criticism of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs who, on each of the occasions that I was personally with him, made himself available to anyone who wanted to see him, no matter how long it took. These personal criticisms of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs are outrageous. As the Chairman of this Committee, Senator McMullan, said, they are salacious in the way in which they have been presented in this report and deserve the utter contempt and rejection of the Senate.

Before I get on to the report proper, I must also drop a gentle bucket on my National Party colleague from the Northern Territory, Senator Tambling, who was the genesis of this Committee. It was Senator Tambling's motion that initiated the setting up of the Committee. If my memory does not play me false, Senator Coulter seconded the motion. Senator Coulter at least had the intestinal fortitude to serve on the Committee, and of course Senator Tambling did not. For the benefit of the people of the Northern Territory, the only reason I mention this is that, had Senator Tambling simply moved the motion and then done nothing further, I would not have had any valid criticism to make of him. But since then Senator Tambling has, on numerous occasions during the months that this Committee has been operating, put out public statement after public statement, beating his breast in the Northern Territory saying, `Aren't I a clever boy? It was all my work. I set up the Committee with a motion that I moved in the Senate'.

As someone who has had the hands on involvement of serving on what has been a difficult and controversial committee, I have to say that it was very frustrating for me to see these statements being put out-although I did not respond to them-by someone who moved a motion to establish the Committee but who did not have the intestinal fortitude to follow it through. As far as Senator Tambling is concerned, it was no care and no responsibility. I hope that Senator Tambling does not have the absolute temerity to contribute to this debate, because he does not deserve to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I could not have done anything on the Committee.

—The honourable senator should not have moved the motion. As I have said, I had no objections to Senator Tambling doing so, but if he wants to parade upon the public stage in the Northern Territory taking credit for the work the Committee was doing, as he has attempted to do in public statement after public statement, he could at least have served on it. Senator Coulter made a number of remarks about criticisms of the Committee. My response to those criticisms is slightly softer than Senator Coulter's. I can understand the frustration of a House of Representatives Government Minister wanting-passionately wanting, I believe-to have legislation in which he very strongly believes put through the Parliament.
—Do you believe in the legislation?

—My opinion on this legislation, as is Senator Boswell's, is contained within the covers of this report. Senator Boswell's interjection deserves comment. I believe that the Committee dealt with this matter both expeditiously and competently. The application of every senator on the Committee was reflected by their high attendance. I personally gave the Committee precedence over all other committees that I serve on in this Parliament with the sole exception of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, the reason being that I chair that Committee. I have a view that, if one chairs a committee, that committee deserves to have precedence over other committees one serves on. I regret that I was absent from the Queensland sector of the Committee's work-it was the only sector from which I was absent-because of obligations I had as a result of my chairmanship of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. On a second occasion I was not able to attend the Committee's hearings because, although I had come to Canberra for them, unfortunately I had to return to the Northern Territory to attend the funeral of a close friend of mine of 20 years-probably the most prominent cultural leader of Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory, Nandjiwarra Amagula, at Groote Eylandt.
—What evidence did he give to the Committee?

—The man is dead, so let us not canvass that too broadly. Senator Tambling would canvass it because he does not have any scruples. Nandjiwarra Amagula had what was the largest Aboriginal funeral I have ever seen in my life, with about 2,000 people attending. Aboriginal people from the central desert, Maningrida, the Tiwi Islands and all over the Northern Territory went to that funeral to demonstrate the very high regard in which they held Nandjiwarra. It is a fact, in response to Senator Tambling's interjection, that the very last occasion that I, as a politician, received representation from Nandjiwarra Amagula was in Darwin in my capacity as Acting Chairman of this Senate Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I say again that the application of all senators to the work of the Committee was excellent. I understand the Minister's frustrations. As I say, it is something to which I have a softer response than Senator Coulter. One of the first lessons I learnt in my first week in this Parliament was that there is in fact a profound ignorance on the part of members of the House of Representatives, whether they be Ministers or backbenchers, as to how this Senate operates. It is a profound ignorance. I must say that members of the House of Representatives who live in that ignorance do not hesitate to let one know that as far as they are concerned ignorance is bliss because they do not want to know about this place. I suppose the Minister's frustrations stem from the fact that he would like to see the end of the Senate, like a lot of other people in the country.

There is a profound difference, of course, in the way in which the two chambers operate. That was very largely responsible for the criticisms that were made. In the House of Representatives if one wants to make a conquest there is no seduction. It is a simple case of rape with a bit of S and M involved. There is an application of the gag, a touch around the ears with the guillotine and then it is `wham bam' and not even `thank you, Ma'am'. In the Senate, of course, a different approach is required. In here one needs candlelight and soft music. There are no Democrats in the House of Representatives. That is the significant difference. One needs at last a five-course meal. One has to expect that there is a good chance the menu will be referred to a committee for amendment before the night is over. French champagne is what suffices. I might add that one needs a better and more persuasive line of patter than: `Have you been here very often?'. And again I might add that one stands a very good chance, despite all of that, at the end of the evening, of ending up stuck with the bill and one's conquest of the night disappearing with the head waiter. That is the reality of the Senate. It is something that members of the House of Representatives do not appreciate. In fact, that was principally responsible for the Minister's full and frank comments about the operations of the Committee. I do not place any greater weight on them than that.

However, in the last 48 hours the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has made a number of statements with which I do concur. The statements in fact have been touched upon already by the chairman of this Committee, Senator McMullan. When the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs said on the Face to Face program on Sunday and, I understand, again in an interview this morning, perhaps even on the AM program, that, having studied the report, if in his view the amendments that have been canvassed by this Committee are of such substance that they require further input from the Aboriginal community-I might add it is a form of operations that this Minister has exercised far more extensively than any other Minister, in my opinion-he will take these recommendations which most directly affect the Aboriginal community back to the Aboriginal community without simply unilaterally making a decision on them himself. That is a course of action which I support.

I would therefore, without detaining the Senate for too long, wish to restrict the remainder of my remarks to two issues. The first instance relates to the vexed question of the sacking of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) commissioners, which caused me some personal pain as a number of them had been appointed on my recommendation. Secondly, I wish to canvass those particular recommendations which this Committee has made in conclusion that fall into that category of recommendations that would be of considerable significance to the Aboriginal communities that they may wish to have some input on.

So far as the sacking of the ADC commissioners is concerned, I can do no more than suggest and recommend to members of this chamber that they read page 93 of the report where we canvassed that issue. We said on page 95 of that report, in paragraph 5.17:
The position of the ADC, its extensive powers and quasi-representative role are essential background to an understanding of the dispute with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.

That is correct because there is and always was an inherent conflict between the two roles of the ADC which I believe brought about this dispute. That is canvassed at page 93 of the report, where we say:

However, the ethos of self-management and self-determination which had developed with the ADC's experience, and was heightened after the Report of the House of Representatives Expenditure Committee in 1985, did not sit easily with the legislative reality of its position.
We go on to say:

On the one hand the ADC is a quasi-representative Aboriginal body established in acknowledgment of and partial compensation for the injustices inflicted on that community. Its guiding principles are self-management and self-sufficiency of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders . . .
We then go on to say:

On the other hand are the familiar structures of Ministerial control and direction, and Parliamentary accountability appropriate to any Commonwealth agency administering Government policy and managing public revenue.

We then go on to quote from the speech of the honourable senator who introduced that legislation into this Parliament, Senator Neville Bonner. In direct response to representations from the National Aboriginal Conference that the ADC should not be accountable in this way, he said:
The Government believes that the Minister cannot meet his responsibilities as required by the Administrative Arrangements Order . . . without a power of general direction.

I concur with that opinion of the then Senator Bonner. With the best will in the world, I do not believe one can provide to any statutory body a sum of public money that could be in the vicinity of $600m a year without being able in the ultimate to have a Minister responsible in the elected body, the Federal Parliament. This is simply not on, in my view. I might add that that is precisely the conclusion that the majority report comes to.

However, it is necessary to understand that there is that conflict in the two roles of the ADC, that is, the balance between responding on the one hand to the Aboriginal community of Australia and, on the other hand, accepting the ultimate veto and responsibility of the Federal Parliament which is properly exercised.

Turning to the recommendations themselves-as I said before, I will simply touch on those ones which in my view will be of some significance to the Aboriginal community-the obvious one that others will probably seize upon is recommendation 20 which says:
The preamble in its present form be put to the Parliament as a separate and simultaneous resolution with the ATSIC Bill.

In other words, the preamble to the legislation should be removed from the Bill and passed as a separate resolution. The Committee had quite a number of representations on this question of the preamble from non-Aboriginal groups and from the Northern Territory Government, for example, which gave us the benefit of its quite extensive advice on this issue. I must say that I was not personally persuaded by many of those representations which feared that the preamble would be read in some way as affecting the interpretation of the Bill in such a way that legal status that was not intended would be given. I do not believe that that was the case. Nevertheless, I accept the validity of the advice we received.

However, on the other hand, we also received representations from the Aboriginal community, some of whom did not want the preamble to be put in the Bill simply because of that same non-legal force. They put to us that they were fearful that the preamble could be seen as some second class substitute for the compact that has been announced by the Government between Aboriginal Australians and the Federal Government and that it could be seen in some way as derogating from that. That was a submission which did have some weight with me.

In the final event the Committee decided-I think rightly-that to satisfy both sides of the argument, to remove any doubt that could have been there and to accommodate the fears that some Aboriginal people expressed by way of the handling of it, it should recommend in the report that the preamble be removed from the legislation itself and passed simultaneously with the passage of the ATSIC legislation as a separate resolution of the Parliament. Obviously, that is a recommendation of some weight. Clearly, Aboriginal people will want to have some input into it.

Recommendation No. 1 of the Committee is that a separate office of Aboriginal Affairs be retained within the Employment, Education and Training portfolio, again a matter of some significance to the Aboriginal community. The Committee received representations from Aboriginal people that no separate office of Aboriginal Affairs be retained and that ATSIC should be the sole source of policy advice to the Minister. Clearly, the Aboriginal people who expressed those views to us will not be happy about this particular recommendation.

Recommendation No. 2 was also canvassed at some length by Senator Coulter. It is one of substance and weight. The recommendation is that a greater proportion of the current activities of the Aboriginal Development Commission should be the responsibility of the proposed AEDC that is envisaged in the Bill. I refer briefly to the section of the report that deals with that because it is an important recommendation. Currently, the legislation proposes that both ATSIC itself and the AEDC have concurrent financial responsibility for funding Aboriginal enterprise. It is not entirely clear where ATSIC leaves off and the AEDC takes over, although the implications is that ATSIC will handle matters of a smaller community based nature, whereas the AEDC will handle the larger investment matters. However, the distinction is not clear. We think that the recommendation has much merit. Simply to transfer more functions is not sufficient. I can do no better than to quote from paragraph 2.36 on page 20 of our report, which states:
A more appropriate division would involve:
(i) abolition of the ADC;
(ii) transfer all its housing functions to ATSIC; and

(iii) responsibility for enterprise development, enterprise support, land acquisition and investment functions currently proposed for ATSIC in the Bill to be transferred to the AEDC. The AEDC's charter should be amended to make explicit the retention of the link between the investment and enterprise functions.

In other words, it is recommended that all financial enterprise involvement, with the sole exception of housing which, of course, is a general welfare type provision and therefore a sensible exception, should be transferred to the AEDC. Again, that is a recommendation of some substance on which the Aboriginal community would want to be consulted. The third recommendation is also one of substance. It is that the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies should, in effect, continue to exist as an autonomous and independent body independent of ATSIC. However, ATSIC commissioners would serve on its board.

Recommendation No. 10 refers to consultation in respect of regional boundaries. The majority report has come to a sensible conclusion on regional boundaries. They are a vexed question. I have received many representations from Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory who have provided very valid reasons for their unhappiness with the current boundaries. I give the Senate one brief illustration. It is not simply a matter of cultural objection to some of the boundaries. In some cases, there is a very sensible administrative objection to the current boundaries. One such example, which we used in the report, is that of the community of Ngukurr on the Gulf. Ngukurr acts as a resource centre for many outstations in the area. Those outstations rely on Ngukurr financially and for their logistic support. However, Ngukurr is in one region of ATSIC and the outstations are in another. Under the proposed boundaries, the outstations will rely for their funding on a regional council which has nothing whatever to do with them. There is a clear case there for a change to the boundaries. The recommendation that ATSIC itself be responsible for these necessary amendments is a sensible and reasonable one.

Aboriginal people may also wish to be consulted on recommendation No. 11. The Committee recommends that regions with populations of fewer than 1,000 will elect 10 councillors and so on, on a sliding scale. It is a sensible recommendation. It is perfectly true that regional councils do not have a problem with malapportionment in respect of their regions, but there is a problem in respect of the role they play collegiately in electing zone commissioners. To some extent, this would overcome the problem. Recommendation No. 12 proposed voluntary enrolment and compulsory voting, which is precisely the situation that existed in the Northern Territory in relation to general elections for Aboriginal people for many years until both enrolment and voting became compulsory. Again, Aboriginal people may wish to be consulted on that recommendation.

Recommendation No. 14 is an important one in that it suggests that the ATSIC Bill should be amended to allow regions to establish their own systems of elections. The Tiwi people on Bathurst and Melville Islands are particularly keen on this recommendation as it is something they want to do. The Minister, to his credit, made three separate visits to address members of the Tiwi Land Council and is well aware of that. Recommendation No. 17, to remove the requirement that the Minister must transfer any increase in the Torres Strait regional allocation from the other regional allocations, is an important recommendation and one in which Aboriginal people might wish to be involved.

I have already covered recommendation No. 20 that the preamble be removed from the legislation and be moved as a separate motion. It is a recommendation of some substance. Should the Minister determine, as he flagged yesterday and again today, that these recommendations are not recommendations on which he can properly make decisions unilaterally but in consultation with the community, I indicate, as did Senator McMullan, that I concur with that situation. I conclude by saying that it is important that the basic principles of ATSIC be adhered to and continued with. Some elements of the conservative parties in this Parliament and other parliaments simply want to see the demolition of ATSIC and the replacement of it with nothing whatever. That is not a motive I ascribe to many people on the Opposition benches because I know that would be a totally unfair criticism, but certainly some members opposite wish to see that happen. I reject that approach utterly and comprehensively. I hope that the Minister will carefully consider the recommendations in this report; I know he will. I assure the Senate that the Committee has laboured over the report with a great deal of application and care, as it is a controversial subject. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —If ever the Aboriginal people looked to the Parliament for fair play and protection, it was in the matter of the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, that creature we know by the acronym of ATSIC. If ever a group was betrayed, it was the Aboriginal people with the majority report of the Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. The majority report is a disaster. Faced with a mass of evidence, that report finds not as the evidence demands so clearly, but in a party political way for the Government and in spite of the evidence. Faced with significant questions and doubts about the whole concept of ATSIC, the majority report chooses to give only an historical account of the process by which ATSIC was developed and chooses to say little at all about the threshold issues which are critical to any proper assessment of this radical and complex proposal. The majority report makes no attempt to justify ATSIC, to make a case for it. It presents no case to show why the Government proposal for ATSIC would be in any way superior to the proposal of the former Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) for portfolio restructuring. We do not favour a vacuum. The alternative proposal for portfolio restructuring was a serious one which was not given due consideration. The examination of that argument and the only logical conclusions were left to the minority report and to coalition senators. Faced with allegations of intimidation, coercion, standover tactics, the offering of inducements in the ATSIC process, as we were, the majority report chooses to make only the most minimal of findings to send the allegations off to Mr Andrew Menzies, to see as little as possible, to say as little as possible, to recommend the absolute minimum of action and to fail to offer other logical and necessary recommendations. Yet just this day we had tabled here a statutory declaration from Mr Merv Gibson of Hopevale in which he states on oath that funding for the infrastructure project at Hopevale would have to be reconsidered if he and the Aboriginal coordinating council continued to oppose ATSIC. He says in his statutory declaration that that threat was made by Mr Gayler, the local Labor member of parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Further, faced with the quite disgraceful treatment of eight former acting commissioners of the Aboriginal Development Commission, including the deliberate circulation of untrue and vindictive allegations about the ADC, of which they were then commissioners, the majority report chooses to make only the most minor recommendations. It does not even call on the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) to acknowledge publicly that the stories in the newspapers about financial mismanagement are untruthful and damaging. It does not even go that far. That was left to the minority report. The majority report, in short, is a tribute to the discipline and the priorities of the Australian Labor Party. It is predicated on the needs and priorities of the Labor Party, not on the interests of Aboriginal people or of Aboriginal Australia. For that reason, it is a betrayal of Aboriginal Australia and of the interests of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians.

The evidence before the Select Committee reveals a mess the like of which I have never seen in 15 years in this place. The Department that has emerged before this Select Committee is not the Department I knew in the 1970s, or when I was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in the early years of this decade. The report of the majority details some of the evidence but does not then proceed to the obvious conclusions to which that evidence should have led. For instance, the evidence is eloquent about the failure of Mr Hand to consult adequately, or thoroughly, or as he had promised, or with all those who would be affected by the legislation now before the Senate. He simply did not bother to consult with State governments in the development and promotion of the proposal. He did not bother to consult with mining interests. He did not bother to consult with local government. He did not bother to consult with farming interests. Unless he had been seeking some confrontation deliberately or had considered these interests to be unimportant or irrelevant, such a failure to consult makes no sense and is the one sure way to guarantee that he will meet opposition later from the groups he so assiduously ignored. It was left to the minority report to draw the logical conclusions and to make the logical and necessary recommendations in this area.

I remind the Senate that this Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs was proposed, on a motion by Senator Tambling, after an enormous amount of work done by him and by Senator Short, which culminated in the estimates committee hearings and in the revelations which emerged before Senate Estimates Committee E, I think it was, in late 1988. The committee process was long and difficult but it was courteous, and consultation within the Committee was detailed. It was a difficult process for the Committee secretariat, which performed its tasks with diligence and distinction. There was agreement on many matters of drafting, on what was said, on what occurred, on what was written in documents and, finally, on some of the minor conclusions. The disagreements arose when the Committee came to consider what the evidence told us on major matters, or what the evidence told us on any matter that involved any criticism of the Minister. I have to say the Labor senators were determined to allow no hint of criticism of the Minister of any kind to appear in the agreed report.

Senator Chaney has a story about his first select committee in 1975, when he was advised by former senator Sir Reginald Wright to `let the evidence lead you on'. That is what should have happened here: the evidence should have led us on. The evidence was overwhelming in what it revealed. We have set out some of the obvious conclusions in our minority report and we will, I hope, pursue those conclusions here in the Senate at an appropriate time if that is necessary. There is no point in seeking to get amendments, as Senator Coulter would do, after the Bill becomes an Act. Does anyone really think Mr Hand will welcome amendments then? The only time to fix the Bill, if the Government is determined to proceed, is now, before it becomes an Act of Parliament.

Let us consider first the threshold question of the justification of ATSIC. One would imagine that a prudent or sensitive government seeking to overturn all the existing arrangements for administering Aboriginal affairs in Australia would have made a strong, cast-iron case over a period of time for that course of action. One would also have thought that it would have made that case known to the Australian public. The Labor Government has not done so. The course is being followed, it seems, out of prime ministerial ignorance and ministerial prejudice. But honourable senators will realise immediately that neither of those elements, of themselves, can justify ATSIC. Neither relates in any way at all to the well-being or the advancement of Aboriginal Australians.

The Government is proposing that all existing arrangements should be ended arbitrarily; that existing arrangements with the States should be terminated unilaterally; that the successful Aboriginal Development Commission should be subsumed into an untried and uncertain new body; that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs should be made over into the new body; that the Institute of Aboriginal Studies and Aboriginal Hostels Limited should also be included. Such radical rearrangement should be justified by careful and adequate argument, but this proposal is not and never has been so justified. Accordingly, at the threshold, we can say that the proposal should not proceed. It should not proceed now and it should not be brought back until a case has been made and defended adequately in open public debate.

What is proposed by Labor is a white man's structure, democratic in white man's terms, but irrelevant to traditional Aboriginal culture or practice. Pastor Paul Albrecht, a distinguished observer whose whole life has been spent with and for Aboriginals, had this to say last year, talking about elected organisations:

These organisations, far from helping Aborigines manage their own affairs, are in fact destructive of what is left of the Aboriginal culture and social organisation because they not only ignore but actively denigrade existing Aboriginal leadership responsibilities and structures.

A second negative effect of this approach to dialogue and self-management is that none of the Aboriginal organisations is accountable to the people they are meant to represent. They are solely funded by government . . . they are elected and operate on non-traditional lines . . . The only claim to Aboriginality they have is that they employ some people of Aboriginal descent.
Pastor Albrecht's view is not based on some theory or ideology. He knows, from a lifetime in the field, what he is talking about. But ATSIC proposes the very course that he has criticised.

Is this what the Government is seeking to do-to destroy what is left of traditional Aboriginal culture and structures? Is this how the Government sees the way to achieving what it wants to achieve? Let me make it quite clear that the responsibility of justifying the Government's course rests with the Government. The pressure for this foolish proposal has come from radical elements in both the white and black communities whose goals relate primarily to the acquisition and use of power. The failure of the Government to make and to sustain its arguments for ATSIC is a fatal flaw in the proposal. For that reason alone, if for no other, the proposal should not proceed. To be in favour of Aboriginal advancement, of greater opportunity, of betterment, of better outcomes, of reduction of disadvantage, does not logically lead to or require any honourable senator here to support ATSIC. To be opposed to the ATSIC proposal does not mean, and should not be so presented, as being against the best interests and the future of Aboriginals. Whether or not the creation of an elected Aboriginal representative body controlling all resources is a good thing, whether or not it will fit better with white perceptions of how things should be done, does not of itself, in any way, promise any benefit to any needy Aboriginal or Islander. These people are, far too often, under educated, unemployed, alienated, deprived, dispossessed and without hope. Any restructuring which fails to deliver better outcomes for these people, the most disadvantaged in Australia, is a restructuring which is not worth pursuing. Labor senators should address this question. They should satisfy themselves before they proceed further that there will be real benefits for all, not just for those who enjoy the ear of the Minister or who might enjoy the spoils of the ATSIC structure. If they cannot see those benefits-and may I say that it is better outcomes that we are seeking, they are the benefits I am talking about and they are the benefits which I believe Senator Coulter is seeking on behalf of the Australian Democrats-then they should withdraw this proposal at least until this most simple and vital threshold question is answered.
In his important newspaper article on ATSIC on 17 December 1988 Paul Kelly quotes a Labor parliamentarian as saying:
ATSIC will be either a disaster or a fraud.
He goes on to explain:

A disaster if the Act works as intended and the Minister lets the councils and Commission exercise their powers; a fraud if the Minister violates the spirit of the Act and relies upon its letter, thereby using his power to direct on a routine basis.

Not only has the Government failed to justify ATSIC, but it has also done something else-this is the second main objection: it has failed to honour one of the few commitments made by Mr Hand on behalf of the Government; that was the commitment to adequate consultations. Oh yes, I know that consultation has been intense; I know that it has been extensive. That does not mean that it was effective and that does not mean that it was adequate.

The evidence before the Committee makes clear that the consultation process was not adequate. Aboriginal community after Aboriginal community, Islander community representatives, and individual people all came to give evidence before us and they told us that the consultations promised had not been carried out, specifically the second round of consultations on the Bill and its details. What they asserted specifically was that there had been some initial consultation, as a result of which agreement for the proposal in principle had been gained. Agreement for an elected representative body was what they had in principle at those early meetings. But it is equally clear from the evidence that they had been promised further consultation on the details of the proposal once those details were available; that had been promised at meeting after meeting. Honourable senators should go to the majority report. We have quotes from the decisions of the meetings. Remember that when the consultations were held there was no Bill for them to see and the Bill now before us is a massive instrument of 103 pages. Further consultations clearly did not occur. They did not occur as promised, or as widely as promised, and, in most circumstances, they did not occur at all.

Among the roles we discharge here, there is the role of trustees of the public interest, in the honouring of which we might have to take the part of the weak against the strong, of communities against government, of the wronged against what Shakespeare called `the calumny of power'. The failure of the Minister to consult Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities about the details of the legislation, as he had promised he would, creates one of those occasions when the Senate should exercise its trustee function. Even if the Senate were disposed to proceed with the ATSIC proposal in some form, our trustee role, in the light of the mass of evidence given to the Senate Select Committee, requires that we not allow that legislation to proceed until the process of consultation has been carried out adequately and in the detail promised. After all, that would require only a few more months, and what are a few months when we are considering a proposal to alter beyond recognition the administration of Aboriginal affairs in Australia and probably to alter it for a long time? This is not a demand that every Aboriginal and every Torres Strait Islander understand every word of every clause of the Bill. That has never been the demand and it will not assist the debate if any honourable senator so seeks to present our call for fair and adequate consultation. But we all know that Aboriginal people have been sold short by the Minister, the Hon. Gerry Hand, on this matter of consultation which he promised them. He promised it publicly and promised it at meeting after meeting.

The minority report is derived from the evidence. It can be understood by reading the evidence. It flows from the evidence, and its conclusions, especially in relation to the unredeemed promise of further consultation, its conclusions about the disgraceful treatment of dismissed acting commissioners, its conclusions about the failure to deal fairly, if at all, with the alternative proposal of the ADC and its conclusions about the failure to make a case for ATSIC-all these flow from the evidence we received. The minority report draws together, in a coherent totality, what the report of the majority failed to do. The conclusions reached in the minority report were the obvious conclusions that should have been reached unanimously and quickly by the whole Committee. I commend those conclusions to the Senate and to the country. As far as we are concerned, the ATSIC proposal as it is presented in the Bill on our Notice Paper is unsafe, unnecessary, unjustified by evidence or logic, dangerous, unlikely to work, unable to be implemented without extensive amendment, unfair to many people and, above all, contains no real expectation that Aboriginal and Islander people will be better off if it becomes law.

In the light of such findings, we can only hope that the Government will think again before it asks the Senate to debate and determine the matter. I say to the Minister, `You have the numbers but you haven't got the right of the argument and you will be very unwise to press ahead'. I say to the Senate that fairness, history, and the hopes of a quarter million disadvantaged Australians demand no less than that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Devlin Sen A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support what my colleagues have said but I would like to express my views of what I have seen and what we have heard from many people who have given evidence. On 1 June last year the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs was established. I believe that it was established by the Opposition-unfortunately with the support of the Australian Democrats-in the hope that it would kill off the Government's proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). Setting up such a committee meant inevitable delays for the Government. Members of the Opposition did not come into this chamber and state their position. They did not come in here and say, `We don't like the ATSIC proposal and these are our reasons'. They did not come in here and say, `Let's debate the legislation and we will make the reasons for our opposition known'. No; instead they said, `Let's set up a Senate committee and in six months time we will let you know what we think'. What we have today is yet another attempt by the Opposition to gloss over the real issues, to smear by rumour and innuendo, to oppose change on the basis that it is radical and far-reaching, and to arrogantly support the continuation--
—Come out with some facts.

—The honourable senator has no facts. The Opposition is supporting the continuation of an administrative system that simply does not work. From the Opposition's point of view it has been a waste of six months.
—Are you talking for the Opposition or the Government?

—The honourable senator knows whom I am talking about. From the Opposition's point of view it is nothing but a political exercise and its dissenting report is absolute evidence of that. The report is based on allegations and rumour and makes much of evidence that was never able to be substantiated. Opposition senators call them serious allegations but they fail to provide anything concrete to back up their assertions. It is just another example of running with the allegations. It does not matter if they are true or not; it does not matter whose reputations they harm; one thing is for sure-they will give a good headline. And is that not what the Opposition is after these days anyway?

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Peter Baume's contribution to this report is most disappointing. It is surprising that someone with his reputation has allowed himself to be part of the Opposition's political campaign against the Aboriginal people. I would like to know what Senator Baume thinks should be the future for Aboriginal affairs administration in this country. His own Party wants to wash its hands of Aboriginal affairs at Commonwealth level. Is that the alternative to the current system, or does the Opposition have a set of options? Perhaps Senator Baume might like to tell us about them today.

The Opposition places a great deal of emphasis on consultation. So does the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand). He has spent more time on the ground than any other Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, talking to people and listening to their views. I would suggest that his consultation process on ATSIC was more extensive than any consultation ever undertaken on any piece of legislation, including the Aboriginal Development Commission Act set in place by the Fraser Government. But, of course, that is not good enough.

The Opposition now insists that the overwhelming majority of Aboriginal people must not only know about ATSIC, agree with it in principle and have the opportunity to make changes, but also know the legislation from cover to cover.

TALK.START.PARA: —What absolute rubbish!

—The honourable senator knows that that is true. Most Australians probably do not know how a piece of legislation is passed, let alone the details of the Bills which will affect them. However, there is a different set of rules when it comes to Aboriginal people. How many people in the Australian Capital Territory have seen the ACT self-government legislation? How many members of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats insisted that they see it? Not one.

SPEECH.PARA: As a member of this Committee I must first acknowledge that the Committee's consultations were not in any way as extensive as those undertaken by the Minister. I must also acknowledge that there is a tendency with committees such as this for people who have complaints to come forward rather than those who are happy with what is proposed. I do not think this Committee is any exception.

There were many parts of the country that we did not visit. We did not travel to Western Australia, the State with the second largest Aboriginal population; nor did we go to New South Wales, Victoria or Tasmania. We must, therefore, accept that there are gaps in the evidence that we have taken and that the evidence of particular individuals does not accurately reflect the majority of views of the Aboriginal community.

The Opposition has made much of allegations of coercion and the offering of enticements. As a member of the Committee, I reject those allegations. Witnesses appearing before the Committee were unable to provide any concrete evidence whatsoever. As a member of the Committee, I hope that all members of the Senate take note of that, especially given the public attention which no doubt will be focused on this institution and the role it performs. Quite clearly, the majority report supports ATSIC. We believe that it is a major step towards Aboriginal and Islander self-determination. It is the only way that governments can proceed and, no matter what sorts of delays are imposed on governments, the demand for change from Aboriginal people will not go away. It is not an issue which can be swept under the carpet or dismissed in a haze of anti-black headlines.

There is overwhelming support for ATSIC, in principle, amongst Aboriginal people. The total rejection of ATSIC by the Opposition is an indication that it does not want to hear what the Aboriginal people are saying to all of us. Members of the Opposition cannot come into this chamber and say honestly that Aboriginal people do not want the sorts of changes that ATSIC embodies. The time for ignoring the views of the indigenous peoples of this nation is over. I support the legislation.
Debate (on motion by Senator Tambling) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I claim to have been misrepresented by Senator Devlin.
—Does the honourable senator seek leave to make a personal explanation?
—Yes.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Devlin said in his remarks that the establishment of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs had occurred with the support of the Australian Democrats in an attempt to kill off the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). That was certainly not our intention. Honourable senators will recall the order of matters that came before the Senate. Firstly, I moved a motion, which received Opposition support, that the ATSIC legislation lie before the Senate for a period of six months so that Aboriginal people and others would have an opportunity to look at it. Subsequently, the Opposition moved a motion establishing a Senate select committee, which I supported simply to give effect to my initial motion-that is, to allow an opportunity for Aboriginal people and others to make representations so that the ATSIC legislation could be improved. I refute completely the allegation that Senator Devlin has made that there was any intention on the part of the Democrats to support the establishment of the Senate Committee as a mechanism merely to kill off ATSIC.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.28 to 8 p.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning I gave notice of a motion to refer certain matters to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I wish to deal with that now. I can either move for the suspension of Standing Orders with all that that entails or I can seek the indulgence of the Senate to do it by leave.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. There is no Minister in the chamber. I do not wish to delay events, but I do not think that the Senate should sit without a Minister. I ask the Government Deputy Whip to rectify that situation.
—He is on his way.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matters be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for inquiry and report on or before the last sitting day of the penultimate week of the 1989 autumn sitting of the Senate:
(a) the adequacy and appropriateness of section 72 (ii) of the Constitution as the only basis on which judges can be removed from office;

(b) the adequacy and appropriateness of the matching provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 for the removal from office of presidential members of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission;

(c) the need for, and type of, alternative mechanisms for the removal of judges from office with paramount regard being paid to the need to protect the independence of the judiciary, the rule of law and the role of Parliament in the process;

(d) the workability and effectiveness of courts and the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission (or the new Industrial Relations Commission) being responsible for the arrangement of their business, with particular regard to the utilisation of all judges on those courts and the role of Parliament, if any, in that arrangement;

(e) whether any charge of misbehaviour or incapacity within the meaning of the Act has been made against Mr Justice Staples, a deputy president of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and if such a charge would be made out to the satisfaction of the Committee;

(f) the compatibility of the Government's method of removing Mr Justice Staples from office with the existing mechanisms for removing judges from office and with any alternative mechanisms which the committee might propose; and
(g) whether any action should be taken to appoint Mr Justice Staples to a position on the Industrial Relations Commission.

The motion that the Australian Democrats gave notice of this morning came at the end-and very nearly at the bitter end-of a very long and protracted wrangle about two important issues: one about the treatment of Mr Justice Staples and the other the associated principle of the independence of the judiciary. A large number of people in the community perceive the treatment that Mr Justice Staples has received at the hands of successive governments as being no more nor less than a breach of the British tradition that Australia inherited where the judiciary was held to be totally independent from the Crown, totally independent and free from interference by the government of the day. That tradition is well entrenched and very valued. There are certainly other countries that deal with judges in quite a different and much less democratic way than Australia has in the past, until this unsavoury incident occurred to tarnish that record. In other countries judges are murdered if their decisions go against the wishes of the reigning government. That has been true, for example, in Pakistan under the rule of the late President Zia; it has been true in the Philippines and in a number of other countries whose commitment to democratic government and the freedom and independence of the judiciary is non-existent in some cases, and certainly not as established as it is within the traditions of the British system.

I think the history of the treatment of Mr Justice Staples is well enough known, but I think it is also worth quickly running through some of the things that have occurred. Let us face it, Mr Justice Staples has made a few statements and come down with the occasional judgment in the past 10 years or so that have met with some displeasure on the part of governments, the business community, the unions and others who are involved in the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and the conciliation and arbitration system that we have in this country. At this stage no suggestion of misconduct or misbehaviour or incompetence has been made with regard to Mr Justice Staples, so as a consequence of his somewhat maverick comments over the years, and for no other reason, he was given only Full Bench work and then for the past three years, no work at all. Now, this has meant that no use has been made of a capable judge and of a judge willing to work. He must be a capable judge or the government of the day would have made allegations to the contrary. He must be a capable judge or he would not have been put there in the first place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that right?
—The Minister asks whether that is right and that, of course, raises the whole question of decisions made by governments.
—People put you and me here. That might not be a very sensible decision.

—Senator Button can speak for himself and leave my supporters to make their own decision. The fact of the matter is that Mr Justice Staples, like other judges, was appointed to this position, presumably because he was considered capable at the time. The fact that he occasionally bucked the system seems to have offended some people mightily and because at that stage nobody could see any way of getting rid of this troublesome judge, they simply gave him no work to do. Then the Government hit upon an expedient which has meant that Mr Justice Staples can be removed absolutely. The history of this man has now culminated in his removal from his position by the device-and it is a device-of getting rid of the old Commission, establishing the Industrial Relations Commission and failing to appoint of all the judges who were on the old Commission, only Mr Justice Staples.

SPEECH.PARA: This went without a great deal of clamour from the legal profession, from the ranks of the judiciary until quite recently when we have seen a flood of objections stemming from academics and from those members of the judiciary and the legal profession whose concerns are centred not only on the treatment of Mr Justice Staples but also on the question of the independence of the judiciary because that is the fundamental point at issue here. Disgraceful though the treatment of Mr Justice Staples is, I suggest the real issue is the setting of a very dangerous precedent indeed, and the threat to the independence of the judiciary that comes in the setting of that precedent. Removing Mr Justice Staples by this expedient has threatened a great deal more than his career. It has placed in some jeopardy, in some question and in some confusion the position of judges elsewhere.

Let us remember that section 72 (ii) of the Constitution makes it perfectly clear that the only way a judge of the High Court or any other court established by the Federal Parliament can be removed is on an address from both Houses of Parliament which alleges misconduct or misbehaviour or some other form of incapacity. If that is not enough then the relevant sections of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act put into place a very similar requirement. The Act provides that a member of the Commission can only be removed on an address praying for his removal on the ground of proved misbehaviour or incapacity being presented to the Governor-General by each House of the Parliament. I do not think anything could be clearer than that, more precise or more ignored by this and previous governments.

The facts are that Mr Justice Staples, as a deputy president of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, had the same rank, status, precedence and title as a judge of the Federal Court of Australia. Recently we have heard arguments about whether a commission is the same as a court, whether a judge on a commission has the same rank as a judge anywhere else, and whether, indeed, he is a judge at all. To his eternal credit, the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), who is in the chamber, stated quite clearly, in answer to a question from me in November last year, that Mr Justice Staples was indeed a judge. However, some people have attempted to muddy those waters. I would suggest that we apply the duck principle here: if it looks like a duck and sounds like a duck, then it is duck. I suggest that Mr Justice Staples, by nature of his title, is indeed a judge and is entitled to the protection not only of the Constitution in so far as it affects him but also more particularly, of those sections of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act that deal with the removal of a judge.

Since those two areas-that is, section 72 (ii) of the Constitution and the relevant sections in the old Act-are pretty much equivalent in that they relate to misbehaviour or incapacity proved and accepted by both Houses of Parliament, I suggest that it does not matter at all whether Mr Justice Staples is a judge as far as the Constitution is concerned or only as far as the Conciliation and Arbitration Act is concerned. He is nevertheless a judge with all the status and precedence and rights of a judge, and deserves to be treated as such. Part of that treatment would involve being removed only on the conditions laid down either in section 72 (ii) or in the relevant areas of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act.

That did not happen. To the best of my knowledge, Mr Justice Staples's behaviour has been as impeccable as that of any other judge. He has not been found incapable of hearing cases either on the Full Bench or individually. He has not been charged with anything. No allegations have been made about him.The only problem with Mr Justice Staples is that he is a nuisance, a maverick, a man who does not toe the line, a man who challenges that nice club-like atmosphere we have seen develop in the last 80-odd years within the ranks of the conciliation and arbitration system-a club-like atmosphere in which the business community, the unions, the Government and anybody else cooperate, shall we say, in a little charade. Mr Justice Staples bucked that system. He challenged the system. Occasionally he argued against the system and he got up everybody's nose in the process. So, confronted with what it regarded as an inconvenient person to have on the Bench-that is, somebody who upsets the applecart and irritates people-the Government just chose to ignore the accepted processes and sought to have Mr Justice Staples removed by other means.

I think this sort of government interference, whether it is done by sleight of hand, as has happened here, or at the point of a gun, as happens in other countries, is intolerable. The present community outcry, late in coming as it has been, indicates that I am not alone in this belief. The Australian section of the International Commission of Jurists spoke out last week in a very long news release on this matter. It said that the Government's treatment of Mr Justice Staples was a dangerous threat to the independence of the judiciary. That is not a group of people to be taken lightly. The news release reported the Secretary-General of the Australian section, Mr David Bitel, as saying:
. . . the treatment of Justice Staples since 1980 raised three fundamental questions about judicial independence.
The bypassing of proper legal procedures to remove a member of a court or tribunal by the expedient of establishing a new tribunal.
I might ask at this point: If the Government gets away with it here, what else will it restructure in order to get rid of minor irritants of this sort? It continued:
The misuse of the discretion to allot work to a member of a court or tribunal.
