The denial of natural justice by the refusal to give any explanation or reasons or to give the person affected an opportunity to answer the allegations against him.

One of the purposes of the Democrats' motion to refer this whole unsavoury affair to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs was to give Mr Justice Staples and his detractors an opportunity to put their respective cases in public, in full, and with the Parliament-or at least the Senate-being an adjudicator. At the very least there would have been an opportunity for a man who has been grossly mistreated to put his case and to get some sort of judgment, redress and justice.

The Secretary-General of the Australian Section of the International Commission of Jurists went on to point out that, in fact, the Government has breached the relevant sections of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act in treating Mr Justice Staples in this way. The news release pointed out that all of this was contrary to a strong legal tradition and convention that when one new court is created in place of another the status and tenure of the members of the old court are respected. They were in every case except that of Mr Justice Staples. I do not think that the Parliament of this country, bound up as it is in the Westminster tradition and the tradition of a truly independent judiciary, should sit back and do nothing about this. A letter to the editor from a number of signatories from the Faculty of Law at the University of New South Wales took up the same issue. The opening paragraphs of the letter state:
The measures adopted by the federal government in removing Mr Justice Staples through a reconstitution of its industrial tribunals deserves censure.
This is not an esoteric wrangle of interest only to lawyers debating the finer points of constitutional law.

Mr Justice Staples was appointed to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, a statutory tribunal, with a statutory tenure which provided for removal only following an address of both Houses of Parliament on the ground of proved misbehaviour or incapacity.

Over the last few months the Opposition has got itself worked up into a right knot over the behaviour of a Minister in this Government, censuring him for all sorts of things, attacking him for a variety of other things, condemning him for still more things; yet it is prepared to sit back and watch the government of the day continue what the Opposition started itself and that is a gross piece of injustice towards a single individual who has no recourse to any other tribunal than the Parliament of this country. The Opposition has indicated that it will not support our proposed reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. Yet all we are asking in this reference is that that Committee, the most appropriate body the Senate has, look at the adequacy and the appropriateness of section 72 (ii) of the Constitution with regard to Mr Justice Staples's position. We ask that it look at the adequacy and appropriateness of the matching provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act which deal, as I and more learned people than I have pointed out, with the removal from office of presidential members of the Commission.

We have asked that the Committee look at the need for and the type of alternative mechanisms for the removal of judges from office, with paramount regard being paid to the need to protect the independence of the judiciary, the rule of law and the role of Parliament in the process. This also involves looking at the workability and effectiveness of courts and the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, or the new Industrial Relations Commission that comes into effect at one minute past midnight tonight, being responsible for the arrangement of their business, with particular regard to the utilisation of all judges on those courts and the role of Parliament, if any, in that arrangement. We went on to ask that Committee to look into whether any charge of misbehaviour or incapacity within the meaning of the Act has been made against Mr Justice Staples, even though we know that the answer is no. We finished with a recommendation that any action that should be taken with regard to Mr Justice Staples be held in abeyance until the Committee had looked at whether he should be appointed to a position on the Industrial Relations Commission.

Those terms of reference sent to that Committee would have gone a long way indeed to determine whether natural justice had been denied Mr Justice Staples. We know that no charge of misbehaviour or incapacity has been made against Mr Justice Staples. We have Senator Button's authority for the fact that Mr Justice Staples is in fact a judge. We have the condition specifically laid down in the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission with regard to the technique needed to remove a member of that Commission.

Most importantly we have to look at the whole question of whether and how a government can interfere with the judiciary-something which most Australians, and I would have thought most members of this chamber, would have regarded as intolerable in any circumstances unless some charge laid had been proved. None of that has happened. Not only has no charge been laid or proven, but disappointingly very few members of this place appear to be at all concerned either about Mr Justice Staples and what has been done to him or, much more importantly than what happens to any single individual in this community, what is being done to the independence of the judiciary.

Although it was surprising that it took so long for individuals and groups in the legal profession to speak out, it is not surprising that they have finally done so. What has happened cannot be ignored. Judges of the Court of Appeal of the Supreme Court of New South Wales, the Australian section of the International Commission of Jurists, the New South Wales Law Society, the Victorian Council for Civil Liberties, 10 judges of the New South Wales District Court, at least one member of the Commission in South Australia, and much earlier, to her eternal credit, Mary Gaudron, have all protested at Mr Justice Staples's treatment and the attack on the independence of the judiciary that is inherent in the treatment of Justice Staples by successive governments. Clearly, an inquiry is imperative but, more importantly, any inquiry that is held has to address the real issues.

Instead, we are confronted with a situation that can only be described as collusion between the Opposition and the Government, culminating in a wimpish cop-out, a motion which was foreshadowed by the Opposition early this afternoon and which, after it has finished opposing our motion, it intends to proceed with, with the full support, I understand, of the Government. The Opposition's motion calls for an inquiry, but it is merely a dumping of Mr Justice Staples, and in doing so is a complete rejection of any commitment the Opposition ever had to the principles of natural justice, to say nothing of the independence of the judiciary. But this inquiry with which the Opposition wishes to proceed is only into the principles governing the security of tenure of office of quasi-judicial officials.

This afternoon Senator Hill moved for an inquiry that would look into and report on the principles that should govern-not even necessarily would govern, but simply should govern-the tenure of office of quasi-judicial and other appointees to Commonwealth tribunals, and in particular whether the provisions of section 24 and 28 of the Industrial Relations Act provide proper and adequate provision for the tenure of office of presidential members and commissioners of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Well, what a big deal! None of that will help Jim Staples. None of that is even necessary. There are provisions in existing legislation and a quite clear statement of principle in our Constitution. The committee that Senator Hill would like to set up will establish nothing except the spinelessness of both the Government and the Opposition-an unpreparedness to look at what they have done not only to an individual judge, but to the whole principle of judicial independence. It is, as I have said, a cop-out, and I would have expected more of the Opposition in this case, given the fact that although Opposition members started this exercise they have not been the ones to finish it.

The Opposition's so-called inquiry into the principles governing the security of tenure of office will lead to nothing. Both parties are aware of that. Any body with any sense is aware of the fact that it will achieve nothing, couched as it is in such vague terms as `should', `maybe' and `perhaps'. It is a pointless exercise that will eventuate at the end of this evening. It is a refusal by the Opposition and the Government to have a real inquiry into the denial of natural justice to an individual and a threat to the independence of the judiciary, and its replacement, instead, with a pathetic excuse of a `maybe' inquiry into the tenure of office of quasi-judicial and other appointees to Commonwealth tribunals.

This has ducked the issue of how effective and appropriate and adequate the existing system is. It has by default argued and defined that judges on the new Industrial Relations Commission are quasi-judicial. This immediately removes them from any protection laid down in the Constitution, put there for High Court judges and other judges appointed to courts established by the Federal Parliament. It is a cynical exercise by both the major political parties in this place to avoid facing up to their responsibilities, and to avoid acknowledging that a grave injustice has been done to one individual in this country, and untold damage done to the judiciary as a whole.

As a further cynical exercise, the proposal is that the Committee should report during the winter recess, thereby neatly cutting it off from any immediate investigation and debate by the rest of this Parliament. It is a cop-out. I suggest that Mr Justice Staples's growing army of supporters and those concerned with the independence of the judiciary, which, as I said at the beginning of my speech this evening is a vital element of our democratic society, will not be conned by this trick. Both the Government and the Opposition are going to be seen for what they are-powerful groups in the Parliament prepared to deny natural justice to an individual in an attempt to tamper with the independence of the judiciary.

There is no acknowledgment in the Opposition's motion that judges and those of equivalent status must be protected from government interference. There is no acknowledgment in the Opposition's motion that the whole basis of our three arms of government depends on this independence. It is, I suggest, the end of what has been a disgraceful episode in Australia's political and judicial history and does no credit to either the Government or the Opposition, because the repercussions of the damage that they are doing this evening to an independent judiciary will probably never be corrected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Haines has alleged that the Opposition is spineless, which is a pejorative remark. I suppose that there are all sorts of things one can accuse people of. One can accuse people of being spineless. One can also accuse people of being mindless and of misrepresenting an issue completely because of some populist view that the issue as presented will find favour in the public mind. Senator Haines really ought to read the Constitution.
—I did.

—Senator Haines did not understand it clearly then, because it says that the justices of the High Court and of other courts created by the Parliament shall not be removed et cetera except by an address from both Houses and so on.
—Bring it before the Senate.

—Senator Coulter should listen for a minute, then he can interject. On 8 November, in an answer to a question misrepresented by Senator Haines on radio this morning, I said exactly the same as Senator Haines has said about the importance of the independence of the judiciary and what that section of the Constitution comprehended. I said that confidence in the judicial system depends on its actual and perceived independence. The Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is not a court for the purposes of the Constitution. I say to Senator Haines and her Australian Democrat colleagues that the fact that somebody is entitled to call himself `Judge' or to be called `Mr Justice' because he has a law degree is not proof of the fact that he is a judge. He is a judge if he exercises judicial power.
—A lot of very eminent lawyers disagree.

—A lot of very eminent lawyers, with respect, are very confused, I think. The contribution to the debate made by Senator Haines has not helped. Senator Haines kept talking about the treatment of Mr Justice Staples. I will come to that in a minute. That is a completely different thing from what we are talking about in respect of this legislation. The treatment of Mr Justice Staples over a 10-year period is a different issue from what we are talking about here, from the nub-what lawyers would call the gravamen-perhaps of Senator Haines's motion. The treatment of Mr Justice Staples is something that I might have personal views about, but they are not relevant to this motion.
—Are they as good as your personal views on interest rates?
—What do you believe to be my personal views on interest rates, Senator, seeing that you have raised the issue?
—I believe what I read in the newspapers-absolutely.

—Obviously. That is very clear. Senator Haines quoted from a whole lot of silly letters in the newspapers. She obviously believes what she reads in the newspapers. I turn to Senator Haines's motion. The Government will not support it because it is a silly motion.
—Yes, it talks about natural justice and the independence of the judiciary.

—I went through it all a moment ago. Senator Haines can be full of good heart and call other people spineless, but if one is mindless oneself that does not contribute much to the sum of human wisdom. This motion from beginning to end is based on some pretty silly assumptions.
—Held by a lot of judges.

—No judge in his right mind would have come up with a motion as silly as this one. There might be a case for a resolution against a judge for incompetence if he came up with a motion like this, because it is quite extraordinary. It goes to the question of what I said a minute ago as to whether Mr Justice Staples is a judge, or was a judge, in the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission just because he was entitled to be called a judge. The answer to that question is no. The Conciliation and Arbitration Commission did not exercise judicial power. If Senator Haines had heard of the boilermakers case--
—Don't drag up the boilermakers again.

—Senator Haines does not want to hear about the boilermakers again. She does not want to hear about anything. She just wants to have a little stunt in the Parliament because she thinks it will be popular. To come to the point of Senator Haines's motion, it assumes certain things which are quite wrong-such as that section 72 of the Constitution applies to the Conciliation Commission. It does not. The motion assumes that this question involves the removal of judges from office. It does not. It goes on to the general question of the workability and effectiveness of courts and the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The Liberals at least have a motion which entitles people to address the workability and effectiveness of the courts as questions of principle. It does not bundle the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in with the courts in the one hit, as Senator Haines's motion has done. Paragraph (e) of Senator Haines's motion-this is the really beaut stuff-talks about `whether any charge of misbehaviour or incapacity within the meaning of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act has been made against Mr Justice Staples'. Senator Haines wants that to be a matter of inquiry by a Senate committee and yet tonight she says that the answer to that question is no. She knows the answer before she has the inquiry. The purpose of having paragraph (e) in the terms of reference is to add a bit of emotive content to what is otherwise a bald and unconvincing narrative.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Haines's motion goes on to talk about `the compatibility of the Government's method of removing Mr Justice Staples from office with the existing mechanisms for removing judges from office'. Last year this Senate passed legislation containing a clause which entitled the government of the day to remove a person from the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. This chamber debated the legislation for 21 hours. Forty amendments were moved. Was there one reference by Senator Haines to this clause affecting Mr Justice Staples being put in that legislation?

Senator Haines talks about people slowly getting on the bandwagon. The people who slowly got on the bandwagon were people like Senator Haines. There were 40 hours of debate in the House of Representatives and 21 hours in here. Did Senator Haines say anything about Mr Justice Staples and the fact that the legislation provided a clause under which he could be removed? Everybody who knew anything about the legislation knew that. There was not a beep out of Senator Haines. It was not the Government that provided the method of removing Mr Justice Staples; it was the Parliament and Senator Haines was part of it. If Senator Haines was not part of it, she was negligent in her duty as a senator. Senator Haines has come in here tonight with this frothed up stuff and introduced emotive language about whether or not Mr Justice Staples was subject to a charge. Senator Haines knows perfectly well what the answer to that is. The Government cannot support this motion because, as I said, it is silly.

I want to get one or two other things on the record. Senator Haines talked about the treatment of Mr Justice Staples. I said that one is entitled to have quite personal views about the treatment of Mr Justice Staples over a long period. Before we go to that issue let us be clear about what happened when this industrial relations legislation was passed. I repeat-it was an Act of this Parliament which determined this issue and there was not a word about it out of the Democrats. When talking about the treatment of Mr Justice Staples the fact of the matter is, as Senator Haines would probably agree, that he has had little useful work to do for nearly 10 years. Only on occasions did he sit on a Full Bench between 1980 and 1986. Since 1986 he has been given no work at all. That was a matter for decision by the President of the Arbitration Commission. Two presidents, succeeding each other, Mr Justice Moore and Mr Justice Maddern, between them decided, in allocating work to the Bench, not to give work to Mr Justice Staples.

Senator Haines might disagree with that decision; a lot of us might. Senator Haines might disagree with it because she might think that the President of the Arbitration Commission of the day did not give work to Mr Justice Staples for some sinister reason, such as him being a maverick as she said. But that is a fact. That first fact has nothing to do, if I might say so, with this Government being in office. The decision preceded this Government coming into office for many years. Governments of the day have no role whatever in the internal administration of the Arbitration Commission. The government of the day is responsible for payments of the judges. Mr Justice Staples was paid throughout his career by the government of the day. But he was not, in fact, allocated work by his boss, the President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, and no government could interfere in that and no government did interfere.

Successive Presidents of the Commission have made these decisions. I have dealt with the assumption, of course, that Mr Justice Staples is a member of the judiciary. Let me make the point that, if one goes back over the history of the so-called treatment of Mr Justice Staples, he has been paid all the time. He has been paid close to $100,000 a year. He has not been allocated work as a result of the decision of the President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission of the day whose function it is to determine whether a member of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is allocated to particular work. That is his responsibility as President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It is not the responsibility or function of this Parliament, or any Senate committee appointed on the motion of Senator Haines, to determine whether a deputy president or a judge, so called, of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission should be given work. That would be real interference in the process which Senator Haines said in the course of her remarks that she objected to most strongly.

The Government's prime concern, of course, is to ensure that the industrial relations system operates as effectively as possible in this country. It is, as I said on 8 November, to ensure the independence of the judiciary; to ensure, as the Constitution provides, that the judiciary is protected in the way which section 72 provides for. But in terms of dealing with this question, the motion moved by Senator Haines does not give a sound basis for looking at some of the general issues associated with this problem; and it is a problem. I would like to think of him as my friend. Jim Staples is a vocal and noisy person. It is a problem in terms of the public arena. That is a fact of life. The motion which I understand is to be moved by Senator Hill comprehends a serious examination of some of the issues. But it is not debauched right from the beginning. It is not contaminated by all of the silly stuff which implies that Mr Justice Staples ought to be the subject of some charge or something like that-all of that silly stuff which is in the Democrats' motion. For that reason we cannot support Senator Haines's little effort tonight. We will, in fact, support the formation of a joint committee to look at this matter as contained in the Opposition's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not especially intended to take part in this debate tonight but I did hear a comment on radio that made me think I should. Having listened to the Democrats' reasons for the motion that they have put forward, I certainly wish to make a few remarks. Although Senator Button has just dealt with the matters I wish to refer to, I think they warrant repeating. Senator Button has referred to the length of time that the Industrial Relations Bill was debated in the Senate last August, and, I think, into September. He referred to the number of amendments that were moved. Most, if not all of them, were moved by Senator Chaney who had the conduct of this Bill for the Opposition. The debate went on for a particularly long time. We have had the Democrats tonight tell us that at last the legal profession and a whole lot of other bodies have sought to speak out on this matter. We have had a very self-righteous presentation of the Democrats' position in relation to Mr Justice Staples. We have been accused of a cop out in relation to the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to the Democrats that if in fact they were serious about this, they had the opportunity to present a case to the Senate last August when the Bill was being debated. I cannot think of one of the amendments that we put that they were prepared to support seriously enough to hold up the Bill for matters they now say that they believe in.

Last August Mr Justice Staples did not matter in the slightest to the Democrats. They had the opportunity then to say to the Government, `We will not allow this Bill to go through; we will join with the Opposition and hold it up until you give us a unequivocal assurance as to the future of Mr Justice Staples'. But it did not matter that much last August when they had the opportunity to do something. Now they come into the Senate tonight and start accusing other people and carrying on.

There are times when I think one can only say it must be very easy to be a Democrat. Tonight has proved that point. They had the opportunity last August to nail their colours to the mast on this matter and actually to do something to pin the Government down. They did not take the opportunity to do so. As I said, I heard the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Haines) on air in Canberra earlier this week speaking about how important it was, about how weak kneed we had been or whatever other adjective she brought to mind at the time. We were very strong on this Bill and our objections to it. No-one in the Senate, but for the Democrats perhaps, could have forgotten the line that we took on it. Now, tonight, we are told that it is so important and that this issue ought to be dealt with in the way that they now propose. I suggest that it is nothing but hypocrisy that it is being given this form of emphasis at this time. They forfeited their opportunity.

Nobody in this place had any doubt about what the Government had in mind for Justice Staples when the matter was debated last year. It was perfectly clear that part of the background of the Bill was to deal with him in the way the Government is now dealing with him, but that was not sufficiently important last August for the Australian Democrats to say to the Government, `You will not get this Bill; we will join with the Opposition to hold it up until such time as you give us an unequivocal assurance as to the judge's future'. We are now subjected to this motion. I shall say no more about it, but the people of Australia are entitled to know the way in which the Australian Democrats behave on such matters as this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of Senator Haines's motion and fully endorse the comments she has made. I am appalled on two levels by what has happened to Justice Staples, both to him on a personal level and with respect to the principle of the independence of the judiciary. In relation to the latter point, I place on record a letter by Judge Allan of the Industrial Court of South Australia. The letter touches upon this matter of principle. The letter, which is addressed to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Prime Minister,

I write with respect to the situation of The Honourable Justice Staples; and I do so for the purpose of raising with you a matter of fundamental importance in relation to the independence of the judiciary; a concept which has always been at the heart of the system of government which operates in this country and one which the Advisory Committee on the Australian Judicial System recently stated to be essential within modern Australia.

The failure by your Government to appoint Justice Staples to the new Australian Industrial Relations Commission, established pursuant to the provisions of the Industrial Relations Act 1988, in the absence of consent on the part of Justice Staples or any other lawful reason is, and must be seen to be, an attack on the independence of the judiciary in this country. As I understand the position, all former members of the old Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, with the exception of Justice Staples, have been transferred or appointed to the new Commission.

The next point made by Judge Allan might be particularly relevant to Senator Button whose casuistry at times surprises me. He described the Commission as not a court for the purposes of the Constitution. If he wants to disregard the Constitution, perhaps he could look at the international conventions. Judge Allan touches on them in his letter, which continues:

Generally accepted international, minimum standards of judicial independence require that the abolition of a tribunal of which a judge is a member should not be accepted as a reason or an occasion for the removal of a judge. The reasons for that would be obvious to you. I respectfully draw your attention to clause 20 of the `Minimum Standards of Judicial Independence' adopted by the International Bar Association in October 1982:

`20 (a) Legislation introducing changes in the terms and conditions of judicial services shall not be applied to judges holding office at the time of passing the legislation unless the changes improve the terms of service.
(b) In case of legislation reorganising courts, judges serving in these courts shall not be affected, except for their transfer to another court of the same status.'

I also refer you to clause 2.39 of the `Universal Declaration on the Independence of Justice' adopted on 10 June 1983 by the World Conference on the Independence of Justice at Montreal, Canada which provides as follows:
`2.39: In the event a court is abolished, judges serving on this court shall not be affected, except for their transfer to another court of the same status.'

Finally, I refer you to principles 1, 12 and 18 of the `Basic Principles on the Independence of the Judiciary' unanimously adopted by the United Nations General Assembly which respectively provide as follows:

`1. The independence of the judiciary shall be guaranteed by the State and enshrined in the Constitution or the law of the country. It is the duty of all governmental and other institutions to respect and observe the independence of the judiciary.
12. Judges, whether appointed or elected, shall have guaranteed tenure until a mandatory retirement age or the expiry of their term of office, where such exists.
18. Judges shall be subject to suspension or removal only for reasons of incapacity or behaviour that renders them unfit to discharge their duties.'

The method adopted to remove Justice Staples would seem to be a deliberate attempt to circumvent the law relating to the removal of a judge in the position of Justice Staples, established convention and the principles to which I have above referred.

All this seems particularly poignant against the background of a history of Australia co-sponsoring and voting in favour of resolutions of the United Nations General Assembly and the United Nations Commission on Human Rights relating to the administration of justice and the importance of an independent judiciary.

I urge your Government to reconsider its position in this matter; and, with the consent of Justice Staples, remedy this wholly undesirable and potentially destructive situation by appointing the learned Judge to the new Australian Industrial Relations Commission. In that way, your Government would be, and be seen to be, maintaining the independence of the judiciary in this country; and would no doubt receive the respect and gratitude of the community therefor.

It is quite clear from what has happened that if any future judge of the Industrial Relations Commission displeases persons outside the Commission, he or she will risk being removed from office and stood in the corner. With respect to the personal effect all this has had on Justice Staples, I quote very briefly from a letter dated 24 November last year that he wrote to the Prime Minister. In part, it reads:

It is little to ask in the light of the disruption to my life and to my reputation that the reaction to my work in a public office appears to have brought on. It is no idle inquiry. I do not believe I have done wrong. Matters have proceeded secretly so far. It is time now for publicity of reasons. Those jumpy phrases the journalists love to cite against me are no explanation sufficient to throw aside relevant legislation and the conventions, to create a precedent for a step of this magnitude. God help the use of language if they do. We shall all impale ourselves on our pens.

My removal from office will be an immense act of defamation. It will compound the loss of reputation I have already suffered in the eyes of people unaware of the facts and who give governments credit for their acts in the absence of cause to the contrary. Whether I deserve it or not, my loss of reputation is a fact which is quite inescapable in my life. the courts have always asked for the justification of defamations which damage reputations. The courts will accept many justifications as of course. All these are rules of common justice. I ask you to set down the justification upon which your government relies for what is projected against me.

I have to go on living in a community which will know I was dismissed. An unexplained dismissal without justification will not reduce the defamation, but rather compound it, for some will sense that my offence was unspeakable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is before the Senate at the moment the motion of the Australian Democrats to refer to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs matters dealing with Mr Justice Staples. I indicate that we will not support the motion, something that I have already indicated to Senator Haines. In view of what the Minister at the table, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, said, the motion will therefore be defeated. I understand that we will then deal with the motion of which I gave notice this morning. That motion proposes to set up a select committee to consider what might be described as some related matters. The committee would look at the principles that should govern the tenure of office of quasi-judicial and other appointees to Commonwealth tribunals. I understand, again from what Senator Button said, that that motion will be carried tonight, although I was also under the impression that the Australian Democrats would support it.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems that I should briefly give the reasons why we cannot support the motion of the Australian Democrats and at the same time very briefly say why we prefer the motion that I will move at the conclusion of this debate. That will then save a subsequent speech and presumably will please the Senate in that way. Senator Haines, in her address tonight, said that there had been collusion between the Opposition and the Government on this matter. That is totally untrue, as she would be aware, as she told us in the debate tonight that she reads and believes what is in the press. The issue has been debated with great care by the Opposition and we have reached certain conclusions that I will enunciate in a moment. Our great area of difference with the Australian Democrats is really what Senator Haines said, and I think I am correct in quoting the words she used in debate tonight. When speaking of Justice Staples she said, `By nature of his title he is indeed a judge'. By nature of his title he is not, in fact, a judge. Perhaps I should really start with the basis of protection of tenure of office of judges of courts of the Commonwealth. That, of course, is the constitutional protection included under section 72 of the Constitution, which provides:
The Justices of the High Court and of the other courts created by the Parliament-

(ii) Shall not be removed except by the Governor-General in Council, on an address from both Houses of the Parliament in the same session, praying for such removal on the ground of proved misbehaviour or incapacity:
Therefore, justices of the High Court-that is not relevant to this debate-or justices of other courts created by the Parliament shall not be removed except by the means I have just expressed.

I do not think anyone is saying that Justice Staples is a justice of a court. He is clearly not a justice of a court. He is a Deputy President-at least until tonight, I think-of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Certain privileges are given to those who hold that office. If they are lawyers they are given the right to use the title `Justice' and they are given that right under section 7 (5) (b), as I read it, of the old Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904, as amended, which says:
any other Deputy President has the same rank, status and precedence as a Judge of the Court.

It does not say that he or she is a judge of the court. Rather, what it says is that he or she is given the same rank, status and precedence as a judge of the court. The matter is really as clear as that. On that basis, we cannot see how the constitutional protection relates to Justice Staples and how it can therefore be said that in some way this matter is evidence of an abuse of the principle of independence of judges of the courts, because, as I said, he is not a judge of the court. The protection of his tenure of office comes from the Conciliation and Arbitration Act itself. His protection is by virtue of that same section 7 of the Act, which says:
. . . shall hold office until he resigns or attains the age of 65 years.
Furthermore:
. . . shall not be removed from office except in the manner provided by this Act for the removal from office of a Judge of the Court.

So while the Commission remains in being, certainly the method for removal of a Deputy President is similar to that for removal of a judge of the court. However, if the Commission ceases to be, then that protection would no longer exist. That certainly seems to us to be the law and, if it is not the law, then we would have thought that Justice Staples by now would have gone to the High Court to seek clarification of that matter of law.

This therefore brings us to the debate about whether any further inquiry is a worthwhile and constructive exercise. We have considered that matter and I want to look briefly at the Australian Democrats' proposed reference to the Senate Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. What the Democrats seeks is in the form of seven clauses. The first matter the Committee is asked to consider states:
the adequacy and appropriateness of section 72 (ii) of the Constitution as the only basis on which judges can be removed from office;

As I have just attempted to argue, Justice Staples is not a judge. It seems to us that section 72 (ii) of the Constitution is not in dispute. We have had debate in this place before, and not all that long ago, as to what is meant by the expression `proved misbehaviour or incapacity', but that does not seem to be relevant to this matter. I do not think anyone has suggested `proved misbehaviour or incapacity' in relation to this matter. So what would be the point in a Senate Committee reviewing a provision of the Constitution which does not seem to me to be in dispute.
The second matter the Australian Democrats would wish the Committee to consider is expressed as follows:

the adequacy and appropriateness of the matching provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 for the removal from office of Presidential members of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission;
Madam Deputy President, as you are aware, this Parliament has voted that body out of existence.

TALK.START.PARA: —As of tonight.

—As of tonight, I understand. So it does not seem to us to serve any constructive purpose to go back and see whether section 7 of that Act, which is about to be repealed, was drawn in adequate terms or whether it should have been drawn in some other terms. It really does not seem to us that that is going to serve any constructive purpose. The Democrats go on in the third paragraph of their motion:

SPEECH.PARA: the need for, and type of, alternative mechanisms for the removal of judges from office with paramount regard being paid to the need to protect the independence of the judiciary, the rule of law and the role of Parliament in the process;

It is our view that judges of the courts should be protected in the way that they are protected by the Constitution. We did not know that that was in dispute. I do not think it is in dispute. Judges of the court should be, and are, in fact, subject to the protection of section 72 of the Constitution and the provisions that require an address from both Houses, `proved misbehaviour or incapacity', et cetera. Again, as it applies to judges, we cannot see that consideration by a Senate Committee of that particular paragraph could be helpful to this Parliament or to the legislative process in the future. The fourth paragraph of the Australian Democrats' motion states:

the workability and effectiveness of courts and the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission (or the new Industrial Relations Commission) being responsible for the arrangement of their business with particular regard to the utilisation of all judges on those courts and the role of the Parliament, if any, in that arrangement;

It seems to us, in that instance, if we talk about the utilisation of judges or the utilisation of presidential officers of these bodies, that that is not a matter for the Parliament and, in fact, it is not a matter for government. In that circumstance, again we have great difficulty in seeing how referring that question to a Senate committee can be helpful in the future in matters relating to this area of the law. The fifth paragraph that the Democrats put in their motion reads:

Whether any charge of misbehaviour or incapacity within the meaning of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act has been made against Mr Justice Staples, a Deputy President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, and if such a charge would be made out to the satisfaction of the committee.

Apart from the question as to whether it is appropriate for the Committee to consider whether there is evidence upon which such a charge could be made out, as I have indicated, as far as I am aware on reading all the papers I can get on this matter, no-one is suggesting a charge in those terms could or should be made out against Mr Justice Staples. So in that circumstance what can be gained from referring such a question to the Senate Committee? Obviously the answer is that no benefit can be gained. The sixth paragraph of Senator Haines's motion reads:

The compatibility of the Government's method of removing Mr Justice Staples from office with the existing mechanisms for removing judges from office and with any alternative mechanisms which the committee might propose;

Again, as I have attempted to indicate in this instance, we are not debating what is the appropriate mechanism for removing judges; we are rather debating what, if any, is the appropriate mechanism for removing these persons who have what might be described as a quasi-judicial status. We think in fact that there is some argument for looking at that question, and that is taken up as the specific reference in the motion that we will be moving in a few moments.
The last paragraph of the Australian Democrats' motion reads:
Whether any action should be taken to appoint Mr Justice Staples to a position on the Industrial Relations Commission.

Of course, it is only the Government that can do that. So we cannot see what can be gained. We cannot even see really how a committee can consider the question as to whether action should be taken to appoint him. Obviously the Committee cannot direct the Government to appoint him.

So, for those reasons it seems to us that although there are very serious matters at issue here, the way in which it is being approached by the Australian Democrats is not the best way to get to the important issues that are involved and, therefore, we propose what we regard as a better way, which is a reference which, as I said at the outset, would look at the principles that should govern the tenure of office of quasi-judicial and other appointees to Commonwealth tribunals and, in particular, whether the provisions of section 24 and section 28 of the Industrial Relations Act provide proper and adequate provision for the tenure of office of presidential members and commissioners of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

As honourable senators will be aware, section 24 and section 28 provide provisions in similar terms to that which I mentioned before for removal of a presidential member from office in relation to section 24 and termination of appointment of a commissioner in relation to section 28; that is, proved misbehaviour or incapacity and that being presented to the Governor-General by action of both Houses of this Parliament acting in the same session.

We think that there is a worthwhile debate for this Senate, a worthwhile matter to be addressed, as to whether that is the appropriate way to deal with those who hold these quasi-judicial offices, not only in relation to the Industrial Relations Commission but also in relation to that whole band of quasi-judicial tribunals that exist under Commonwealth law. Honourable senators would be well aware that the view has been expressed by some that there ought to be some other mechanism short of proved misbehaviour or incapacity. For example, if somebody is appointed under this Act who is clearly incompetent-I am not trying to suggest that that applies to Mr Justice Staples-if government makes a mistake in the appointment, which can occur, and somebody is appointed who is wholly incompetent, should that person in effect be appointed until the age of 65, or should there be some other mechanism that can be taken by government? We would not argue that in relation to a judge because we regard this principle of independence of the judiciary as so paramount to the safeguards of the judicial system of this country that we would be prepared to bear the cost to the community of what might be an incompetent judge. But in tribunals that are not judicial tribunals but are rather quasi-judicial type bodies, should there not be another mechanism? This Committee could consider questions such as that. It could consider whether appointments to such bodies should be for shorter terms so that there would be a reasonable turnover of personnel.

Therefore, we believe that there are a number of constructive questions that would be addressed by the Committee in that debate, and it may well use some of the experiences of the Justice Staples matter as food for thought in consideration as to what the law should provide in the future. But as I have indicated, it seems to us that there is nothing that can be gained from a review of a situation that misconceives that Justice Staples was entitled to the protection afforded to a judge under the Constitution. So for those reasons we will be opposing the Australian Democrats' motion and when, as we anticipate, that is defeated, I will be moving the Opposition's motion and seeking support for it.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Haines's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: TENURE OF OFFICE OF APPOINTEES TO COMMONWEALTH TRIBUNALS: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE

PROCTEXT.PARA: (1) That a joint select committee be appointed to inquire into and report on the principles that should govern the tenure of office of quasi-judicial and other appointees to Commonwealth tribunals and in particular whether the provisions of sections 24 and 28 of the Industrial Relations Act provide proper and adequate provision for the tenure of office of Presidential members and Commissioners of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

(2) That the committee consist of 9 members, 3 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Government Whip or Whips, 2 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Opposition Whip or Whips, 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and 1 Senator to be nominated by any minority group or groups or independent Senator or independent Senators.
(3) That every nomination of a member of the committee be forthwith notified in writing to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives.
(4) That the committee elect a Government member as its chairman.

(5) That the committee elect a deputy chairman who shall act as chairman of the committee at any time when the chairman is not present at a meeting of the committee and at any time when the chairman and deputy chairman are not present at a meeting of the committee the members present shall elect another person to act as chairman at that meeting.
(6) That 4 members of the committee constitute a quorum of the committee.
(7) That the committee have power to send for persons, papers and records.
(8) That the committee have power to move from place to place.
(9) That the committee report by 30 June 1989.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now move, at the request of Senator Chaney:

SPEECH.PARA: That the motion of which Senator Crowley gave notice earlier this day, relating to domestic violence, be taken to have been moved and have precedence over all other business this day till determined.

The matter that we wish to have debated now is this notice of motion given earlier this day by Senator Crowley that sought to malign me, in this instance, by suggesting that I regarded domestic violence as a soft issue. I propose to demonstrate the urgency of that matter and why it should be debated this evening by the Senate. In fact, the matter is regarded by us as so urgent that we would have moved this way earlier in the day but for the months of work that have been put in by honourable senators on a number of important Senate committees, in particular the one relating to Aboriginal affairs. The Senate was to receive those committee reports today, and honourable senators intended and desired to speak to them.

I put it to the Senate, Mr President, that this is a matter of urgency partly because of the terms in which Senator Crowley's motion is expressed. The motion is a personal attack upon another senator that should not be allowed to lie in the Notice Paper, perhaps indefinitely as is often the case in these matters. Clearly, it should be dealt with expeditiously and the most expeditious way in which it can be dealt with is to deal with it tonight. The second reason for urgency, apart from the personal maligning that is included within its contents, is that it is obviously designed to divert attention from what is becoming apparent in this country, and that is, the very serious decline in the economic status of women. From this morning's newspapers we found that the Government in its Caucus yesterday had been debating the serious lowering in the polls of its standing in the eyes of women. The Government, in its usual diversionary way, tried to suggest that this was a result of the uncouth language and behaviour of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), which was an interesting way to divert attention from the somewhat patronising attitude of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to women. In fact, it is apparent to all of those who have been listening to women's organisations in this country, and particularly to individual women, that their real concern is the drop in living standards and the difficulty of economically sustaining themselves and their families which is not being given proper recognition or support by this Government. So we have this diversionary tactic into areas that this Government clearly knows are untrue in order to cover up in some way for this failure and this inadequacy.

The matter is obviously urgent to Australian women. If the economic concerns were not of such urgency, then we would not find such ridiculous motions being put to the Senate by Senator Crowley this afternoon. I would have thought that Senator Crowley, like most other senators, would not think that I would possibly condone domestic violence which I, as much as anyone else in this chamber, regard as abhorrent. I would not have thought that we would find her attempting to use the forms of this House to divert the debate on status of women to such matters or that we would find the Prime Minister trying to allude that the drop in the standing of the Australian Labor Party in relation to women's affairs was in fact related to the foul language that is used by his Treasurer, although there is no doubt that such foul language is not appreciated by the women of this country.

When we speak to women's organisations in Australia we find that poverty and lowering of standards of living are their principal concerns and matters of great urgency to them. This becomes relevant to the debate on domestic violence. As Senator Crowley would no doubt know because she has an interest in this area, women's refuges in this country are now being flooded not only by women who are there as a result of some domestic crisis but also by women who are in poverty, who simply cannot afford housing in the city and who are looking for somewhere else to turn or, alternatively, by women who have become part of this process of de-institutionalisation-I think that is the word. These are women who come out of institutions such as prisons, mental hospitals or some other form of hospital, because of government policies-and in some ways these are sensible government policies. Instead of the Government providing half-way houses and appropriate support mechanisms for such women, there is no alternative for them but to turn to women's refuges that were created for an entirely different purpose. We find the refuges flooded. We find that the women who are running these refuges are now coming to the Opposition and saying that the Government is putting them in an impossible position, but it is all related--

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the honourable senator debating the urgency motion?
—Yes, the urgency motion. Senator Haines could help us out very easily.
—Get on with it.
—Are the Australian Democrats prepared to support the suspension?
—Yes, of course we are.
—Good; I will finish there.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Original motion taken to have been moved accordingly.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that Senator Crowley might argue that she should speak first because this was her motion. However, I am on my feet and she does not wish to rise. As Senator Crowley decided to take this diversionary tactic earlier in the day, it seems an opportune moment for us to talk about the very real problems being faced by Australian women at the moment. It is also an opportune time to point out the disappointment that Australian women are now showing with this Government. This Labor Government built very high expectations among women's organisations in this country and it did so in the form of identifying a number of areas of difficulty or concern to women, and building these issues through high level publicity campaigns. Now the women's organisations are finding that those expectations are not being met. As they are not being met there is growing disillusionment with this Government among Australian women. We will hear more of this when Senator Walters's Bill comes on relating to the attitude of women's organisations to pornographic videos, the business of which is supported by the Government through its legislative framework in the Australian Capital Territory. The ACT is becoming the headquarters in Australia of the pornographic video industry-an industry which so demeans women.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at areas such as health, we find the profile of the health issue was raised by Labor's publication, Women's Health: A Framework of Change which sets out the problem areas. However the women's organisations are waiting for a detailed response from the Government. Rural women have been identified as a particularly neglected group and the booklet Life has never been easy was published setting out the issues. But a response to the issues has yet to be forthcoming from this Government. We had the experiences of the Women in Advertising conference, a project which has now been going for some years and what has been disappointing is the lack of--

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't know what you are talking about.

—I am pleased that the Minister for Local Government has come into the chamber tonight. It is more than she does on the video debate. It will be interesting to see whether she will stand up in that debate when it comes on. The Opposition has supported the raising of the status of women in advertising and the avoidance of the stereotyping that occurs in that area. However, after a great deal of money had been spent and conferences had been held, very few substantive results followed. Let us move to consideration of the National Agenda for Women which followed what was probably the most comprehensive survey ever conducted to identify what women regard as--
—I am glad you acknowledge that. You didn't do anything about it.

—If the Minister listens for a while she might learn something. The National Agenda for Women followed the most comprehensive survey on identifying what women regard as the key issues. We found that the agenda sets broad and perhaps often bland parameters without the detailed policy prescriptions that Australian women expected. What we have found is that in each of these exercises, as I suggested, there has been a sophisticated public relations campaign emphasising a government that is actually achieving something. What is happening is that Australian women, particularly through their organisations, are now saying, `Where is the performance that matches this rhetoric?'. Expectations have been built but they are not being met in practice.

SPEECH.PARA: One can go on to the area of legislative and award restrictions. I remind Senator Reynolds of the conference in 1986. It seems that only now is the Government again addressing itself to the restraints within awards that disadvantage women, particularly in relation to part time work. There was an expectation that there would be significant and widespread changes in awards that would provide opportunities for part time work for Australian women, but those reforms in the award system simply have not occurred.

As Senator Reynolds will know, migrant women were given a high priority in 1985 with the national conference on immigrant women's issues. Until the end of last year, when Senator Reynolds decided to hold another mini-conference, very little occurred in the meantime. Women are disappointed with the lack of response by the Government and are now starting to recognise the initial conference and the lack of progress that followed as simply a confidence trick. We should consider the shameless way in which the Office of the Status of Women is used by this Government to promote its image when the perception is given-with the dismissal of heads who do not totally toe the line-to Australian women that in some ways it is offering independent advice and providing some form of safeguard. Those who work within that Office clearly would like to assume that responsibility, but this Government does not give them that responsibility; rather it uses them to promote its image.

That Office had chosen for it as its two major current projects the women in advertising project and the domestic violence project. I have said that the Opposition supports the women in advertising project. I said so at the recent Sydney conference, and Senator Reynolds knows that when the project commenced the then Opposition spokesman in this area also joined in supporting the project. We also support any real efforts that are made to reduce domestic violence within our community, which I and everyone in the Opposition would regard as abhorrent. However, we have been somewhat disappointed with progress in that area. I think that is coming through to the women's organisations, which do such magnificent work in this area. What we have seen is a three-phase project. The first phase is to run more surveys to identify the problem; the second phase, which is the one we are in now, is the educative phase.

We support April being designated as the month of awareness for domestic violence, but when we speak to women's organisations they say that they want more work done on the causes of domestic violence and more effort and resources put into supporting those who are abused by domestic violence. Particularly, they express concern of a linkage between the growing levels of domestic violence and the growing levels of what might be described as family poverty within our community. They say to us and no doubt to the Government, which is turning a blind eye, `The lack of support for families inherent in this Government's policy is placing greater stress on families'. Some feel that that is related in some way to the ever increasing level of domestic violence in our community. They say to us, as they no doubt say to the Government, `Why will this Government not give greater support for families to try to relieve some of that economic stress?'. It is an interesting debate because the first charter of the Office of the Status of Women is, in fact, to improve the financial independence and the financial security of women. But the Government seems to have given that a lower priority. We support the other projects, but what this Government has been able to do is camouflage its lack of progress in the critical area of financial independence and financial security of women by diverting attention to other areas.

When we talk to women they remind us-and this is in the statistics to which the Government has access-that, although there has been greater access by women to employment opportunities, there is very little evidence of vertical improvements in women's occupations. More women are coming into the work force but their progress up the ladder to higher paid jobs that will give them greater financial security and independence has been disappointing. Perhaps the worst example is within the Government's own bailiwick. When we look at its performance in relation to the Senior Executive Service of its own Commonwealth Public Service, which I think Senator Reynolds tried to explain away at the end of last session, we see that in the last year there was an increase in the number of women at that level of the Public Service of only 0.1 per cent. So there has been near enough to no improvement in that level of the Public Service. Australian women are becoming somewhat irritated by this because expectations had been built and they are not being realised.

As well as failure in the area of vertical improvement in employment of women, there is also the extremely disappointing factor of so few moving into fields of work beyond the traditional areas of employment. I would be concerned, as Senator Reynolds should be concerned, that when Australian companies provide apprenticeship positions for girls and young women in non-traditional areas and they are not being taken up in areas of extremely high unemployment for women and girls, there is a major problem. What has this Government been able to achieve in that area? It would seem very little.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing.

—Senator Walters says, `Nothing'. I think she is probably right. Moving to the very high profile of the Affirmative Action Agency, I support efforts to educate business within our community to its responsibilities and, in fact, the material gains that can come to business from giving greater and better opportunities for women, ensuring that they are in an educational position to compete properly and contribute to individual work forces to their maximum capacity. But to get real, hard information as to what improvement there has been, notwithstanding the Affirmative Action Agency, is very difficult. All that the last annual report of the Affirmative Action Agency really demonstrates to those who read it is that large businesses, as it then was-it has now come to the next category of business as well-have cooperated with the forms required under the Act. But are women actually getting to the higher positions of employment within large firms? The evidence is there that movement has been very slow, and women's organisations are expressing their disappointment. If Senator Giles can produce figures to us tonight demonstrating that there are material gains arising from the project, there will be nobody in this place more pleased than I. What it does, in effect, is enable the Government to claim that results are being achieved. All it really proves is that the forms are being complied with. If the Government wanted to achieve something it would start within the province that is totally within its control, which is the Commonwealth Public Service. It has failed totally in that area.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps we can give the Government some indication as to what women's organisations are telling us are the high priorities. They all relate primarily to this area of financial independence and financial security. They are still coming to us expressing concern about failures in child care and lack of access to child care places. The complaint is that such places are too expensive and that this inhibits women's capacity to take employment, particularly more responsible employment. The Government's response in this area is not regarded by those organisations as adequate.

Women in employment are coming to us and asking why they cannot be given an equal opportunity in relation to other benefits of employment such as superannuation. Clearly they are not being given those benefits. Our superannuation laws have been structured on the basis of someone who remains in employment continually rather than of someone who may come into employment for a significant period, but then leave to meet other responsibilities such as perhaps bringing up children. The women's organisations are asking why this Government will not do something about that situation. Why in relation to disability insurance do women have to pay premiums almost twice as high as those paid by men? What has this Government done in that regard? The answer is that it has done nothing. Women are complaining because the Government built such high expectations. They have come to us complaining about the lack of educational opportunities for training and retraining to enable women to rise to higher paid places of employment rather than simply be employed in the more lowly paid places of employment, which keeps them in the status of economic poverty or near economic poverty. We should tell this Government that one can be employed but still be in poverty-a fact which this Government seems to have forgotten.

The women's organisations still come to us complaining about a lack of flexibility in employment hours and lack of opportunity in regard to permanent part time work. The women's organisations are particularly coming to us now complaining about a lack of affordable housing. This Government should appreciate the position in which women are now being placed, particularly women who are supporting children but other women, too-under this Government's policies, which have put housing beyond the reach of those people. Interest rate policies immediately come to mind.

The other area in which women's organisations primarily come to us to complain about is the cost to families who are on one income and as to whether they can afford to bring up children. If this debate serves any purpose tonight, it will do so if it brings home to this Government, during its last few months of office, how families on low incomes are now suffering in trying to bring up children. Families are having to make the decision that they cannot afford to have children because of the incomes they have and the lack of family support given by this Government pursuant to its deliberate policies which leave women in no position to support children. This is the message that is coming through to us and it should be coming through to this Government. I hope that we can get it through to the Government tonight.

When the Government identified some groups of women who are in particular difficulty they were identifying correctly, but with all the benefits of being in government, that much at least could be achieved. When the Government was prepared with the Country Women's Association to look at the particular problems of rural women, it was tapping into a sector of the community who have been disadvantaged over a long time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under your Govern- ment.

—The Minister should remember that the Labor Government has been in office since 1983. She should not start the Senator Walsh game of going back to the times of previous governments. Labor has now been in government long enough to be able to stand up and justify its own achievements, and they simply do not exist. All the Government has done in relation to rural women is to identify them as a problem area, and particularly identify the problems of isolation, the fact that such women have a lack of work opportunities, and that rural women are particularly concerned about the lack of educational opportunities for their children. When those women have to send their children to the cities to get a comparable education, the Government chops back on Austcare.
—Don't you mean Austudy?

—Austudy. I thank the Minister. That is very constructive and helpful. The Government has also chopped back on the isolated child's allowance. That is the contribution of this Government which the Minister might stand up and try to argue is constructive and helpful. But if the Minister talks to rural women, she will find an area of great disappointment in terms of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The other area which the Minister identified correctly as suffering particularly, and which in many ways has been abused by this series of conferences which have produced so little, is that of migrant women. Such women have suffered a different form of isolation but nevertheless just as real. They have also suffered from a lack of community awareness of the particular problems they face. It is about time that this Government faced up to those particular difficulties and did something constructive rather than simply talk about the problem. I turn to the next area or grouping of women who could be identified as facing particular problems which has also been overlooked by this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —When are you going to come to your position on domestic violence?

—I thought that I had done so. I said that I abhorred domestic violence. Why does the Minister not listen? Furthermore, we said that if more resources were put into identifying the causes, and if more resources were put into family support, the Government would be doing something constructive. Certainly if more resources were being put into supporting those who are abused rather than into running publicity campaigns, the Government would be doing something worthwhile for those who are suffering in that way. What is needed is less public relations and a little more constructive effort.
—Action!

—Or, as my colleague suggests, action. I also wish to refer to aged women, who have been neglected by this Labor Government. Suddenly the Government has become aware of this problem through its surveys, as has happened in the last few days when it has been disclosed that Australian women are rejecting this Government. Suddenly the Government has become aware that the aged are angry at the lack of concern and consideration they have received from this Government. I remind Senator Reynolds of a fact of which she should be aware-namely, that the majority of aged people are women who are particularly suffering from this Government's policies or lack of them.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to give others the opportunity to participate in this important debate on the failures of this Government in relation to the status of women, particularly the Government's failures in relation to its responsibility. The Government had accepted the responsibility of lifting the financial security and financial independence of women. But it is not just I who stand here this evening saying that Australian women are disappointed in this area. It is being said by Australian women. This Government should be aware that women's organisations, on which not many years ago the Labor Government thought it had a mortgage, are now looking for alternatives. They are tired of the rhetoric, the publicity, the public relations campaigns. What they wanted is real performance in these areas to match the rhetoric, and it has not been forthcoming. My last word is that if this Government did more about family support, that would be the area which would be of greatest benefit to the majority of Australian women.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall address the motion in more detail when it is returned to me in a few minutes.
—It's your motion.
—Apologise to Senator Hill.
—I would ask Opposition members to allow me to make my own speech. It will be seen that in the first words of the motion I refer not to Senator Hill, but to his remarks.
—What is the difference?

—Because the motion does not go to the person, but to his comments. There is a clear distinction that should be drawn. Secondly, although Senator Hill criticised me for not giving him notice, the same might be said of him. However, that is somewhat petty. I heard Senator Hill say that he presumed that I had got the information from the National Media Liaison Service. He is, of course, again quite wrong. It was a good guess, but quite wrong. The matter was drawn to my attention by a constituent who wrote to me enclosing some references, to the best of their recollection, from a radio interview with Senator Hill subsequent to the press comment. I had received a transcript of a radio interview. I concluded from that that Senator Hill had made those remarks and was taking the opportunity to get it straight on radio. If that is not the case, I beg Senator Hill's pardon. I was, as my colleagues were, somewhat surprised that Senator Hill would have been so flippant about domestic violence as I had not understood that to be his attitude. The transcript led me to believe that Senator Hill had made the remarks that were attributed to him in the newspaper. Inasmuch as that has been corrected by Senator Hill, I accept his accounting of how that happened.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's conclusion that domestic violence is not a matter of great importance for women is a terrible conclusion to draw. We have had to address seriously the issue of how to manage the question of domestic violence.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a matter of great concern to us; we have said that.

—Indeed, the Opposition has said that. We appreciate that the Opposition has now joined us in understanding how appalling domestic violence is. Senator Hill seems to suggest that we should address the causes of domestic violence as though he understands what the causes of domestic violence are. The Opposition often offers a simplistic solution for the causes when quite clearly there is evidence that the causes are very complex. If anyone knew what the causes of domestic violence were I suppose that we could proceed to address them. But to suggest that household economic constraints are the cause of domestic violence is to be wildly wrong and demonstrates a wildly insufficient analysis. If Senator Hill understood anything about domestic violence he would understand that it occurs both in families that are poor and in families that are very wealthy. It occurs in families that have no economic constraints on them and in families that do.

SPEECH.PARA: To suggest that economic constraints, if they exist at all, are a cause of domestic violence shows an insufficient analysis. If Senator Hill says that is the case, do we conclude, therefore, that wealthy men commit domestic violence for entirely different reasons? I suggest that the causes of domestic violence are much more complex than indicated in the simply analysis made by Senator Hill. The Government cannot address the causes of domestic violence in a simplistic way because they go to the motives, attitudes and behaviour of people. The Government is addressing the issue seriously by saying to the community, `No longer will this community allow domestic violence to go on'. This Government has gone on the record as saying that. It is taking the issue so seriously that it has set aside a month specifically to address the issue of domestic violence. It has a campaign going. It is taking up the public acknowledgment that domestic violence is not tolerable, that it is not acceptable. The Government will not accept it and it is saying that it will take further steps to address it. Already it is taking steps, but it is now concerned to make quite clear to this community that domestic violence is appalling and is not acceptable to this Government. If the Opposition shares our attitude we would be pleased to accept its contribution.

Senator Hill also says that addressing the domestic violence problem with a public education campaign is insufficient. That would seem to me to be falsified by his own evidence. Would he say that we should not have an education campaign addressing the question of AIDS? Would he say that the AIDS campaign has done nothing to help the community understand the significance of that problem? Is he not aware that one of the biggest problems associated with domestic violence is that people do not really believe that it happens; people do not really believe that it is as bad as we say; and people do not really believe that women are belted up, smashed up, and delivered with broken noses and arms to the casualty wards of hospitals, where I have served, or take themselves to women's shelters which the Government has funded and which, at last, provide them with a haven and a place to go to.

We have addressed the problem. The first thing we did was to acknowledge that it existed. We women have brought it to the attention of government. Secondly, the Government has taken any number of steps to address the problem. Senator Hill says that we should do more by way of providing services. This Government has funded shelters. We introduced the supported accommodation assistance program. Funding for shelters has dramatically increased, precisely because this Government takes the issue seriously; precisely because the Government knows the costs down the line, the costs to people of what happens when a family is smashed up-the cost of individual misery, the cost to the children, the cost to a bloke who may be out of work, the cost to the taxpayers of funding shelters. These things are understood and appreciated. These measures are in place.

Senator Hill's arguments on this issue are spurious in the extreme and very wrong. The Government recognises the problem. It appreciates that much more has to be done in the way of community education to make people in the community aware of the size and significance of domestic violence, of how totally unacceptable it is and how it has to be addressed with all sorts of programs and steps. But we cannot do that if people do not know the problem exists. The steps are already in place in any number of States and Territories. I remind honourable senators of the changes introduced by the domestic violence ordinance in the Australian Capital Territory, which has been in place for six to 12 months already and which, from all accounts, is working very well. That does not stop domestic violence, but it intervenes and addresses the problem much more efficiently, immediately and successfully that has been the case in the past.

Governments have not been able to deal with domestic violence because there has been confusion between Commonwealth and State. Should the State police interfere?
