Should the Commonwealth police interfere? Whose jurisdiction is it? Women were advised to take out injunction orders: `You can get an injunction order that might protect you'. We all know how difficult it is for people to get injunction orders. There is a time constraint. There is a possibility that the injunction will be broken, and it is clearly understood by many women who have been beaten, psychologically stood over, had their windows broken and so on that an injunction is not very much protection.

Over the years women have sought the protection and assistance of the shelter movement. More than 85 per cent of residents in the shelter movement are women who have come because of domestic violence. If one understands, from talking to women working in the shelter movement, the history and pattern of people who come to the shelter movement, one will know that certainly we on the Government side are acutely alert to the pattern of behaviour in domestic violence and to the best ways of dealing with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Family stress is a cause.

—Family stress may be a cause, but there are thousands of families in this country that are stressed and whose members do not resort to violence on each other. There are thousands of families who cope with stress in an adult and mature way. We are talking about a selective group of people who choose to commit domestic violence. In my own State of South Australia there are now committees-one emerged out of the community health centre at Clovelly Park where I worked; I know the people involved very well-providing voluntary assistance to the perpetrators of violence, violent men who have come to discover that they can solve problems when they are angry by means other than their fists. That is something that is under way, something that has already been done. Does Senator Hill know about it? It is happening in his own State. If he does not know about it, I refer him to the excellent first piece of research emerging from that domestic violence counselling unit. Mr Reg Branch and his colleagues produced a report the other day.

SPEECH.PARA: Domestic violence is understood by the Government. The Government is also aware that domestic violence is not understood in the community. That is why the Government has taken this issue so seriously. The other reason the issue is being taken so seriously is that the women of Australia have raised it. The women of Australia have said, `Violence is not acceptable. We do not want to be thumped when we walk down the streets. We do not want to have our handbags stolen. We do not want to have burglars breaking into our houses and committing crime and violence. We do not want to be beaten up in our own homes. We do not want psychological or domestic violence'. It is the women of Australia who have put this issue on the national agenda and asked the Government to take it seriously. It may not be the highest priority economic issue for women but anybody seriously addressing women's issues will listen to what women say. They say domestic violence is abhorrent and appalling. They say, `How come we cannot feel safe in our own homes? Is this not the society that talks about peace and protection? Please, can you let people know the extent of domestic violence and can you let them know the steps that you are already taking and the further steps that have to be taken to address this problem?'.

Domestic violence is an absolutely appalling problem. Those of us who have been working with victims of domestic violence have seen how women with the protection and support of the shelter movement have emerged through domestic violence. They have come back into the world as sufficient and confident women again and have been able to provide that care and support for children that the Opposition talks about. These are some of the matters in the domestic violence area that we on the Government side know because we have travelled very closely with it. We have campaigned and fought for domestic violence to be on the agenda for at least the last 10 years and probably the last 15 years, since domestic violence emerged as an issue in the original shelter movement. That material is well known to government. That is the sort of funding that the Government has put into the domestic violence area. That is the sort of attention the Government has paid to it. That is why there have been legislative changes under family law. That is why there have been consultations between the Commonwealth and the State law enforcement agencies, which are addressing this issue so seriously.

Only the other day I had a briefing along with a number of other citizens in South Australia by the South Australian police force. The issue of community services and, in particular, domestic violence is of such great importance that it made the agenda in a three hour briefing by the South Australian police force. The appalling fact is that the majority of women in this country who are murdered are murdered in a domestic violence situation. If one asks the police what is the most hazardous part of police work they will say it is attending domestics, as they are called. We have to acknowledge that and not keep pushing it aside and sweeping it under the carpet.

Senator Hill, this domestic violence campaign is no soft option. It is now moving forward to a public campaign that must go with the other steps that are being taken so that people will know that domestic violence is not acceptable. They will know that there are places where people can go to seek assistance and help. It would be much better if a man actually sought help before he thumped than after the event.

I found it quite remarkable that Senator Hill used my notice of motion to run through the latest litany of the women's policy proposed by the Opposition. In fact what Senator Hill said was not bad stuff, I suppose, for a late night political speech. That is about all it is good for. It was fraught with just about every inaccuracy that those of us on this side have had to give the flip to. I say to Senator Hill that for the first time ever on the record, 50 per cent of students completing Year 12 in the secondary schools around Australia are girls. For the first time ever, more than 50 per cent of students in the tertiary institutions in this country are women. Of the more than one million jobs created since this Government came to office, in those six years in which Senator Hill said we have done nothing, 58 per cent of those jobs have been taken by women. What better way to address the poverty of women, the poverty of their lives, than to give them a job so they can get off welfare and get into the work force and can manage for themselves with increased confidence and can better able attend to the needs of their children. They can do this because they are now citizens in an active and alive world. They are not locked out of it by being denied anything more than an ongoing life of perpetual poverty on a pension.

It is vital that people who do not have the opportunity or, yet, the choice to take that step are supported by the pension. I note that that pension has increased in real terms since we came into government. It is also true that nobody would prefer to live out his or her life confined to the restrictive income of a pension. Many women in the circumstances that I have described have taken the opportunity to take up the jobs that are now available to them. What does Senator Hill mean when he says that we have not had achievements for women? What Senator Hill is saying is extraordinary. He says that we have created expectations. You bet we have! The women of Australia for the last 80 years had no expectations. In seven years of Fraser, what did that Government give them? It gave them no expectations. We are delighted that we have created expectations and we are meeting and fulfilling them. If women are coming back to this Government and saying, `We want further attention', I say, `Thank God we now have in this country a women's movement that is vocal, that is organised, that is coherent, and that can actually speak for itself to government'. That is something that was not available to women in times past. Women did not have educational opportunities in past times.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Settle down.
—Thank you very much, Senator Giles. It is wonderful when Opposition senators all stop and I can just talk instead of trying to be heard over them.
—I just suggested that they relax.

—That is excellent. Do speak them back into their chairs more often. Women actually have opportunities. Women actually have a voice. They have a government that listens. They have an extended consultative mechanism-the National Women's Consultative Council. It continues to provide avenues by which women will bring to government their preferred options, their new steps and their indications of extra needs.

SPEECH.PARA: Some years ago, women did not speak to government. In fact, women did not speak for themselves. Gentlemen and Senator Newman, were you not around in the 1950s and 1960s? That is when there was no women's movement. That is when women did not have a voice. That is when women did not have access to jobs, let alone the prospect of rising because of the Affirmative Action Agency, to more senior positions in the public and private sector. I pick up on this point. Senator Hill says that the Affirmative Action Agency is very nice but, by and large, what it is doing is getting people to fill in the forms. Has Senator Hill seen the forms?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have.

—Has Senator Hill noticed that for the first time ever all those firms and educational institutions are required to say how many men and women are in the work force and at what level are those women in the work force? In 12 months time and in two years time when they have filled in those forms, it will be interesting to say, `But firm Y, college Z, your figures remain the same, your affirmative action program is not effective'. One cannot say that the first time around. What is being collected at the moment is base data. We also have the Affirmative Action Agency establishing the other points under that legislation that are required, that is, that there be an affirmative action person appointed, that there be an affirmative action program, that there be consultations with the unions and workers involved, if there is no union, that there be consultation with managers and that steps be put in place to address these questions.
—Why do you think your women's vote is slipping?

—I am delighted that Senator Hill thinks that if he ever got into government he could have done all of that in six months. What we have to say to this point is that the Opposition has never even considered this matter worthy of legislation. It took this Government to introduce affirmative action legislation. What is more is that it did that in a way that enjoyed the support of the private and public sector, that is, because of comprehensive consultation and a program of outlining the best model to work with. In fact, I would have thought that the affirmative action legislation would be something that Senator Hill would be celebrating. It takes into account many of the points which he raised about the importance of the involvement of all those concerned-in this case, employers and workers-working the situation out together. But if Opposition senators criticise the Affirmative Action Agency as being nothing more than tinsel because all it does is have people fill out forms--
—I didn't say that, did I?
—Senator Hill did say, as I heard him, that all it has is a report that says essentially what people are doing is filling out forms.
—What I am saying is that there is no evidence of any substantive result. That is why women are getting angry.

—That is to misjudge what it is about. There is evidence. I will not draw it to Senator Hill's attention tonight; but I will recite for him one other piece of data that might have slipped his memory. In January for the first time ever the labour force participation rate of women was 50 per cent.
—Because they are broke; so are their families. Why else do they do that? You silly woman! Don't you understand? They have to have another income.
—We now have more opportunities. Women are now working in a larger sphere than ever before. Senator Newman's criticism is--
—There are too many interjections. In such an important debate there is soul in the occasional interjection. However, we will listen to Senator Crowley in some silence.

—I am appreciative, Mr Acting Deputy President. Senator Hill with a remarkable sweep of logic wandered around suggesting that women were not in the work force and that was a tragedy. I point out that women are in the work force. Almost in anticipation of that little defence he said, `Ah, yes, but they're not in senior positions. You've got this other thing called the Affirmative Action Agency and women aren't there in the senior positions-have a look at the Public Service'. Indeed, let us look at the Public Service. Let us look at it 10 years ago. In one year there was a 0.1 per cent increase. I might say we are delighted that Senator Hill is concerned about it. Those of us on the Government side have been concerned about that for the whole of the year. In fact, we are very concerned to make sure that the equal opportunity legislation which covers the Public Service is making a difference and having its effect. Senator Hill said that women should be rising in all these positions. We point out that part of our legislation insists on the principle of merit as well as the principle of opportunity. It may well be that there were not enough candidates with the necessary qualifications. It may well be that there were no vacancies. We cannot ask people to create vacancies in the public or private sector just to get the numbers up. I could conclude from what Senator Hill said, but I will not, that the Opposition is after quotas and that it will not be satisfied until it sets quotas and insists on them. The Government in its affirmative action and equal opportunity legislation insists that the legislation and increased opportunities for women be based on the principle of merit. If honourable senators read a number of reports and figures from the private sector, let alone the public sector, they will certainly see that any number of people are delighted with the increased representation of women in senior managerial positions in firms, large organisations, or in their own businesses. I would have thought it was fairly clear that the increased number of women in business, management, consultancies and banking, to name just a few sectors, is clear evidence that what Senator Hill is saying is a nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hill said that because the Government has a national agenda, which does not say what it will do, it has a lack of commitment to women. He said that we have a health policy but we do not have the final report, that we have consulted with rural women, but that was a talkfest. That is a complete misunderstanding of what the Government is doing in those areas and it is a complete misrepresentation of the achievements of the Government in all those areas. Senator Hill forgets, for example, that in the area of health the first and greatest contribution of the Government was to introduce Medicare.

The more than one million people who were previously not covered under insurance are now covered and thousands of women with the principal responsibility of taking children or elderly parents or relatives to the doctor now have complete freedom from the anxiety associated with whether they can afford to pay the bill. That is one of the greatest contributions to the benefit of women made by the Government in the area of health. I have mentioned the increased and improved opportunities for women in education, which women and girls have been taking up. We do not have 50 per cent of women in tertiary institutions by default. We have it because women are choosing to undertake tertiary education because they have the opportunity to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has this to do with domestic violence?

—Senator Newman may well ask what it has to do with domestic violence, but Senator Hill led it in his case and I am simply running across some of his ground. If it was relevant for Senator Hill, I presume it is as relevant for me. Senator Hill seemed to suggest that people were at home being beaten up because of poverty; then he said that they were apparently being beaten up because they were not getting executive officer positions, a most illogical speech if ever I heard one. Thus licensed to wander, I will so wander, but I do not claim that it has anything to do with domestic violence. However, I thank Senator Newman for her interjection because it allows me to make that point nicely and clearly.

SPEECH.PARA: In the minutes left to me I would like also to pick up on what Senator Hill had to say about how women are not being affected by changes under the awards. He said that the Government was going to fix everything for women through changes to the awards. Was Senator Hill not around when the nurses' award was introduced? Does he not understand the campaign that actually got an award for nurses, got a career path for them, got benefits of increased payments for nurses and the work they have been doing such as have never been there before? That was an extraordinary achievement and an absolutely fantastic effort by nurses on their own behalf, particularly in view of the fact that their union has a composition of something like 96 per cent women. Senator Hill really ought to blush for getting that example wrong.

Secondly, the enormous restructuring currently being undertaken by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and already in place in some parts of the Public Service will see considerable increases in opportunities for women who are largely in the same segregation of jobs as they have ever been-in sales, services and clerical positions. Previously in those sections of work force participation, women could expect very little opportunity for advancement. Under the award restructuring, career paths will open to them. That is precisely what we have argued for; that is, increased opportunities and financial return for women in the work force will open up, not only under the benefits of the affirmative action legislation and the agency and the changes that firms, public and private organisations, will be making, but also under the award restructuring changes that are currently being developed within the ACTU and already, as I understand it, within the Commonwealth Public Service. For the edification of Senator Hill, it is my understanding that award restructurings at the lower end of the Commonwealth Public Service have led to something like 100-plus job classifications being reduced to eight, but I will not be held to those figures. Those changes mean that there are now career paths for people in those new classifications. Those career paths allow not only increased work participation and new work opportunities, but also increased remuneration for that work. We thank Senator Hill for drawing that to our attention too. For those women who choose to work, who have to work or who get into the work force for whatever reason, there are very many more opportunities under this Government.

Women are most appreciative of the changes put in place for them by the Government and they are also aware of the shortfall because much is still to be done. However, to come in here and say that women reckon we have done nothing is absolutely false in the extreme and extraordinarily simplistic. Women are now saying that they have a voice, that they have a government that listens, a government that has implemented any number of opportunities for them, a government that has provided child care places. The Government has increased the number of child-care places from some 43,000 to 110,000, with another 30,000 promised over the next four years. It has enormously encouraged women and tried to assist them to get into the work force through its specifically targeted programs like the jobs, education and training program (JET), the planning and implementation stage of which is well under way, so as to provide the opportunities and training and back into training and retraining into the work force for women who have been long term unemployed or single parents. The Government's commitment to women is there. If we have failed at all it is because we have still more to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —We can agree with that.

—We make no apology about it. That is why we have the Office for the Status of Women. That is why we have a Minister representing the status of women. Quite clearly we do not expect to correct in six years the insufficiencies of years of Liberal opposition. The Liberal Party never gave women opportunities. It still thinks, if I read correctly its new platform dreaming of the past, that women live in the home and enjoy the dependent spouse rebate if they are lucky enough to have it passed across to them. I do not quite understand from reading the Opposition's policy document what it will do for this hypothetical small percentage of women, but I noticed as I read the document that something like two column inches were devoted to child-care. If our policies are insufficient, I would not hold my breath with respect to the Opposition's plans, unless we can expect a future `future' document that will spell out the future `future' directions and we hold our breath and wait for it. In the meantime, we have addressed those problems. We have recognised the importance of women. We have created child-care places. We know so much more is to be done, but the Government has a commitment to 30,000 extra-child care places. It quite clearly appreciates that in a few years we cannot cover the full takeup of child-care requirements. It also appreciates that child care is of critical importance to women whether they are going to use it in the occasional care way or for full term employment. Women have made choices of all sorts about how they will live, about when they will have their families and how they will have them and whether they will go back to work full time or part time or whether for some years they will use child-care only in the occasional care way. There are provisions and a recognition of the diversity of women's lives under our policy.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The hypocrisy of Senator Crowley in this motion before the Senate is unbelievable. It is a pity she did not take the trouble to research her subject when she accused Senator Hill of saying that domestic violence was a `soft issue'. Being present at the press conference, I can assure her that the assertions in her motion were totally untrue. I give her a little advice. In the future, if the honourable senator does not intend to do any research on her own motion, then she should at least have the decency to tell the Senate that she does not know something for sure, that she has heard it from someone else. I say to the honourable senator, `Do not do what you have done tonight-discredit women in this Senate'.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Crowley has just found a new interest in domestic violence. She has never before spoken in this chamber on domestic violence. She has never asked a question on domestic violence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I have practised some tolerance, Mr President, but I find it quite outrageous that Senator Walters could accuse me of only just having discovered domestic violence and of never having spoken on it before. I would ask you to correct Senator Walters for that gross dishonouring of my name.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—As I said, Senator Crowley has never spoken on domestic violence in this place.
—That is what I would call a lie.

—I have had the Parliamentary Library do a check, and Senator Crowley tells me that is a lie. I would be interested to know on which occasion Senator Crowley claims she has spoken on domestic violence. She has also never asked a question on domestic violence. The only time she has ever used the words in this place was on an urgency motion on videos and she used one sentence only. She has never shown any interest in this Senate in domestic violence.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, Senator Reynolds, has also never spoken in this place on domestic violence. Indeed, the only time Senator Reynolds used the word `violence' in this Senate was in regard to the referendum. This is pretty indicative of the Government's concerns, and it seems to me that what we have seen tonight in the completely untrue statements in the motion put by Senator Crowley is nothing more than rank hypocrisy.

The problem the Government has is that Senator Hill travelled around the country discussing this matter, and at a press conference he said that women were concerned primarily about the economic issues-hard issues such as home interest rates and the drop in living standards. He said that he was surprised domestic violence had not been raised, not that he would call it a soft issue. He said that women were highlighting the causes of domestic violence. Senator Crowley has said tonight that Senator Hill was-I think these were her words-`widely wrong' in saying that the stress of economic issues created domestic violence. Perhaps we ought to look at someone who has a little more expertise in this area than Senator Crowley. Let us turn to the Institute of Family Studies. On 5 January this year, the Institute said:

Domestic violence is now so widespread police must use all their powers to deal with families in crisis. . . Australia needed a major change in social values, among the public and on the part of State authorities.
Dr Edgar, the Institute's Director, said:
. . . the removal of poverty, unemployment and poor living conditions which fuelled family stress lay at the base of any attempt to reduce community violence.

Senator Crowley, when Senator Hill comments in that area, says he is `widely wrong'. What absolute rubbish. Is it any wonder the Government is getting nowhere when it is not prepared to listen to people like Dr Edgar and the Institute of Family Studies and is incapable even of attempting to look for the causes of domestic violence? All it is prepared to do is use the bandaid methods.

Senator Crowley spoke widely tonight about the shelters the Government has funded, but it has not carried out the basic requirement of looking at the causes of violence. Indeed, it has fuelled the causes. We all know what a dreadful mess the economy is in. We all know living standards have dropped. We all know that families are now worse off by $58 as week. We all know that housing interest rates have gone up to 16 per cent and that the stress on families is quite horrific. Is it any wonder that, as the Institute says, domestic violence is now so widespread that police must use all their powers to deal with families in crisis?

The Government has done nothing. I would just like to go through the Government's approach to domestic violence. On 25 May 1988 Senator Reynolds first said that the Government had set aside $1.6m for a national education campaign to reduce the incidence of domestic violence. She did not say that in this place but in the public arena. That does not come into effect until April this year. We have had a 12-month lapse. Let me go on. On 29 August last year Senator Reynolds put out another news release following the domestic violence survey. She said, `We found in Australia that one in five people think it is all right for a man to give his wife a bit of a bash up in certain circumstances'-one of them being if she does not obey him. That is a horrific figure. She again reiterated her May statement when she said:
The Government has allocated $1.6m over three years-
that is a lot of money-
to be spent on the domestic violence campaign. The first stage of the campaign will be designed to lift awareness of domestic violence issues.

So we are getting on through the year; we have not actually done anything yet. On 30 August, Dr Paul Wilson of the Australian Institute of Criminology pleaded with the Government to do something about domestic violence. He pointed out that domestic violence was a major crime in Australia, responsible for many assaults and for between 30 and 40 per cent of all murders. Senator Reynolds again said, `We have got that $1.6m to be spent over three years in this area'. When Mr Shanahan pointed out that there was a great need for education, Senator Reynolds said, `Well, that could be done through such television programs as A Country Practice'. The mind boggles, and the Government still has its $1.6m waiting to be spent.
That was in August. In November last year, we got another news release from the Office of the Status of Women. Senator Reynolds again talked about her $1.6m. She stated:
From January 1989, the Government will establish a network of Information Officers in each State and the Northern Territory . . .

The Government is aiming, we were told, to raise public awareness from January 1989 and a range of public education materials will be prepared. It is now February and I do not think many people have seen them.

TALK.START.PARA: —In April.

—It is all to be done in April; but the Minister's first announcement was made in May last year. So over a period of 12 months the Minister has been working up to this tremendous $1.6m, to be spent over three years, this vast sum of money. The Minister has been telling the people of Australia about this domestic violence situation for over 12 months-and has been doing absolutely nothing. The Minister stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The National Education Program will include multi-lingual material and give special consideration to the needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women, and women living in rural and remote areas.

All that will be done on $1.6m over three years. It will be a good campaign, will it not? Then on 26 November last year we finally had an advertisement in the newspaper. The advertisement was headed `Community Project Grants'. It stated:
Grants will be made in amounts between $250 and $5000 . . . Selected projects should be timed to coincide with the Government's Domestic Violence National Awareness Month in April 1989.

So still no money has been spent, and the Minister started last May. We have been having a running commentary on what the Government was going to do in 12 months time. The $1.6m now depleted by the 7.7 per cent inflation rate is beginning to look a bit small. It has been 12 months since the original announcement. Is it any wonder, as Senator Hill said, that the women and the women's groups are fed up with the Government? Is it any wonder that people such as Eva Cox made such criticisms of the Office of the Status of Women? She stated:
. . . Labor Government in 1983 moved the unit back to the Prime Minister's portfolio.
The name was changed from the Office of Women's Affairs to the Office of the Status of Women.

Yet five years later, there is considerable disquiet about the office and its effectiveness. References are made to the Office of Women of Status, and expressions of surprise that it still exists are fairly common.
That is because the people out in the community do not even know that it is in existence. She continued:
It is now often seen as peripheral. The main function seems to be telling women what the Government has done for them, not vice-versa.
It is not letting the women tell the Government what they want. She continued:

If the period had recorded many gains for women, maybe this lack of visability of the office would be acceptable. There have been some gains in the legislative area with the Sex Discrimination Act and the Affirmative Action legislation. We have had five years of child care expansion . . .

But women are losing in a range of important areas. The only universal payment to women, the Family Allowance, is now income tested; sole parents now lose pensions when their children turn 16; custodial parents may now be compelled to claim maintenance or lose their pensions; introduction of fees and tertiary taxes are reducing female participation in post-school education; childcare programs . . . are still on shaky ground and their expansion has slowed.
It's on the economic side that the losses are occurring. And it is in this area that the office seems to be least effective.

Under Malcolm Fraser, there was a powerful National Women's Advisory Council which spoke out against government decisions and represented its constituency. The present National Women's Consultative Council certainly does not seem to have the access to the Prime Minister and the media . . .

Eva Cox has expressed very clearly what the women of Australia feel. Is it any wonder that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has asked the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to moderate his language? Is it any wonder that the Prime Minister has said, `I want you all now to start using language that is acceptable to women because we are losing their vote hand over fist.'? It is an absolute insult to women to be told that the Government will get their votes back if Mr Keating uses pleasant language and does not use the sort of language that we are so used to hearing in this place.

Did the Federal Government set up a men's health forum as was done in Tasmania? The men's health forum in Tasmania had men, who were the perpetrators of domestic violence, coming and listening to many speeches and entering programs. I think that it would be a good idea if the Federal Government took some sort of similar action, because this forum occurred 12 or 18 months ago now. I am not quite sure when it was, but it was quite some time ago. It is about time that this Federal Government started that sort of forum throughout the country.

Senator Crowley said that if we have failed at all, it is just that we have still got more to do. I have never heard such a master understatement, because all this Government has done is give the rhetoric. It has done nothing about the problems, the causes of domestic violence. The only thing it has done is exacerbate them. It has created the stresses and strains within a family that, according to Dr Edgar, are the real reasons for domestic violence. The economy is in a dreadful mess. As Senator Crowley said a little while ago, this year for the first time under Labor we have 50 per cent of women in the work force. What an indictment! Those opposite should speak to many of the women. They say, `The only way I can keep my house is if I put my baby in a child-care centre and get out into the work force because it is impossible under this Government for a one-income family to own a house. So I have to leave my baby in a child-care centre and I have to get out and work to pay the high interest rates that this Government is imposing upon the women'. Senator Crowley has the hide to say what a great plus it is, what a great thing it is, that 50 per cent of the work force are now women. She calls that a great gain for this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the kids?
—What about the kids, what about the babies who have been put in the child minding centres? What about the mothers?
—They do very nicely.

—Senator Giles says that they do very nicely. What about the mothers who weep tears at having to put their babies in these shelters? They know that they cannot pay off their home or keep their home going unless they go out into the work force. It is this sort of insensitive government that has no knowledge of the grass roots feeling among the women that is, I can assure honourable senators, losing the women's vote hand over fist. It will continue to do so while it has such stupid comments from the women senators in this place who applaud the fact that these women have been forced into the work force and say, `Is it not wonderful that we now have 50 per cent of women in the work force?'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats I wish to make a brief contribution to this debate. We consider this to be a debate on domestic violence, however I would say at the outset that we have the greatest difficulty with this motion because we see it as a motion which should not even be being pursued here tonight. There is a question mark over whether Senator Hill made the statements which are attributed to him. Indeed, I understand that he has made a personal explanation to that effect. Nevertheless, this is a motion concerning domestic violence and we did not want to let this debate go past without making a contribution. Although the Government has pursued this motion tonight and the Opposition has successfully negated the adjournment, it is, as I say, a motion which should not really be being dealt with. When it comes to the end of this parliamentary session and we are all sitting here until two o'clock in the morning rushing through important social security legislation which no doubt will be designed to assist the very people who are addressed in this motion, the Democrats will be reminding both the Liberal-National Party Opposition and the Government of this sort of wasting of the time of the Parliament with what tend very often to be mischievous motions.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, while Senator Hill may have been misquoted-he says he has been misquoted, which is an experience most of us in this chamber have shared with him at one time or another-in essence the sentiments expressed in this motion ring quite true. All too often it is the case with the Liberal-National Party Opposition that the only `real issues' seem to be the solid economic issues, the bottom line, the trade balance or the Budget surplus. This also applies to the Australian Labor Party in government-a matter of great regret and distress to many groups in the community that are still battling for survival in their daily lives. Due attention is not given either by the Government or by the Opposition to the issues of genuine concern to people in their daily lives.

Senator Crowley, in her contribution, admitted that women in this community are constantly asking for more. It is true that in many areas this Government has taken some steps, where it can, and I think we should note at this point that the majority of necessary legislation specific to child abuse and to domestic violence falls within the purview of our colleagues at the State level. Nevertheless, in those areas where the Federal Government can affect the daily lives of people, particularly those struggling to get out of poverty and support themselves financially, this Government has taken some action. It has had to be pushed, and amongst the groups pushing it hardest have been the Australian Democrats along with various groups in the welfare sector and in the women's movement. One should acknowledge action where it has been taken-for instance, in relation to refuges and the general shelter movement. On the other hand, we have had the recent report of the Human Rights Commission and Mr Burdekin into child homelessness. Surely nothing could be more violent than a situation in which tens of thousands of young children are out on the streets. Increasing numbers of children are living in poverty. Bringing children into this world and then not being able to support them is a violent act in itself.

Of course, women are asking for more and they must continue to do so while there is deprivation in our community-and indeed there still is deprivation in our community. One of the things the Government has attempted to do has been to provide employment. The Democrats believe that the claims the Government makes about its success in these areas are wildly exaggerated. One of the things that disturb us most is that the Government and the Opposition and most political and economic commentators in our community seem to have accepted about a 7 per cent to 8 per cent plateau of unemployment as though that were adequate. It is not adequate. It is not much more than 15 years ago that we were horrified to see unemployment beginning to creep up above 2 per cent. In 1970 I recall going to the United States of America to live for a time. I went from a country which had less than 2 per cent unemployment to a country that had 6 per cent unemployment, and I was horrified. Now we cannot get it back below that. Just as an aside, when the latest employment figures came out, closely followed by the latest inflation figures, it was appalling to see most of the economic and political commentators throwing their hands up in the air and saying, `If people get more jobs they will spend more money and there will be more pressure on the economy', almost as if we have to keep people in poverty and out of jobs in order to balance our Budget. I consider that to be an exercise in community violence.

There is one area that the Democrats would like to draw attention to in this debate. As we all know, the committee on violence came out with its first report during the parliamentary break. That report is very factual and it really should bring us all up to a pretty short and sharp start. It is a slim volume and it is packed with frightful information on domestic assault and child abuse. I wish to refer to one comment at the end of the section on domestic violence, violence in the home. This section tells us that about 25 per cent of all homicides are marital killings; that almost all child homicide victims are killed by fellow family members; that almost 60 per cent of all homicides occur in the home; that almost 40 per cent of family killings involve firearms; that a prior history of domestic assault occurs in almost one half of all marital homicides; and so on. In a little section headed `Australian attitudes to violence in the home' we find:
The information presented so far suggests that violence in the home is not a rarity. Moreover, attitudinal studies show that such violence is widely tolerated in the Australian community.

I think that comment more than any other comment in this report is the one that we should really pay close attention to. The committee on violence has given us this information, and we have seen other surveys earlier which have indicated it. We must take it seriously. We must understand, as much as we might find it abhorrent, that violence is to a disturbing degree an accepted part of our social fabric and we must do something about that. We must do all of the things that the Government is attempting to do; we must do all of the things that the Opposition says that it would like to do; we must do all of the things that all of us would like to do.

I want to mention one point that has not been raised in this debate. We must seriously get into developing and establishing a program of peace education in our community. We must look at non-violent optional means of conflict resolution. Conflict is an integral part of everybody's daily lives. We cannot get rid of conflict but we can work out ways to deal with it which will mean that people do not beat up on each other. That is what peace education is about. I am a Victorian. I can say that Victoria leads the way. I have already said that most of the initiatives that will really address the fundamental issues that are raised in this motion are in the hands of State governments. The State Government in Victoria has developed not only a good policy but also a good program. A peace education resource centre backs up those schools and those teachers who introduce programs of peace education in their schools, supported by their school communities, by parents and by the community at large. Other governments around Australia have policies, such as the Western Australian Government and the South Australian Government, but they are not acting on those policies. The former New South Wales Labor Government developed curriculum material and it was ready to go. That material is now gathering dust on Greiner's bookshelves, or somewhere deep in a cellar. Of course, we need not mention Queensland or Tasmania in this context. We need to think about these kinds of solutions as well as the more traditional approaches which have been part and no doubt will continue to be part of this debate for a long time. Those are the two major points that we would like to make.

In underlining our concern about the acceptability of what we consider extraordinarily unacceptable rates of unemployment, a couple of other points should be made. One is that the greatest single category in murders-whether victims or perpetrators-is the unemployed, so we must get unemployment down. We would also like to comment on the assertion, by Senator Newman particularly, from the Opposition benches that the only reason that the participation rate of women in employment is rising is that women simply cannot afford not to be employed. I assume that Senator Newman is here because she cannot afford not to be and that her other female colleagues are only here to keep the wolf from the door. There are other reasons why women wish to be in employment, one of those being so that they can be independent, individual human beings upon whom the male members of this society might think twice before perpetrating an act of violence.

However, the Australian Democrats do not accept the shining record of the Government which has been put forward by Senator Crowley. In this past couple of days we have found it very insulting that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) have decided to woo the women's vote by simply watching their language. On the other hand, they cannot find time to go and open the women's tax summit at the weekend, and they have pushed Jenny Acton aside to let Simon Crean in. There are all sorts of similar evidence; it is not a perfect record by any means. Unemployment must be removed and we must get into peace education. Those are perhaps two additional messages that we would like to insert. I quote from the latest newsletter of the Women's Electoral Lobby which has a rather delightful section on its back page entitled `Pig Pen'. Here is a quote from Justice John Gallop in the Australian Capital Territory on a custody case which was reported in the Canberra Times last Christmas Eve. He said:
Despite some serious errors of judgement in the past-such as taking the children to peace rallies and demonstrations-she had emerged as the parent who was more emotionally mature . . .

Until we can get rid of attitudes like that, until we can take seriously a different approach, we will never get rid of this problem of domestic violence. The Australian Democrats feel it is unfortunate that this debate did not take place in the context of something less opportunistic than this motion. However, we wish to indicate our serious concern about this most vital issue in our community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator REYNOLDS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Local Government and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we have had a very wide ranging debate starting with domestic violence but extending into other areas relating to the status of women in Australian society. At this time in the evening on our first night back I do not propose to take up the time of the Senate by going into great detail about a number of those issues, much as I am tempted to do so. I think it is very unfortunate that the bipartisan spirit that Senator Vanstone and I attempted to foster in relation to status of women issues seems to have broken down somewhat in the last few months.
—That is Senator Crowley's fault for giving a notice of motion today which she has now admitted is false; and you cannot blame us for that.

—Well, Senator Reid, in the spirit of that bipartisanship that I believe we have had on a range of status of women issues in this place, I am proposing to withdraw Senator Crowley's notice of motion and to move an alternative motion in its place.
—You will need leave to withdraw the motion.
—I seek leave to withdraw Senator Crowley's notice of motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I am sorry that this is not as well organised as we would have liked, but we are working to try to get the issue back on the agenda and to take some of the political point-scoring out of it. I have sought leave to withdraw the notice of motion. I thank the Senate for granting leave for me to do so. In its place I seek leave to move the following motion:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate condemns widespread domestic violence in the Australian community and particularly the acceptance of domestic violence and endorses the Government's national domestic violence awareness campaign.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not the words that I said I would agree to. I said that I would agree with a motion that--
—The motion should also include the words:

SPEECH.PARA: and applauds all steps to reduce domestic violence.
Mr President, with your patience and that of the Senate I would like to reword that motion in the following terms:
That the Senate condemns widespread domestic violence in the community and applauds all steps to reduce domestic violence.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Opposition and Senator Hill for enabling us to resolve the major dispute that has arisen tonight about domestic violence.
—The dispute was not about domestic violence.

—That is what it was supposed to be about. I think it would be regrettable if, in the spirit of bipartisanship, certain members of the Opposition were being opportunistic in using domestic violence as a means of raising other issues.
—Put the motion and we will all go home.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate condemns widespread domestic violence in the community and applauds all steps to reduce domestic violence.
I felt I must clarify a couple of points that were made, particularly in relation to what Senator Walters said.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought you were not going to make a speech.

—I will be brief. This campaign will run for three years. The first year related to research. It is vitally important that we know what we are working with. It is pointless just to say that we will have a domestic violence awareness campaign if we do not know the attitudes in the community. So, yes, we did spend over 12 months on our research. But we believe that that research is the vital foundation on which to build the next stage.

SPEECH.PARA: We are now in the second stage, which will culminate in the domestic violence awareness month in April. There are projects all around Australia. We are working with local government, police, doctors and community health centres. We are working with a wide range of community organisations and representatives of women's organisations to try to get the Australian community to appreciate that this is a community concern. It is not an issue for political point scoring; it is not an issue for narrowly saying that this is the cause or that is the cause. A number of issues lead to domestic violence, but it is the acceptance of domestic violence in the Australian community that we as a government and as a parliament have a responsibility to address.

We cannot accept a situation in which many women can be threatened in their own homes. We cannot turn around and say that that is acceptable. Our research showed that one in five believe that it is acceptable. People believe that domestic violence is a private matter. This is all related to attitudes-attitudes to women and attitudes to the relationship between men and women.

The important thing about our domestic violence awareness campaign, which will start in April and have a focus for the month, is that we will then go on to other programs. I am prepared to put on the public record that I want to see a higher budgetary commitment for the domestic violence awareness campaign. Domestic violence is an enormous problem. It is a problem that is greater than we imagined when former Senator Susan Ryan first argued for $1.6m to be put aside in the 1987-88 Budget. The important thing to understand tonight is that we might have started to turn around what began as a debate that, frankly, I did not find particularly edifying-not because it was a political debate and things were said critical of the Government but because I believe that the issues involved in domestic violence go way beyond the Government and Opposition arguing about what we have done and what the Opposition might do in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have had all the information for years. Shelters have been required to put in records, year after year, of categories of clients.

—We have not had information about attitudes. That is the important thing we are trying to get at. Perhaps we should debate this at another time. I will invite Senator Newman to come when we brief our Commonwealth-State domestic violence task force on a number of these issues. She would be very welcome, as would Senator Hill or any other member of the Opposition. I think the Federal Government is taking a very responsible attitude in relation to coordinating this national domestic violence awareness campaign. I welcome the support of honourable senators opposite for this motion. I certainly hope that in relation to domestic violence we will not again see a political point scoring exercise. The matter is too serious.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON CORPORATIONS LEGISLATION

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House of Representatives acquaints the Senate of the following resolution which was agreed to by the House of Representatives this day:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House concurs in the resolution transmitted in message No. 302 of the Senate relating to an extension of time for the presentation of the report of the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented. During her contribution, Senator Walters said that the Parliamentary Library had found no evidence that I had ever mentioned domestic violence. Further evidence from the Library indicates that I have mentioned domestic violence on 15 occasions.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today in Question Time Senator Collins asked a question of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) regarding the imposition of fees in the Kakadu National Park in the Northern Territory. Both the question and the answer were very simplistic. They did not cover the very real issue that has been current in the Northern Territory for quite some time. The levying of entry fees in the Kakadu National Park has caused a great deal of community concern throughout the Northern Territory. It has had impositions in a whole number of areas. From the way in which the question was phrased and the answer was given anyone would think that the players in the game this year had been Senator Collins, Mr Snowdon from the House of Representatives and Senator Richardson. That is not the case. There are hundreds of Territorians who felt vitally affected and who made representations. The industry groups, particularly from the tourist industry, were very vocal and certainly made many representations to Senator Richardson. The fact that the matter was quite widely discussed throughout the community, the fact that the Northern Territory Government and various Ministers also became involved, certainly showed that the issue required urgent and prominent attention by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Anyone who looked carefully at Senator Richardson's reply today would think that the issue rested only on permits for commercial filming and still photography, adult entry fees for the use of the park, and the fact that, to quote Senator Richardson, `there were a few complaints from some of the operators'. The controversy relating to the fee was such that it was initiated by the Minister and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS). The debate was over the level of fees and the imposition and the types of fees. Senator Richardson implied that a park use fee of $5 was put in place at the last minute. That fee was struck after much more onerous fees had been suggested and looked at. Of course, there are now also user pays fees for camping and other facilities that are used.

It is interesting to note that the traditional owners of the area, who are largely represented through the Gagudju Association, recently posted a letter on noticeboards in the Jabiru township. The letter was addressed to the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service in Canberra. It reads:
Gagudju is opposed to the imposition of the new park fee on Jabiru people and other people resident within the external park boundaries for most day use activities.
Gagudju believes these people should be able to undertake day sightseeing, picnic and fishing trips free of charge.
Beyond the question of whether the fees are appropriate or not other questions should be considered.
Will aboriginal staff of the N.L.C. and other non-local aboriginal residents be expected to pay?
Will off-duty park staff pay?
Gagudju feels not only are the fees unfair for most day use activities but the inevitable discrimination in application has dangerous implications for A.N.P.W.S. staff and general town harmony.
Please reconsider urgently.
Yours sincerely,
JESSIE ALDERSON
Chairman.

Mrs Alderson, the Chairman of the Association, has posted this notice on noticeboards around Jabiru and has added the words `For the information of Jabiru people', and a further signature `Jessie Alderson'. It is quite clear that the ANPWS did not consult as widely as it ought, or as properly as it ought, with the Aboriginal local residents of the community, the Jabiru people or the Northern Territory commercial and residential community.

The controversy was profound. It is still going on. Whilst there have now been certain exceptions put in place for residents of the township of Jabiru, that now makes two classes of Territory citizens. Other Territorians throughout the Northern Territory regularly use the facilities of the Kakadu National Park for many recreational and other reasons; yet, because they might live a short distance away down the Arnhem Highway, different sets of fees are to be imposed for the use of the Kakadu National Park.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't want Jabiru residents excluded.

—I certainly want Jabiru residents excluded, just as I would like all Territory residents excluded. There are many other situations throughout Australia in which national park fees also need to be carefully addressed. I think it iniquitous that Labor Government members find that they can accept these fees for imposition across the whole situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the Minister did not cover all of the fees that had been put. As I said, his reply was simplistic in that he left out many. Another fee which has recently been imposed through the ANPWS is an additional fee on visitors to the Kakadu National Park who go on commercial water cruises. Additional fees and imposts are now being put in place and are causing concern not only to the tourists who have already paid the upfront adult fee and who are now required to pay an additional fee, but also to tour operators, who have had to plan and commercially set their tariffs and structures well in advance. This state of affairs has been imposed.

I also wish to comment on the point that other representations have been made largely through the Northern Territory Minister for Primary Industry and Fisheries, Mr Mike Reed, to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, regarding compensation for fishermen now displaced in the rivers of the Kakadu National Park. This again is a serious matter which the Minister has chosen to wipe aside. He has attempted to transfer the responsibility back to the Northern Territory Government when the executive action rests with the Minister himself, his Department and the ANPWS. The Federal Government obviously is acting outside its moral obligations. It is attempting to buck-pass all these situations. It is obvious that the recent moves by Senator Richardson are such that he should come to the Territory and face the people who are making these strong, urgent representations that need to be considered. But no, the Australian Labor Party is determined to raise whatever funds it can, wherever it sees an increase in something that is profitable or successful.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.21 p.m.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Agencies: Allegations by Mr J. Doohan

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 20 November 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Attorney-General's Office receive on 2 July 1987, from John Doohan of 21 Bartlett Street, Willagee, Western Australia, an Australia Post registered letter, with relevant documentation requesting the Attorney-General to inquire into serious allegations, by John Doohan, of illegal, improper actions by the Australian Security Intelligence Organization (ASIO) and other Australian Commonwealth agencies?

(2) Did the Attorney-General receive, from Senator Jo Vallentine, 2 letters dated 14 August and 8 September 1987, respectively, requesting the Attorney-General to urgently inquire into John Doohan's allegations referred to in (1) above?
(3) If answers to (1) and (2) above are yes, will the Attorney-General explain why he has not answered the above referred to requests by John Doohan and Senator Vallentine?

(4) Did the Attorney-General on or about 9 July, decline to accede to a request by the Director of Public Prosecutions, for copies of John Doohan's letter of request for inquiry and relevant documentation, on the Attorney-General's stated grounds that his office was not aware of any correspondence received from John Doohan; if so, for what reasons did the Attorney-General deny receipt of John Doohan's letter of request for inquiry into serious allegations against ASIO and other named agencies?

(5) Did John Doohan's letter and relevant material allege that, for many years, ASIO and other named Australian Commonwealth agencies have been covertly compiling and maintaining, on himself, medically unqualified untruthful detrimental psychiatric and `personal defect' assessment and opinion records; if so, will the Attorney-General confirm or deny, (a) whether any mental assessments or opinions about John Doohan are contained in any report or record held now, or at any time, within ASIO, Australian Federal Police or any other Commonwealth agency or Department, including his own Department; and (b) if the answer to (a) is yes, (i) was such assessment or opinion obtained from an appropriately qualified medical authority, and (ii) when, how and by whom was it obtained?

(6) Did John Doohan's letter to the Attorney-General contain a copy of a medical examination report by a registered professionally practising Australian psychiatrist, certifying that in the psychiatrist's opinion and contrary to Commonwealth covert records, John Doohan in no way suffers from any type of mental illness, disorder or abnormality?

(7) If the answer to (6) above is yes, then; (a) has the Attorney-General any valid reason to disagree with the medical opinion expressed in the medical report referred to in (6), above; and (b) if the Attorney-General's answer to (a) is yes, will he explain why?

(8) Did John Doohan's letter to the Attorney-General refer to, and did a third party's accompanying sworn affidavit attest to, an alleged improper visit and interview, by ASIO with John Doohan's private employer, for the purpose of preventing John Doohan from obtaining, or continuing in, lawful employment in order to support himself and his family; if so, will the Attorney-General confirm or deny whether such a visit and interview by ASIO took place in the sworn affidavit referred to above?

(9) Will the Attorney-General explain why Commonwealth Police and succeeding Federal Police forces, also maintained such false detrimental records, about John Doohan, in the covert files of `C' Division, Criminal Investigation Bureau, when he rightfully should have no criminal record of any description?
(10) Will the Attorney-General advise whether, John Doohan is regarded by his office, or by any Australian law enforcement or security force or agency, as a national security risk or subject?

(11) Does the Attorney-General intend to inquire into the allegations presented to him, or those which may subsequently be presented to him by John Doohan; if not, will the Attorney-General explain his reasons for refusing to make the inquiry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (3) I replied to Mr Doohan and to Senator Vallentine on 24 December 1987.

(4) The Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions wrote to the Attorney-General's Department on 9 July 1987 seeking copies of attachments to Mr Doohan's letter to the Attorney-General after the Director had received from Mr Doohan a copy of that letter. The Director's Office was initially informed that no representations had been received from Mr Doohan because the Director's letter and Mr Doohan's letter had been referred to different Divisions of the Department for attention. The reason for this was that Mr Doohan's letter and attachments mainly related to alleged infringements of human rights whereas the Director's letter related to alleged infringements of the criminal law. When this was discovered the Director's Office was supplied with relevant documents on 10 August 1987.

(5) Mr Doohan's letter does allege that Commonwealth agencies have been covertly compiling false psychiatric/psychological reports and opinions and some of the documents attached to Mr Doohan's letter contain opinions about his mental state. These appear to have been based on the personal views of persons who were not medical practitioners. I am not aware of the existence of documents containing medical opinions as to Mr Doohan's mental condition.
(7) I am not in a position to express any view on the medical opinion furnished by Mr Doohan.

(8) and (10) In accordance with the practice followed by successive governments I will not comment on Mr Doohan's allegations concerning ASIO, or whether an individual is or is not a national security risk.
(9) The police documents referred to by Mr Doohan and attached to his letter were prepared in response to his inquiries and allegations of telephone tapping. They are not criminal records.

(11) Mr Doohan's allegations have been examined by the Director of Public Prosecutions and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. The Director of Public Prosecutions advised Mr Doohan that the material provided by him did not disclose anything upon which that Office could base a prosecution. The Attorney-General subsequently informed Mr Doohan that he had been advised by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission that the material forwarded to it by the Department, which comprised copies of the documents forwarded to the Attorney-General by Mr Doohan, did not substantiate a breach of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and, consequently, that the Commission was unable to conduct any formal inquiry into his allegations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Information provided by State and Territory health authorities on gross expenditure on public hospitals for the three years 1985-86 to 1987-88 is shown in the following table. The table also compares the per capita recurrent expenditure by the States and Territories.

(2) Federal assistance to the States for hospital services in 1987-88 was provided under a number of Commonwealth programs. Some funding was specifically identified with public hospital services. In addition, an unspecified but significant amount was included in the financial assistance grants.
The Federal funding readily identified for public hospital services in Queensland in 1987-88 was:
Capital grant for equipment in teaching

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 24 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an evident dispute between the Queensland Government and the Iwasaki family and business associates.

(2) Is the Federal Government monitoring the so-called `Yeppoon' project to assure itself that Mr Iwasaki's project, at its present stage of development or lack thereof, falls within foreign investment guidelines.
(3) Is the Federal Government constantly kept aware by the Ahern administration of developments in the row mentioned in (1) above.

(4) What courses are available to the Federal Government to force either the completion of the project, or the withdrawal of the Japanese interests that are not in accordance with Foreign Investment Guidelines.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) In 1978 when the Government approved the Iwasaki tourist development at Yeppoon, foreign investment policy requirements were more restrictive than those applying now.

Development of the resort has progressed, albeit slowly, and for a time the developers reported annually to the Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) on its progress, consistent with a condition of the foreign investment approval for the project.

In more recent years the foreign investment policy guidelines applying to tourist resort developments have been liberalised and proposals similar to Yeppoon are now readily approved, usually without conditions of the kind previously imposed. In these circumstances, conditions applying to earlier foreign investment proposals are treated as having lapsed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 24 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Minister confirm that, according to Mr Barry Coulter, `Cumulative uncommitted demand for uranium enrichment over the next 10 years is estimated at 37 million separate work units. The United States Department of Energy has lost half of the world's enrichment capacity since 1975 . . . The door is wide open for Australia to develop competitive enrichment'; if so, can that assessment be reconciled with a statement in the Nuclear Engineering International December 1987 (page 42):

`Production capacity will be more than sufficient to meet requirements until 1995. By the end of the century, the projected capacity will be some 8 percent lower than expected demand. Whilst it might appear that new facilities might therefore be needed before the end of the next decade, the mothballed diffusion capacity in the United States would be sufficient to cover the excess demand.'; and if not, which statement is correct.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The form of words used by Mr Coulter are his own, particularly with respect to ``competitive enrichment''. However, the two statements to which the honourable senator refers are not necessarily inconsistent. As the Nuclear Engineering article points out, world enrichment capacity exceeds projected demand at least into the late 1990's. The Northern Territory statement, however, refers to uncommitted or uncontracted demand, inferring that some of this demand might be secured by new entrants to the enrichment industry at the expense of existing enrichment plants.

It is clear that in a situation of substantial overcapacity the establishment of a new enrichment plant would involve major financial risk. The overcapacity situation led to the decision of the US Department of Energy earlier this year to permanently close its Oak Ridge enrichment plant which had been maintained in a standby mode since 1985. There are of course other uncertainties in the enrichment market discouraging new investment including the fact that the economics of established enrichment technologies may well be affected by the development of new technology which is the subject of research in a number of countries.

(3) What attention has been given by the Australian Government to Conservative Member, Robert Rhodes-James', allegations regarding the death of former Australian-born serviceman, Captain `Bunny' Warren of the Royal Northumberland Fusiliers and Special Operations Executive.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

(2) In the light of evidence from a number of sources the Australian Government has adopted a policy of limited dealings with Dr Waldheim, confining contacts with him to those which are unavoidable in his role as Head of State.

(2) Does that evidence show a prima facie involvement in the death of Captain Warren and about 12 others by the now President of Austria and former United Nations Secretary-General, Dr Kurt Waldheim.

(3) What measures are being taken at an international level by the Australian Government to investigate these fresh allegations against Dr Waldheim's military, political and personal conduct during World War II.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

(3) The Australian Government is awaiting the results of the enquiry by the British Ministry of Defence before considering any further action.

(3) What level of security clearance is required for Collins Radio Company staff engaged in Government contracts.

(4) Has the Government's attention been drawn to the requirement of the Collins Radio Company that its potential employees be Australian citizens by birth or naturalisation, in addition to having been continuously resident in Australia for the immediate past 5 years; if so, (a) does the Government support those requirements and (b) is he able to say why such requirements are set.

(5) Is a requirement that job applicants be Australian citizens by birth or naturalisation, in addition to having been continuously resident in Australia for the immediate past 5 years consistent with Australia's obligations under the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination as reflected in federal and State anti-discrimination legislation; if not, what action does the Government propose to bring Collins Radio's security requirements into line with those obligations.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 22 November 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What steps have been taken over the past 6 months to overcome the continued sniping on both sides of the Tasman caused by anomalies in quarantine administration in Australia and New Zealand;

(2) What arrangements are being planned to achieve comparabilities in quarantine administration in both countries to overcome the destabilising situations that have become quite common on both sides and to enable ordinary and reasonable trade in fruit and vegetables to be carried on.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Under the Protocol to the CER Agreement on Harmonisation of Quarantine Administrative Procedures, signed on 18 August 1988, a Quarantine Consultative Group has been established to help resolve outstanding technical differences on quarantine and related inspection matters.

The Consultative Group, which comprises the Heads of the responsible Departments in Australia and New Zealand, is also charged with providing overall impetus and direction for quarantine harmonisation between the two countries. The Group held its inaugural meeting in October in New Zealand and will play an important role in overcoming quarantine related problems which arise from time to time in trans-Tasman trade.
