QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 23 November 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Did the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade issue a press release on 22 June 1988 announcing the establishment by that Department and the Attorney-General's Department of a joint Co-ordinating Committee on International Law; if so: (a) who are the members of that Committee; (b) why did the heads of the Departments agree that the implications of trade in services should be considered by the Committee initially; (c) who sets the agenda for Committee meetings; and (d) will the Committee be examining issues such as indigenous rights, human rights, environmental protection and the legality or otherwise of nuclear weaponry; and if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Press releases were issued by my Department and the Attorney-General's Department on 22 June 1988 announcing the establishment by the two Departments of a Joint Co-ordinating Committee on International Law.

(a) The Secretaries of my Department and the Attorney-General's Department are ex officio members of the Committee. Other officers of the two Departments, nominated by the Secretaries, also participate in meetings of the Committee.

(b) Liberalisation of international trade in services has been the subject of considerable activity and debate in recent years, particularly in the GATT and the OECD. A Protocol on the subject was concluded between Australian and New Zealand on 18 August 1988. The issue was therefore considered to be one which merited examination by the Committee.
(c) The agenda is set by agreement between the two Departments.

(d) The Committee will progressively examine a range of issues of interest to the two Departments in the field of international law. It is not possible at this stage to say which items will be given priority in the future. The subjects currently being considered are intellectual property and trade in services. The issues mentioned in the honourable senator's question have been brought to the attention of relevant officers of my Department and the Attorney-General's Department.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 24 November 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What part does the Commonwealth Government play and/or what assistance does it provide in detection, research and record keeping involved in the fight against the crime of arson.
(2) What is the best estimate in monetary terms of the annual loss to the nation as a result of arson.
(3) What is the estimate of loss to Federal revenue as a result of arson.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The investigation of offences of arson is a matter for individual jurisdictions. The Commonwealth's involvement, through the Australian Federal Police, is only the investigation of those incidents occurring in the ACT.

Notwithstanding jurisdictional constraints, the Commonwealth recognises the seriousness of the problem and therefore has supported, through the forum of the Australian Police Ministers' Council (APMC), the development of a national arson data base as part of the National Exchange of Police Information (NEPI) System.

The APMC recently approved the NEPI Management Group's strategic plan, which includes the National Arson Data Base as part of the NEPI System. However, the Management Group has agreed that priority at present should be given to developing the Central Names Index and Criminal Histories applications for the system.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 25 November 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Minister aware of the inconsistency in his Government's policy whereby this country now has an exemplary position on the conservation of our own tropical moist forests, by the proclamation of the ``Wet Tropics'' as World Heritage, but still continues to allow the importation of timber and timber products which are derived from the unsustainable exploitation of primary tropical forests and cause the ethnocide of tribal people like the Penan of Sarawak; if so, what is the Government's position on these imports and what is it doing to stop them.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Australia does not impose special conditions on the importation of rainforest timbers including those sourced from Malaysia referred to in the honourable senator's question.

Australia, along with the major consuming and producing nations of tropical timbers, is a member of the International Tropical Timbers Organisation (ITTO). This Organisation provides an effective framework for co-operation and consultation for the development of national policies directed, among other things, at:
(a) the sustainable utilisation and conservation of tropical forests and their genetic resources; and
(b) the maintenance of the ecological balance in the regions concerned.

Since becoming a member of the ITTO and its Council, Australia has argued strongly for the development of responsible forest management policies and practices and has encouraged producing nations to pay greater attention to the environmental values of their tropical forests.

Among the many initiatives taken by the ITTO, at its most recent meeting in November 1988, the Permanent Committee on Reforestation and Forest Management earmarked funds for major research projects to investigate:
(1) the conservation status of tropical timbers in trade, and;
(2) conservation concerns related to the diversification of timber species extracted from tropical forests.

The high priority that the ITTO is placing on conservation of tropical forests establishes a strong framework for further international action to be taken to reduce the unsustainable exploitation of these forests.

Consistent with the strong actions taken by the Commonwealth Government to protect our national rainforests I will be looking carefully, through our involvement in the ITTO and through other avenues, at practical steps that Australia can take to ensure that effective measures are put in place to conserve rainforests on a global scale.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 1 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Given the differing interests of the Australian Wool Corporation, which acts on behalf of growers, and the Minister with his own preferred position of improving down-stream processing in order to add value to our raw material, what steps is the Minister taking to resolve this dichotomy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The principle objective of the Australian Wool Corporation is to increase the commercial returns to Australia's woolgrowers. This is achieved by a number of means including the facilitation of wool marketing. The marketing powers of the Corporation include to process or arrange for the processing of wool.

As such, the Corporation has recently become involved in a joint venture at Laverton, Victoria to scour Australian wools. The plant is utilising advanced scouring technology developed by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and equipment manufactured in Australia. Market access for around half of the plant's output has been secured through one of the joint venture partners.

Through such participation in the processing sector the Corporation seeks to position woolgrowers in the manufacturing pipeline in order to protect their long term interests and to enhance the long term viability of Australian woolgrowing. The Corporation also provides advice to potential investors in the area of further value added processing.
Hence, the Corporation's approach is in line with the Government's stated policy of encouraging further processing activity in the wool sector provided there is sound economic potential.
Areas of activity such as further value added processing of Australia's rural raw materials are essential in generating employment and export earnings for Australia's future.
I believe that the Government and the Australian Wool Corporation are working together towards achieving these goals.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 1 December 1988:

(2) The Government will consider sympathetically any request from the Government of Bangladesh for assistance for the cyclone victims.
(3) The Government of Bangladesh has not made a formal appeal for international assistance for the cyclone victims.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 5 December 1988:

(4) Is it a fact that a JIO analyst who questioned the appropriateness of the award was the subject of moves to remove him from that organisation on security grounds and has subsequently been denied security clearances that would enable him access to US intelligence agencies.

(5) To what extent is advancement to high-ranking positions in Australia's defence intelligence community dependent on meritorious intelligence service to foreign governments, and other foreign agencies such as the Central Intelligence Agency.

(6) Is the CIA involved in the recruitment, security clearance and promotion of officers in the Australian intelligence community, either directly (under existing intelligence-exchange arrangements) or otherwise.

(7) Does the present Government approve of the awarding of honours and medals by foreign governments to serving officers of the Australian intelligence community for distinguished intelligence services rendered to those governments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 6 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation about to introduce shift restructuring which will reduce the number of personnel currently involved directly with the High Flux Australian Reactor at Lucas Heights; if so, what reductions on what shifts are planned.
(2) What percentage of the current staffing on the shifts affected do the reductions represent.
(3) What are the qualifications and positions of the people that will be affected.
(4) What, if any, safety assessment has been conducted to substantiate the proposed reductions in manning.
(5) What are the trends regarding staffing on equivalent nuclear reactors overseas.
(6) From both a statistical and psychological viewpoint, what is the most likely time an industrial and/or nuclear accident could occur at Lucas Heights.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Shifts will be restructured so that accredited reactor engineers will not be on rostered duty as ``Reactor Shift Managers''. They will, however, be involved in a duty officer arrangement covering the period 5 p.m. to 8 a.m. with accommodation provided on site.
A duty officer is an officer or employee, located at the Lucas Heights site outside normal working hours, held in readiness to perform duties as required.

(2) Staffing on shifts varies to meet workload requirements. Under the proposed arrangements, engineers will perform other day work of higher priority and higher engineering content, including planning and management of reactor operations. In these circumstances, it is neither possible nor valid to indicate a percentage reduction in shift staffing. All procedures requiring professional engineering oversight will continue to be so supervised.

(4) Safety assessments have been undertaken by management at ANSTO and the proposed arrangements have been reviewed and agreed by the independent Nuclear Safety Bureau established under the ANSTO Act.
(5) Staffing practices at overseas reactors of HIFAR's general type vary but typically comprise two to four persons per shift. Some HIFAR shifts are currently staffed by 6 persons and others by 5.

(6) The Lucas Heights establishment has been operating safely for over 30 years and there is, therefore, no statistical base to determine a likely time for a nuclear accident. However, it is ANSTO's opinion that accidents of any type are more likely to occur, if at all, during periods when the number, range and complexity of activities are greatest, that is, during normal day work hours, 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) It is assumed that Senator Archer's question refers to the first voyage of the current season rather than the maiden voyage of the vessel. The position is that the vessel reached her planned destination to:
deploy 33 expeditioners at Macquarie Island including the changeover wintering party and summer expeditioners;
conduct marine research in the Southern Ocean into the effects of ozone depletion on phytoplankton and on the relationship between air particles, cloud formation and phytoplankton;
pick up 19 expeditioners including the wintering party and the overseas telecommunications group which installed the new ANARESAT satellite communication system.
Because of the time it would have taken to work through the area of heavy ice the vessel did not reach:
the area of the South Magnetic Pole; and
Commonwealth Bay(the Lady Franklin reached a position 130 nautical miles short of Commonwealth Bay).
(3) The total estimated cost of the ship and fuel for the voyage, including a proportion of the deployment costs of the vessel to Australia, is approximately $421,000.

(4) Helicopters are not used by all Antarctic voyages as the cost of using helicopters must be weighed against the benefit helicopters can provide on a particular voyage. The Lady Franklin does, however, have the capacity to carry helicopters and is approved by the Civil Aviation Authority for this purpose.

(5) The inability of the Lady Franklin to reach Commonwealth Bay meant that Mawson's hut could not be inspected, that reproduction of historical photographs could not be made and that additions to a field hut could not be completed. Ice conditions also prevented the conduct of an experiment designed to determine the exact current position of the South Magnetic Pole. All other summer research and building programs were unaffected by the failure of the vessel to reach Commonwealth Bay.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, upon notice, on 15 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Given that the militarisation of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) puts it in breach of the treaty agreements between the European Space Agency and NASA, what does the Federal Government propose to do about this anomalous state of affairs.

(2) Has the Canberra Deep Space Communication Complex at Tidbinbilla ever been used to monitor NASA or general military missions, for example, the shuttle flights of Discovery on 24 January 1985, Atlantis on 3 October 1985, and Columbia on 11 January 1986.
(3) Is a record kept of all space monitoring activity at Tidbinbilla.
(4) What procedures are used to guarantee accurate records.
(5) Are the records open to public inspection.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Firstly, your assertion that NASA is militarised is not accepted by this Government. NASA is a civilian space agency. Our Agreement with the US Government calls for ``a cooperative program facilitating space flight operations for the advancement and application of mutal scientific knowledge of man's spatial environment for the benefit of man and the development of advanced space vehicles.'' This intent remains unchanged and NASA's installations in Australia are limited to that goal.
Satisfied that our agreement with the US is intact, I fail to see what role this Government has in any NASA/ESA Agreements.

(2) The Canberra Deep Space Communication Complex (CDSCC) monitors NASA missions. It does not monitor military missions. In fact, our policy prevents the involvement of CDSCC in any military activities. Therefore, no support is provided to Space Shuttles carrying military satellites.

(3) and (4) Because of the real time nature of the activity, data acquired from NASA's scientific satellites and Shuttle missions is relayed directly to the relevant NASA operational control centres in the US. Records are kept of what satellites/missions are tracked and the number of tracks undertaken by each antenna.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 14 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have the Councils referred to on page 12, figure 3.1, of Report No. 2 of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, dated October 1988, been established; if so, when.
(2) What are the terms of reference of these Councils.
(3) Have appointments been made to these Councils; if so, who are the members and how were they selected.
(4) Have these Councils actually met; if so, how many times, and what was discussed at these meetings.
(5) Has funding been provided for these Councils; if so, when did it commence;
(6) Have these Councils incurred any expenditure; if so, what are the details of that expenditure.
(7) What is the role of these Councils in relation to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters and has their existence and operation been considered by the Joint Standing Committee.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The National Consultative Council was established on 29 April 1986. State Consultative Councils were established in Western Australia on 4 July 1986; New South Wales on 19 August 1986; Tasmania on 30 October 1986; Queensland on 13 November 1986; Victoria on 27 October 1987; South Australia on 4 December 1987; and in the ACT on 12 April 1988.
The Councils were established to enable the Australian Electoral Commission (the Commission) to comply with section 22c of the Public Service Act 1922.

(2) National Consultative Council: Without limiting the scope of consultation and negotiation the principal matters for consideration by the National Consultative Council shall be matters of substance with national implications including national aspects of:
(i) the Commission's objectives and their implementation in relation to equal employment opportunity programs, industrial democracy programs and other programs;
(iii) the Commission's personnel and staffing policies and practices;
(iv) the Commission's accommodation and staff amenities;
and any proposed changes including technological changes affecting these matters.
State Consultative Councils: Without limiting the scope of consultation at the state level, matters for consultation at State/Territory consultative Councils could include:
(i) individual staffing issues that do not have national policy implications;
(iii) information held by the State Head Offices;
(iv) matters affecting Divisional Returning Offices within a State not being matters with National policy implications;

but should not include matters which have been or are to be the subject of negotiations at national level other than consultation and negotiation at the State level on implementation of national decisions.

(3) The National Consultative Council consists of 6 management representatives and 3 representatives each from the Administrative and Clerical Officers' Association and the Australian Public Service Association. Representation on the State Consultative Councils varies: there are 6 management and 6 union representatives on the NSW Council; 4 management and 4 union representatives on the Victorian, Queensland, South Australian, and West Australian Councils; 3 management and 3 union representatives on the Tasmanian Council; and 2 management and 2 union representatives on the ACT Council.

(4) The National Consultative Council has met 7 times. The State Consultative Councils have met on the following number of occasions: NSW 10; Western Australia 6; South Australia 4; Tasmania, Queensland and Victoria 3; ACT 2. Matters discussed were as outlined in (2) above.

(5) and (6) Yes. 1985/86. The only funding provided is to meet the travel costs of management and union representatives in attending council meetings. Expenditure in 1985/86 was $1,767; in 1986/87 $10,066; in 1987/88 $7,493.
(7) The Councils have no role in relation to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters nor has their existence or operation been considered by the Joint Standing Committee.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 16 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Government aware that the universities in Queensland which are receiving substantial Commonwealth funding, have taken a decision to cease the payment of full pay to their non-academic staff while they are fulfilling Defence Force Reserve commitments.
(2) Is this an isolated instance, or can the Minister advise how many reservists are being treated in this way by their employers.
(3) What action does the Government intend to take with respect to the decision of the universities in Queensland.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government is aware that the universities in Queensland that receive Commonwealth funding, have taken a decision to cease the payment of full pay to their non-academic staff while they are fulfilling Defence Force Reserve commitments. This situation is the result of the universities proposed productivity agreements with the non-academic staff unions arising out of the need for a 4 per cent productivity improvement to offset pay rises.
(2) This is an isolated instance involving approximately 20 reservists.
(3) Representations will continue to be made by the Government for the universities in Queensland to reconsider their decision.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 16 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: On 10 November last, did the Minister for Defence Science and personnel rule out any establishment of new wage guidelines for Defence Force personnel outside national guidelines; if so, does the Government intend to revise this stance in the light of recommendation No. 21 of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade report on personnel wastage in the Australian Defence Force which states that the Minister should `direct the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal to undertake a complete job analysis and job evaluation review of the Defence Force exclusive of national wage guidelines for the purpose of establishing wage levels'; if not, why not, given that the Committee stressed that the review need not result in wage increases?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel did rule out any establishment for new wage guidelines for Defence Force personnel outside national guidelines.

No, the Government does not intend to revise this stance. It is Government policy that the national wage guidelines be applied consistently and fully to all sectors of the workforce which are within the jurisdiction of industrial tribunals, including the Defence Force. To obtain the recent national wage case increases, the Australian Defence Force was required, and did give, a commitment not to pursue any claims outside the national wage case principles.
The Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal is an independent body and therefore the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel would be acting ultra vires to `direct' the Tribunal to undertake any task.

The Australian Defence Force already has in place a Work Value Project which is designed to conduct an empirical investigation and analysis of employment classifications and their relationships. This will facilitate the appropriate placement of employment classifications within the salary hierarchy in its present form. The application of the national wage case guidelines is not an issue relevant to these investigations. They become relevant only if the results are used as the basis for submissions to the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 19 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With regard to an article entitled `Uphill Battle for Nations's Defence Forces' in the Daily Telegraph on 15 December 1988 in which the Chief of the Defence Force, General Gration, suggested `creating a National Defence College to prepare senior officers for high command, which could also be used to train senior officers from regional allies such as Papua New Guinea or the South Pacific island states', what is the status of this suggestion.

(2) Does the Government intend to implement this suggestion; if so, how and when; if not, why not, given the emphasis of the Cross Report on the necessity and scope for the ADF to improve its managerial skills'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A National Defence College is one of several options canvassed in a number of reports on Senior Officer Development produced in recent years within the ADF and by outside consultants.

(2) General Gration's comments were in the context of ADF Senior Officer Development options. A departmental study in 1986 made recommendations on higher level training and education for senior officers which included a concept for a National Defence College type institution. The Chiefs of Staff Committee endorsed the training and education requirement but agreed that the resources needed to establish an additional facility or major course of study could not be made available in the foreseeable future. A Steering Group was established to keep Senior Officer Development under review and this has led a change in focus of the Joint Services Staff College Course as well as consideration of a proposal for a short Joint Senior Officer Study Period, which would complement attendance at overseas Defence and War Colleges, single-Service Study Periods and overseas study visits. These changes notwithstanding, the advantages of a National Defence College for Australian self-reliant Defence remain, and the proposal will be re-examined when resources permit.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the cost of the Australian Industries Mission to Singapore, Jakarta, Manila, Kuala Lumpur and Bangkok between 24 November and 9 December 1988.
(2) What product and technology services was the Mission promoting.
(3) Were any contracts signed as a result of the Mission; if so, what were they.
(4) Are any further defence export promotion visits planned in the future; if so, when and where are they going.

(5) Does the Government intend to publish an annual register of military exports along the lines of the one produced by the United States of America Arms Control and Disarmament Agency; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) SEAIM was a joint venture with funding from industry, Austrade and the Department of Defence. Setting aside salaries of officers on the mission, the costs to the Department of Defence including the Office of Defence Production for travel and accommodation expenses and publicity material were about $90,000.

(2) The Mission sought to promote Australian defence industry capabilities across the broad spectrum of products, services and technologies. Participating companies were broadly representatives of the major defence industry groupings within Australia, specifically Aerospace, Automotive, Electronics, Engineering (including systems integration), Ordnance and Shipbuilding.

(3) No contracts were signed during the Mission. However, expressions of interest were received and contacts made with a wide range of companies and agents operating in South East Asia. There is good potential for new business being written by Australian firms over the next 12 months.

(4) The Department of Defence, in close consultation with Austrade, is developing a comprehensive program of activities related to the promotion overseas of Australian defence products during the next 18 months. The program will involve participation by Defence, Austrade and local industry at exhibitions and trade fairs in the US, Europe and South East Asia as well as support to individual Australian companies seeking to enter highly competitive foreign markets.

(5) The Department of Defence only receives and approves applications to export defence and defence-related products controlled under Schedule 13 (B) of the Customs regulations. Compilation and publication of export statistics is the responsibility of the Australian Bureau of Statistics, not the Department of Defence.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 19 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the details of the resolutions passed at the Fourth World Wilderness Conference, held in Estes Parl, Colorado, during September 1987, relating to the establishment of a World Conservation Bank.
(2) What existing commercial or merchant banking organisations are involved in setting up the World Conservation Bank.

(3) Has any proposal been made to the Australian Government that areas in Australia listed with the World Heritage Commission be offered as collateral for such a bank; if so, what is the Australian Government's position.
(4) Are State governments being notified and consulted about such proposals.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The motion on an international conservation banking program or facility carried by the Fourth World Wilderness Congress, 13-18 September 1987, read as follows:
3. INTERNATIONAL CONSERVATION BANKING PROGRAM OR FACILITY
Taking note of the conclusion contained in the Report of the World Commission on Environment and Development-`Our Common Future';

`In order to marshal and support investments in conservation projects and national conservation strategies that enhance the resource base for development, serious consideration should be given to the development of a special international banking program of facility . . .
and believing, as expressed by the Commission Report, that such a program or facility;

`could provide loans and facilitate joint financial arrangements for the development and protection of critical habitats and ecosystems, including those of international significance, supplementing efforts by bilateral aid agencies, multilateral financial institutions, and commercial banks.'

1. Welcomes the intention announced at this Congress by the United Nations Development Program (UNDP), the World Resources Institute (WRI), IUCN and other organizations to draw up a proposal for a feasibility study for this purpose,

2. Believes that the terms of reference for such a feasibility study should be quickly determined and invites those institutions in a position to provide expert advice to send their suggestions to WRI urgently,

3. Invites these same institutions to support and participate actively in the feasibility study and to examine thoroughly all proposals which would advance the purposes presented in the WCED Report, especially new initiatives involving the private sector and entrepreneurial skills,
4. Expresses its appreciation to UNDP and other institutions supporting the study, and Requests WRI to inform the International Wilderness Leadership Founding of the status of the study,
5. Recognises that the feasibility study will need to demonstrate that the ICB facility would not encourage multilateral agencies to opt out of their environmental responsibilities,
6. Recommends that IUCN be invited to have the ICB proposal discussed at its next general assembly.
Sponsor: Caucus on `Financing of Conservation and Sustainable Development.'

(2) I have received advice from the World Resources Institute that no private banks are currently involved in setting up the World Conservation Bank or any other initiative that the Institute is working on.

(3) and (4) I was asked a similar question (No. 149) by Senator Bjelke-Peterson on 19 December 1987. The answer is No and I have nothing to add to my reply published at page 1788 of Hansard on 20 April 1988.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With the Introduction of the Champion Shots Medal, will the Queen's Prize for Proficiency in Shooting continue to be awarded to members of the Australian Defence Force;
(2) If not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Should Senator Watson be referring to the Queen's Medal for Champion Shots of the Army and the Queen's Medal for Champion Shots of the Air Force, then the answer is: No.

(2) The Australian honours system was established on 14 February 1975 with the intention that it should replace the use of British honours and awards in Australia. As announced by the Prime Minister on Australia Day 1986, approval in principle has been given for the introduction of a range of new awards for the Defence Force, including the Champion Shots Medal.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the: (a) military; and (b) other pros and cons of procurement of: (i) 4, 6 of 8 new Swedish submarines, (ii) 6, 8 or 10 new frigates, and (iii) 50, 75 or 100 FA-18 fighters.
(2) Do decisions by the New Zealand Government influence the answers to question (1); if so, in what way.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As with all military equipment, the principal military advantage of the acquisition of larger numbers of submarines, ships or fighters is that the resulting force has a greater capability. The priority for acquiring a particular number of a specific type of equipment is assessed against the background of Australia's strategic and geographic circumstances and the policies that derive from them, including the equipment's potential role in the kind of military operation that an Australian Government could credibly direct the Australian Defence Force to perform, and competing priorities both within the Defence portfolio and more broadly within the areas of Government spending. The supporting analysis is generally classified. From the point of view of construction or assembly in Australia, which it is the Government's policy to encourage wherever practicable, larger numbers can lead to economies of scale and thus make a higher level of Australian industrial involvement more feasible.

(2) New Zealand's potential involvement in the acquisition of equipment to be procured for the Australian Defence Force can lead to the benefits of enhanced interoperability and contribute to the industrial benefits of economies of scale mentioned above.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 September 1988 (Hansard, page 1016), Senator Sheil asked me a question without notice concerning job training courses on the Gold Coast. The Minister for Employment and Education Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Under the Community Training Program, The House With No Steps, the project referred to in Senator Sheil's question, receives $99,999 to sponsor the Human Resources Centre project. The sponsor also contributes $33,334 to the running of the project which provides employment related training to disadvantaged job seekers, and in particular, people with disabilities.

Participants in all Community Training Program projects volunteer to undertake training and not only receive training allowances equal to their unemployment benefits, but often receive other allowances for books, equipment, clothing and travel.

The project offers a comprehensive vocational assessment and personal development program, structured vocational training, supported work experience placements and job search training over a 16 week period.
All the courses run by the Centre are based on recognised training documentation:

Sex education is a small component of a life skills course designed to assist the participants to take more control of their lives-participation in this component of the overall course is optional. The sex education component is delivered by a consultant recommended by the Queensland State Department of Education.
The Human Resource Centre has applied for funding under SkillShare and is being considered as one of 14 projects providing specialist services for people with disabilities.
Senator Sheil has criticised a most worthy organisation which provides valuable training and assistance to unemployed people with disabilities, to enable them to enter the workforce.
Senator Sheil's view is not supported by the local community and employers. These have pledged continued support for the project.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 24 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the total of estimated staff and financial savings in all the Block efficiency scrutinies.
(2) What have been the actual staff and financial savings.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The earlier answer to this question, which was published in Hansard on 19 December 1988, pages 4561-66, inadvertently contained incorrect information for certain of the scrutinies. The answer was based on information supplied by the departments which undertook the scrutinies. The correct information for the scrutinies concerned is outlined below. The following summary information reflects these changes:

ANSWER.PARA: The total estimated net full-year staff saving for all scrutinies was 1 971.5 staff years; the total estimated net full-year financial saving was $135.1 million. The actual net full-year staff saving to date is 1 367 staff years; the actual net full-year financial saving to date is $88.8 million.
The scrutiny identified an additional staff requirement of nine ASL, costing $198 000 per annum. The financial savings identified were of two types:
(a) a saving of $500 000 in the funds required by portfolios for reporting services. This is a 10 per cent saving of the notional cost to portfolios before charges were introduced; and
(b) a saving of $1.3 million in CRS expenditure because of reduced demand flowing from the contraction in funds available.
No additional staff resources were provided and the additional workload has been absorbed, along with other implementation costs, into CRS operations.
The actual financial savings have been:

(b) the charges were introduced from 1 July 1988 and their effect on demand for services has not yet been felt. Any savings will be difficult to ascertain because of the effect of other efficiencies within CRS such as improved technology, efficiencies from the second tier salary negotiations, and improved management practices.
Service Personnel-direct credit of salaries (Department of Defence)

The scrutiny report estimated staff savings at 13 in 1987-88 and 49 in 1988-89. Implementation was expected to cost $0.194 million in 1986-87 and $0.708 million in 1987-88, with savings of $2.692 million in 1988-89 and $3.065 million in subsequent years.
The outcome is estimated to be staff savings of 17 in 1987-88 and 35 in 1988-89, a cost of $0.510 million in 1987-88, and savings of $1.341 million in 1988-89.

The reasons for the variations from estimated savings include the cost of additional computer hardware, higher than expected costs to develop software, slower than expected implementation for Navy personnel, and likely overestimates in the scrutiny report of cash delivery savings.
Pharmpay-(Department of Community Services and Health)

The scrutiny estimated that savings would amount to 293 staff by 1988-89. Gross savings were estimated at $8.4 million in a full year, with a cost of $2.0 million per annum for cash incentives to pharmacies. The staff savings achieved to date are indicated in the table below:
1. Recommendations rejected by Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee.
2. Expected implementation 1988-89. Savings expected to be lower than projected because of unexpectedly high number of pharmacists opting for the Claims Transmission System instead.
3. Involved the closure of a Department of Health State office.

The actual gross financial savings were $3 041 910 in 1987-88 and $6 329 600 in 1988-89. Cash incentives (which apply for only two years for each pharmacy) amounted to $678 000 in 1987-88 and $132 000 in 1988-89.
Design Work-Australian Construction Services (ACS) (Department of Administrative Services)
The scrutiny estimated that the additional return to revenue as a result of the introduction of revised fee scales for the non-budget sector would be $3 million.
The actual return to revenue in 1987-88 was $3.8 million more than the estimate of revenue prior to the introduction of the new fee scales.
First Home Owners Scheme (FHOS) (Department of Community Services and Health)

The Scrutiny recommended changes-which were subsequently introduced-estimated to save 44 staff in 1987-88 and a further 56 in 1988-89; in total a staff saving of approximately 25 per cent. The financial savings in salaries (including on-costs) and program outlays were estimated to be $1.35 million in 1987-88 and $6.0 million in the following two years.

The scrutiny recommendations were introduced in accordance with the approved timetable and the above savings for 1987-88 were achieved. Average staffing level and salary allocations for the administration of PHOS in 1988-89 have been reduced in accordance with the recommendations and the nominated savings are expected to be achieved this financial year.
Diesel Fuel Debate, Scheme (DFRS) (Australian Customs Service)

The scrutiny identified staff savings of 61 ASL. Financial savings were estimated at $12.77 million, broken down into $10.17 million for payments under the scheme and $2.60 million administrative costs.
The Government did not accept the recommendation to reduce payments under the scheme. This reduced the scope for savings to 45 ASL and $1.4 million.
In 1987-88 the actual impact was 33.3 ASL ($1.24 million). In 1988-89 the full saving of 45 ASL will be realised.
Corporate Services Division (Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet)
The scrutiny report identified scope for possible savings of up to 1.5 ASL in establishment record-keeping and accounts processing.
However, the machinery of government changes in July 1987 increased substantially the portfolio-wide responsibilities of the Corporate Services Division.
The scale of these changes and associated ASL adjustments meant that the resource implications of the scrutiny report were overtaken by events.

There are two components to this scrutiny. The office automation component includes the use of electronic mail. No staff savings were identified. The net financial estimates were a cost of $0.25 million in the first year, savings of $0.87 million in year two and savings of $1.15 million in the third and subsequent years. These savings will first apply in 1988-89.
The second component concerns use of Optical Character Recognition equipment to enable the automatic scanning of returned Continuation of Unemployment Benefit forms.
Implementation is now scheduled to commence on a progressive basis from March 1989, instead of the recommended date of July 1988.

Realisation of savings has consequently been delayed. The estimated staff savings are 15 positions in the first year, 40 positions in the second year, 30 positions in the third year and 20 positions in the fourth year. The net estimated financial effect of the proposal was a cost of $0.225 million in the first year and savings of $0.22 million in year two, $0.46 million in year three and $0.35 million in the fourth and subsequent years.

Each of the savings above has been identified as a contribution to the Department's commitment to achieve an efficiency dividend and savings due to the STRATPLAN re-equipment program. The figures quoted do not represent additional savings in the Department's forward estimates.
The scrutiny report estimated savings of $3.3 million in 1987-88, after implementation costs and efficiency dividends; and $4.9 million in a full year thereafter.
The 1987-88 figure was subsequently increased to $4.0 million because the Government did not allow the efficiency dividend.

Improvement in overpayment processing procedures saved the Department of Veterans' Affairs $4 million in 1987-88 and is expected to result in a saving of $4 million in 1988-89. These savings are largely achieved by reducing the time taken to process pensioner initiated reviews which result in reductions.

The scrutiny originally estimated that more than $40 million could be saved in a full year. This estimate was revised substantially prior to implementation because some recommendations were not taken up. Refinement of the original savings calculations reduced the estimates further.

Department's running costs budgets have been reduced by $5.4 million in 1987-88 and by $15 million in 1988-89 to reflect savings generated by this scrutiny. Savings are anticipated to rise to $17.5 million in 1989-90 and subsequent years. Apart from the recommendations which were not implemented the differences reflect that fact that the budgets for some agencies, such as the ACT Administration and some quasi-commercial authorities, have not been reduced because, for reasons of principle, funding for these agencies is subject to different budgeting disciplines. Although departments are required to implement the new travel procedures, they are not otherwise bound as to the internal operational arrangements they apply nor does the Department of Finance monitor this sort of detail. This is in accord with the general approach now taken to controlling departmental staffing and other running costs by pegging each agency's total funding for these purposes and leaving it to departmental managers to find the most efficient and effective use of these administrative resource funds now that they are thus limited.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 25 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Minister outline the shortfall, if any, of Australian university graduates in the following fields: (a) medicine; (b) general science; and (c) engineering.
(2) Will the Minister also outline whether or not the lack of graduating trade apprentices poses any difficulty to Australia in the future.
(3) If there are difficulties in these areas, what measures are being taken by the Australian Government to address these difficulties in the short and long term.
(4) Has the assistance of the State Governments been sought to address any problems that might exist.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) There are no general shortages of graduates in the field of medicine. Medical workforce requirements were examined by the Committee of Review into Medical Education and the Medical Workforce, which presented its report to the Government in April this year. It found that compared to other western countries, Australia was well supplied with medical practitioners.

(b) As general science graduates are employed across a wide spectrum of industries and occupations, it is not possible to make a generalised assessment of labour market shortages. However, these graduates are highly employable in the labour market generally, as evidenced by their unemployment rate of less than 4%. Graduates in all fields of study find jobs more easily than do non-graduates, particularly those in scientific, technical and commercial disciplines. Because of the high levels of employability of these graduates, the Government has given high priority to these fields of study in allocating additional higher education places.

(c) Shortages have emerged in the past 2-3 years in the fields of electronic and industrial engineering. Maintaining an adequate supply of engineers is clearly vital if the impetus of economic restructuring is to be maintained. In recognition of these concerns, the Government has been increasing the number of higher education places available in these fields.

(2) The low level of apprenticeship intakes in the early 1980's prior to the Hawke Government coming to office resulted in historically low numbers of apprentices completing their four-year training and entering the workforce. However, since 1982-83, apprentice intakes have increased by almost 60% and have been at record levels during the last few years.

(3) The Commonwealth Government has allocated a total of $142 million to the trade training system in 1988/89. This represents an increase of 17% over expenditure in the previous year. Incentives and support are provided to employers and apprentices through the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice full-time training (CRAFT) and the Special Apprentice Training (SAT) programs. The Government's aim in providing this funding is to assist in meeting the long-term needs of the economy for trade skills by improving the efficiency, flexibility and equity of the trade training system.
(4) The Commonwealth consults with State/ Territory governments on skills training issues on an on-going basis through the Commonwealth-State Training Advisory Committee (COSTAC).

COSTAC is a national forum for consultation and coordination in relation to the operations of the vocational training system. It has played a key role in facilitating changes to the apprenticeship system and in establishing the Australian Traineeship System (ATS).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 24 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the statement of 25 May 1988 by the Northern Territory Minister for Mines and Energy Mr Barry Coulter, relating to prospects for the Territory's nuclear industry accurate, particularly in the light of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development's assessment that the slight excess of demand over supply will be met from massive inventories till at least 1995, and the assessment in the Nuclear Engineering International that there will be little new expansion after 1995 and virtually none after 1997; if so, where will the expansion come from, given that it is now too late for new uranium orders to come on line till after 2005.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of the statements to which the honourable senator refers.
As a general observation it is true that drawdown of uranium inventories will be a major factor in the next few years in balancing the overall demand supplysituation.
The most recent publication of the OECD/NEA and the IAEA on production demand summaries the outlook to year 2000 in the following terms:

Reactor related uranium requirements are expected to continue to rise from their current (1986) level of 39,200 tonnes U to about 52,400 tonnes U per year by the year 2000. Because uranium inventories are, in general, still above desired levels, some utilities will meet part of their requirements by a drawdown of inventories. Therefore, while production capability will exceed reactor requirements until the early 1990s, actual production of uranium is expected to remain below reactor requirements until desired levels of stocks are reached.
In arriving at projections of Australia's market opportunities, it is more relevant to consider estimates of uncommitted demand rather than overall demand and supply.

In the short term, given the oversupply situation in the market, there are few opportunities for sales at realistic prices. At present the uranium buyers and the utilities most certainly hold the upper-hand and the market is characterised by sellers who are prepared to continually undercut each other on prices to secure the limited opportunities available.

Looking further ahead, however, projections for demand not yet under contract show a substantial expected increase in the latter half of the next decade. Uncommitted demand is expected to rise from 14,720 tonnes U in 1992, to 36,127 tonnes U in the year 2000. On current projections there will also be a corresponding dramatic decline in inventory levels by the end of the century. While a good deal of this uncommitted demand could be met through existing operations, some of which could readily be expanded, there are likely to be, on strict economic criteria, opportunities for some new uranium operations selling into a tighter market, in the medium term.

As to the overall expansion of the nuclear industry, nuclear power capacity in the Western World countries is projected by the OECD/NEA to increase from its current level of around 266,700 MWe to around 341,800 MWe in the year 2000.
It should be noted that many factors can change estimates of demand and that past projections have generally overstated potential demand.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 31 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that there is not one member from the field of educational research on the interim Australian Research Council (ARC) and its advisory committees for the social sciences and humanities; if yes, why is this so; if not, why not.

(2) Does the Minister agree that there appears to be a clear bias against the field of education in the make-up of these committees and that there are apparent imbalances in membership of the advisory committees; if yes, what is he doing to rectify the situation; if not, why not.

(3) Is the Minister aware of Australian Association for Research in Education (AARE) estimates that for universities and Colleges of Advanced Education combined, approximately 12 per cent of total academic staff are in education; if not, why not.

(4) Does the Minister agree that on the basis of these figures, at least one representative on the interim ARC or its advisory committees for the social sciences and humanities should be from the field of educational research; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Government policy is to achieve the most broadly representative membership in terms of experience and expertise. However, it is impossible for the Australian Research Council (ARC) to always have as a member, an expert from every academic discipline relevant to its work. The Committee members were selected on the basis of their standing in the research discipline, their availability and willingness to devote a considerable amount of time to the Committee's work, and the extent to which their expertise complemented that of the other members.

The findings of the recently established Committee of Review of Higher Education Research Policy chaired by Professor Bob Smith, the Chairperson of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training, are expected to influence the size, structure and role of the ARC Advisory Committees. The Smith Committee of review will be addressing a range of issues central to the task of maximising the research potential of the higher education system.

(2) No. Ten of the eleven members of the Humanities and Social Sciences Advisory Committee are from higher education institutions and are representative of the major discipline areas which are the concern of the Committee.
See also the answer to part (1).
(4) No. Members of the ARC and Advisory Committees are appointed as individuals on account of their experience and expertise and not as the representatives of any group or institution.
See also the answer to part (1).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

(2) What specific actions has Australia taken over the past 254 months with respect to the dumping of toxic wastes in the oceans and seas to prevent this practice, and what specific actions have been taken with respect to the Italian ship referred to by `The Age'; if no action has been taken yet, why not.
(3) Does the Government intend to take any action; if so, what form will this take.
(4) If action has been taken, what did it involve and when and where was it carried out.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australia has been a Contracting Party to the Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter (which is known as the London Dumping Convention, LDC) since September 1985. Relevant Australian legislation is the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981.

(2) The dumping of wastes and other materials into Australian waters by vessels, aircraft or platforms, and such dumping by Australian vessels, aircraft and platforms into any part of the sea, have been regulated in accordance with the above legislation since this came into effect on 6 March 1984.

The Italian ship referred to by `the Age' appears to have made the transit between Nigeria and the United Kingdom. Neither the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories nor the Department of Transport and Communications has had any indication that the vessel either has or intends to come within Australian jurisdiction.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Minister for Defence announce on 30 September 1987 that the Government intended to replace 7 VIP aircraft by leasing `no later than mid-1988' 5 new aircraft, of which 2 would be capable of `carrying 30-40 passengers' with the remaining 3 able to carry 10-15 passengers each.
(2) Has the Government, instead, selected 5 15-19 passenger French Falcon 900 aircraft which are unlikely to be in service before mid-1989.
(3) Why was the VIP fleet proposal changed, by whom and on what recommendation.
(4) What was the selection criteria for choosing the new aircraft.
(5) How does the Government intend to provide for VIP flights which require seating for more than 15-19 passengers.

(6) Did the Department of Defence recommend to the Government the purchase of Canadair aircraft, which would have brought considerable benefits by way of defence offset spending, as well as having capital costs of about $25 million less than the Falcons, representing an all up saving of up to $50 million.
(7) Who made the decision to purchase Falcon aircraft.
(8) Was the selection of the Falcon 900s based on Departmental recommendations or was the selection the result of a personal preference by the Prime Minister or other Ministers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The relevant News Release (no 149/87) included: ``Although no firm timetable had been set, it was hoped that the replacement aircraft would be available no later than mid-1988''.
(2) Yes. the Government has decided to lease five 15 passenger Falcon 900s due to enter service in September to December 1989.

(3) A Cabinet Subcommittee consisting of the Prime Minister, Minister for Defence and the Minister for Finance determined the aircraft type and numbers to be acquired. This decision was made following detailed contractual negotiations with three of the companies that had tendered.
(4) The main selection criteria for evaluating the aircraft proposals were:

aircraft operational capability and performance; cost, including life cycle costs; support arrangements; Australian industry involvement; and compliance with contractual and other requirements in the RFT.

(5) VIP Flights which require seating for more than 15 passengers will be provided by the use of the RAAF B707 aircraft, two more of which were acquired last year bringing the total to six, or by the use of charter aircraft or by the use of two or more Falcons together, depending on the task.

(6) No. Comparisons of aircraft size, range, utility for current and prospective tasks, along with prices and contract terms and conditions for operations and maintenance, and Australian industry involvement, resulting from the negotiations, were placed before the Cabinet sub-committee by the Department, without a specific recommendation. Cost-capability consideration of these factors determined the number and type of the aircraft. Strong Operator preference was expressed by the RAAF for a single aircraft type fleet and the larger of the two medium aircraft was considered a more flexible and cost-effective way of meeting future requirements, noting the availability of the B-707s.
(7) The Cabinet Subcommittee consisting of the Prime Minister, Minister for Defence and the Minister for Finance made the decision to lease the Falcon aircraft.
