(a) no contribution was required from the applicant; and

(b) the assessed costs included solicitor and junior and senior counsel in view of the importance and complexity of the matter after it was noted that the respondents were represented by senior as well as junior counsel.

(3) Mr Thompson's solicitors lodged the following documents in support of the application for financial assistance-solicitors' letters supporting the application, show cause orders of 14 July, 21 July, 1 August and 21 October 1988, applicant's affidavit of 14 July 1988 in support of the first show cause order (omitting the annexures), his further affidavit of 20 July 1988, affidavit of one respondent of 18 July 1988 and of a witness of 18 July 1988, respondents' points of defence, applicant's statutory declaration as to personal and financial circumstances of 27 July 1988.

There are over 90 pages of material involved in part (3) of the Question and it would be impractical to attach copies. Further, in respect of the information furnished by the applicant as to his personal circumstances, I consider that such information which affects the privacy of an individual should not be disclosed unless this is desirable in the public interest.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 13 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Australian Research Council publish an annual report on the outcome of 1988 grant applications, as in previous years, containing information on the amount of grant by title, the names of the principal investigators, academic discipline and institution; if not, could the information nevertheless be made available to Parliament.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Nevertheless, a report containing a list of research grants awarded under the Australian Research Grants Scheme, the Marine Sciences and Technologies Grants Scheme and the National Research Fellowships Scheme will be published as a Departmental paper setting out the name of the grant recipient, the value of the grant and a plain English statement on the objectives and benefits likely to arise from the research. The report is expected to be available by April 1989.
It will be a Departmental report because the Australian Research Council was established only on an interim basis in December 1987, after the completion of the 1988 grants round.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 14 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What land in or adjacent to Sydney Harbour has been, or soon will be, vacated by the Defence Forces as a consequence of the relocation to Jervis Bay.
(2) What has been, or will be, done with the land so vacated given that the Government purports to be concerned with social justice and has a commitment to improving housing.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) When the Jervis Bay Armament Depot is completed, it is intended that the Newington Armament Depot be closed and the property disposed of by the Commonwealth.
Any transfer of east coast Fleet Base activities to Jervis Bay will not occur for some time into the future. Any property implications around Sydney Harbour will be considered at that time.

(2) The overall responsibility for disposal of Commonwealth land rests with my colleague the Hon. Stewart West, M.P., Minister for Administrative Services. State and Local Governments are consulted about the sale of significant properties and final land use after sale is ultimately the concern of those Governments.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Science and Technology Centre: Entrance Fees

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 14 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How were the entrance fees of $6 per adult and $3 per child for the new Science and Technology Centre determined;
(2) Are these fees in accordance with the main aim of encouraging frequent visits by families and/or students;

(3) Will consideration be given to the issue of concessional family, monthly and yearly tickets as well as one day per week free entry for school children, as is done at the Australian National Gallery.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Basic fees of $5 per adult and $2.50 per child were recommended by Peat Marwick Hungerford in a detailed market and financial assessment of the National Science and Technology Centre commissioned jointly by my Department and the Department of Finance. Subsequently a surcharge of $1 per adult and 50 cents per child was added by the Centre to support the ``Dinosaurs alive'' Exhibition during the period of its display in Canberra.

(2) The Peat Marwick Hungerford's study considered potential visitor market segments and provided visitor forecasts based on similar studies carried out by the Australian War Memorial, Parliament House, the Australian National Gallery, the High Court and Questacon. In determining its suggested pricing policy the consultants agreed that young families would form an important element of the Centre's market, and recommended a charge which they considered would not act as a disincentive to the objective of attracting students to the Centre.

(3) The Centre has recently introduced a family admission and a student concession rate and is developing a membership scheme which will provide, amongst other things, reduced fees or free entry for persons wishing to make frequent visits to the Centre. Other than this, there is no present plan to provide free entry one day per week for any category of visitor.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 14 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Government support a national public inquiry into the proposed Very Fast Train (VFT) project before any decisions are made by the Federal, State or Territorial governments in relation to the proposed route of the train.

(2) Will the government advise the VFT consortium that no approvals will be given and no support in principle will be provided unless detailed information is made publicly available on a range of alternative routes.

(3) Has the Australian Capital Territory Administration strongly supported the VFT proposal, in contravention of the Prime Minister's directive that no such support be given to the project; if so, will the Minister ensure that such support will cease forthwith and not recommence until such time as the Government has had the opportunity to consider the recommendations of a full public inquiry into the project.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Firstly, I should make it clear that the Federal Government's policy is that the VFT project is a private sector venture and the Government has no plans to be involved in the financing or operations of the railway.

A project of this magnitude does of course encompass a wide range of complex issues, including environment/social, technical, economic and financial aspects, all of which will need to be thoroughly dealt with by the VFT Joint Venture if the proposal is to proceed. The Joint Venture has therefore commenced a 2 year feasibility study, to cost some $19m, which will examine in detail the matters mentioned above. (The first stage of the feasibility study, a Concept Report which outlines the proposal and lists many of the issues that require detailed study, has recently been published by the Joint Venture).

A major element in the feasibility study will be an environmental impact study which will be an integrated exercise to ensure that the requirements of the Commonwealth, New South Wales and Victorian Governments are met. This should ensure that all the environmental and social issues relevant to the proposal are thoroughly canvassed-with opportunity for public input.

It is too early in the feasibility study process to make decisions on the need for (or desirability of) including formal public hearings in the process, especially as there is as yet no detailed information (in the form of a draft environmental impact statement or equivalent document) available on all the issues on which questions could be raised.

(2) The normal environmental assessment requirements of the Commonwealth, Victoria and New South Wales require that consideration be given to alternatives including, in this case, the question of alternative routes. The VFT Joint Venture has acknowledged this and, in its Concept Report, has clearly stated that it will be making a detailed examination of alternative route options in the Albury corridor.

(3) The ACT Administration has no view upon and has not expressed support for the VFT Joint Venture. The Administration is involved in the Commonwealth's participation in the Intergovernmental Group on the VFT, which is a co-ordinating body of officials monitoring the project. The formation of this body was proposed in August 1987 by the then NSW Government. As indicated by the Prime Minister when approving Commonwealth participation in the Intergovernmental group, such participation does not imply support for the VFT project and is on the understanding that the project develops entirely as a private sector initiative.
The Canberra Development Board, which is a ministerially appointed, independent advisory body, has expressed public support for the VFT proposal.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 19 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has an exemption been sought for the Lady Franklin to sail to Antarctica, in view of the 1987 Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade declaration that shipping traffic between Australia and its claimed Antarctic Territory is internal Australian traffic; if not, why not.

(2) Is there any basis to the allegation that in December 1985 the Nella Dan was allowed to sail while some persons involved with the Antarctic Division knew the engine to be damaged; if so, have any enquiries been made concerning the allegation, and what action has been taken.

(3) Is it correct that on the Lady Franklin's first visit to Macquarie Island the ship departed without the necessary scientific equipment as part of its cargo; if so, how was the equipment transported to Macquarie Island and at what extra cost.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. For many years foreign flag ships have been chartered for Antarctic work because of a lack of local ships with ice breaking capability. Without these specialist ships Australia's Antarctic program would not have been possible. For this reason the Coasting Trade Provisions of the Navigation Act 1912, which require ships engaged in State-State or State-Territory trade to be licensed, have never been strictly enforced for Antarctic supply operations.
The Aurora Australis, which will be operated to support Australia's Antarctic activities from the 1989/90 season, will be crewed with Australian seafarers trained in ice conditions.

(2) The Nella Dan did not sail in December 1985. It is presumed that the question refers to an allegation made in a submission to the Joint Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee Inquiry into the Management of the Antarctic Division. The voyage which was referred to in the submission departed Hobart in December 1986, not December 1985.

Such an allegation was made to an officer of the Antarctic Division after Nella Dan returned from the voyage in question. The officer discussed the allegation with the Nella Dan's officers. He was satisfied that the allegation was without foundation and no further action was taken.

There is no known basis to the allegation that the Nella Dan departed Hobart in an unseaworthy condition or with its engine damaged, or that any officer of the Division had any prior knowledge of any such condition or damage.

(3) Some scientific cargo was not transported to the Lady Franklin for shipment on its first visit to Macquarie Island this season. The cargo was later air-dropped to the Island by the RAAF. The air-drop was used as an alternative training exercise to provide valuable tactical crew training and was funded by the Department of Defence from existing training funds. It therefore did not result in additional expenditure other than for aircrew accommodation expenses in Hobart totalling $927.50.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many truck shipments of ammunition were made: a) from Royal Australian Navy Armament Depot (RANAD) Kingswood to RANAD Newington; and b) from RANAD Newington to RANAD Kingswood, in the period 1 July 1987 to 30 June 1988.
(2) What is the maximum Nett Explosive Quantity which can be carried by trucks carrying ammunition between RANADs Newington and Kingswood.

(3) What methods and quantified risk factors are used to calculate the risks of an accidental explosion during handling, storage and transport on land and water of ammunition moving through the Sydney pipeline.
(4) What is the: a) estimated cost; and b) completion date, for the proposed shift of RANAD Kingswood to the Jervis Bay Armament Depot.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The maximum amount of explosive permitted to be carried by road under the Commonwealth Explosives Regulations and associated Ministerial Orders, issued by the Minister for Transport and Communications, is 16,000 lbs (7,557 kg). The maximum amount usually transported between RANADs Newington and Kingswood is 1,200 kg because of truck capacity limitations and current Net Explosive Quantity limitation in force at the Newington Wharf.

(3) In the 105 years that Sydney Harbour has been declared a Naval Ammunitioning area, there has never been an accident involving explosives which has caused damage to public property or injury to members of the public. The probability of an accident is very low and although there is no single numeric quantification of risk, assessment of the risk takes into account:-
c. traffic accident on road or water;
d. effects of radio frequency transmission;
f. structural collapse of bridge, building, etc;
h. political or social activities; and

(4) RANAD Kingswood is not proposed to be wholly relocated to facilities currently planned to be provided at the Jervis Bay Armament Depot (JBAD). On present planning, guided weapons storage and maintenance facilities will be retained at RANAD Kingswood for some time. It is not possible to provide a separate figure for the cost of the transfer of those activities which will move from RANAD Kingswood as the JBAD is also proposed to replace RANAD Newington. The current project cost for JBAD is $176,145,000.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will members of the Australian Defence Force continue to be eligible to receive (A) The Air Force Cross; (B) The Air Efficiency Award; (C) The Queen's Commendation for Valuable Service in the Air, for appropriate devotion to duty and bravery in carrying out peace-time air defence and rescue work.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The Australian honours system was established on 14 February 1975 with the intention that it should replace the use of British honours and awards in Australia. Service that would previously have rendered a person eligible for the award of the Air Efficiency Award may attract the award of one of the Defence Force Service awards and, where appropriate, the National Medal.

In relation to the Air Force Cross and the Queen's Commendation for Valuable Service in the Air, exceptional devotion to duty may receive recognition in the Order of Australia; bravery in carrying out peace-time air defence and rescue work may be recognised by the award of a Bravery Decoration.

In addition, The Queen has given approval in principle for the institution of the Conspicuous Service Cross and the Conspicuous Service Medal in the Australian honours system. When formally instituted, these decorations may be awarded to recognise outstanding or meritorious achievement or devotion to duty by members of the Defence Force in non-warlike situations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 November 1988 (Hansard, page 2759) Senator Hamer asked a question without notice concerning the setting up of a Commonwealth Government inquiry into research policies. He asked:

ANSWER.PARA: Will the inquiry be able to recommend the reversal of the proposals for centralisation of higher education research?
The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

There are no proposals for the centralisation of research. The thrust of the White Paper is for devolution of responsibilities to institutions for higher education research. Components of the operating grant are not separately identified, so institutions will be free to determine the most efficient allocation of funding amongst the various categories of expenditure, including research.

The Smith Committee is being asked to provide an assessment of the implications of the transfer of a small proportion of funds from the universities operating grants to the Australian Research Council (ARC).

Advice is also being sought about ``a process whereby the amount of operating grants subject to transfer in respect of the medical schools, can be reallocated through the NH&MRC'' (Terms of Reference 6).
He also asked: Will the inquiry be able to point out that even though the White Paper refers to deregulation it in fact goes in the opposite direction? The Minister has provided the following answer:

The Government's intention, through the White Paper, is to provide institutions with enhanced autonomy within a framework of accountability. Institutions are being asked to manage their scientific research, to think more strategically about their future directions and develop research management plans which set out their objectives, strategies and targets for research.
This is not an unreasonable request, considering the enormous contribution from the Commonwealth Government to the development and maintenance of the research enterprise in higher education.
Indeed it is pleasing to see how quickly and positively many institutions have responded to this request.
The thrust of the White Paper is also for selectivity and concentration of research with a continuing commitment to a strong basic research capability.
He asked: Is not the centralisation of educational activities totally discredited around the world? The Minister has provided the following answer:
All countries are looking to a number of key elements from their higher education research including:
development of highly skilled and trained people;
development of more interdisciplinary areas of research;
concentration of part of the research effort into designated priority areas;
encouraging interaction/links between higher education research and industry.
The Smith Committee is addressing many of these issues in its Terms of Reference.
He asked: Will this not lead to universities ranging from very good to mediocre? The Minister has provided the following answer:
Universities with a strong performance record in research will be enhanced further in their proven areas of expertise and in their ability to attract competitive research funds.
Other institutions will be encouraged also to attain excellence through concentrating their research effort into a smaller number of areas.
This would result in a more effective utilisation of scarce resources (manpower and funding).
He asked: Will the inquiry be able to recommend measures to prevent a de facto research quota for mediocre institutions? The Minister has provided the following answer:
The notion is at odds with the thrust of the Smith Committee's Terms of Reference.
The Committee is to provide advice on the scale and nature of the research effort that could be supported through higher education institutions.
He asked: Will the inquiry be able to recommend that the Minister should tear up the White Paper? The Minister has provided the following information:
A copy of the Committee's terms of reference is available for Senator Hamer's consideration.
